name: President. –
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday, 30 January 2020.

name: President. –
text: Good evening colleagues. I beg your forgiveness for a slightly late start to the session. The President, as many colleagues, is delayed and makes his apologies to colleagues. Many of us had some flight issues. My flight tried to land twice in Basel and failed, but it did land in Strasbourg, which is why I am here. So that was a happy relief for me, but obviously I know other colleagues have had difficult journeys. And bear with me, because I have literally just received the files and I will do my very best. *** I want to make an announcement please. On the occasion of the Day of Remembrance which is commemorated today, I would like to honour the memory of the Italian victims and all the victims of the Foibe massacres and the exodus of Istrians, Rijekans and Dalmatians from their land during and after the Second World War. The defence of democracy and tolerance and our daily commitment to European values are the best tribute to all those who are victims of these tragedies. The transition from opposing power blocs to a union for peace shows how important it is to continue working together for a Europe that puts values and respect for all its citizens in first place. Dear colleagues, we will stand for a moment in silence. (The House rose and observed a minute’s silence)

name: President. –
text: Following the new composition of Parliament and the numerical composition of the permanent committees adopted on 15 January 2020, I have received from the political groups and from the non-attached Members the appointments for Parliament’s committees, in accordance with Rule 209. The lists of the Members appointed to Parliament’s committees are published on Parliament’s website and will be annexed to the minutes. ***

name: Manon Aubry (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to make a point of the internal regulation on the basis of Article 125 and Annex 7 to which it refers. Since 1 January, the members of the European Commission have been illegal, but no one seems to be moved by it. Article 3 of the Commissioners' Code of Conduct requires them to publish their updated declaration of financial interest every 1 January, but none have done so. This oversight is not anecdotal. Several months ago, our Parliament demanded that several commissioners resign from boards of directors and sell shares that are sources of conflict of interest with their duties. However, if we look at the statement available online for the Commissioner in charge of digital taxation, this statement still indicates, for example, that he owns more than 100,000 euros of shares at Amazon. To fail to give evidence that this commitment, among others, has been kept, is to maintain an unacceptable doubt about the independence of the Commission. I would therefore ask you, Madam President, to demand that the European Commission respect this obligation to publish declarations of financial interest and that ethics take precedence over money once and for all.

name: President. –
text: Thank you for that information, Ms Aubry. We will pass it on to the President and ask him to take note. There is another point of order, from Ms Pereira.

name: Sandra Pereira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I invoke Article 196 of the Rules of Procedure to draw the attention of this Parliament as an official visit to El Salvador is being prepared by the Delegation for relations with the countries of Central America, which yesterday, at the orders of the President of that country, invaded the Congress, violating the Constitution of the Republic of El Salvador and seeking to intimidate and blackmail that Parliament. , compromising the democratic rule of law and peace. Here we sympathize with the Salvadoran democratic forces, who denounce this unacceptable situation, demanding that the European Union and its institutions do not contribute to whitening this act of authoritarianism of a scammer nature.

name: President. –
text: Colleagues, we are dealing with points of order, and while that is important information, it is a political statement. Are there any further points of order? If that is not the case, we will move to changes to the agenda. There are a number of requests for changes, so please bear with me in terms of the detail.

name: President. –
text: The final draft agenda as drawn up pursuant to Rule 157 by the Conference of Presidents at its meeting of Thursday, 6 February has been distributed. The following changes have been proposed: Monday: no request for change Tuesday The ID Group has asked for a debate on Council and Commission statements on the freedom of speech in the face of the rise of religious fundamentalism. They want this added as the fifth item in the afternoon of Tuesday, 11 February after the debate on the oral question on the New comprehensive EU-Africa strategy.

name: Jérôme Rivière
text: on behalf of the ID group. - Madam President, our request is motivated by a case now called in France the "Mila affair", the first name of a young girl who dared to criticize Islam. The 16-year-old has been subjected to an avalanche of death threats, rape calls and sexist insults for insulting Islam in a video posted to Instagram. While his words were closer to vulgar lyrics by rappers than to Victor Hugo's prose, they are the freedom of expression, the freedom to criticize a religion. Under no circumstances can these words justify death threats. Very few voices rose in France to defend Mila. For the dominant doxa, everything is criticised, we can make fun of everything except Islam. Some are prepared to reintroduce a crime of blasphemy in France, but on the condition that it applies only to Islam. This story illustrates, once again, the intellectual inconsistency and cowardice of our so-called elites. We reject this submission to an Islamo-leftism, to a communitarianism that has settled in our country, to a great cowardice that makes that politicians no longer want to impose a French way of life, an identity, a history. Not all religious fundamentalism leads to terrorism. Today, it is in the name of radical Islam that we murder. The Charlie Hebdo attacks tragically reminded him of this.

name: François-Xavier Bellamy (PPE).
text: Madam President, of course, we must defend freedom of expression, and what is happening in France, indeed, is a significant sign of this. My proposal is not against this debate, but simply to say that I believe that we need to put it in a broader context. We have a debate scheduled for Wednesday on the fight against anti-Semitism, racism and hatred in Europe, and our group would like to propose that the defence of freedom of expression that we must collectively ensure be included in this broader debate on the fight against hatred.

name: President. –
text: I will put the request for the modification of the agenda for Tuesday to the vote by roll-call vote. This is the ID proposal. Can I just be very clear that you know what you are voting on: this is the proposal from our ID colleagues to change the agenda on Tuesday and to have a Commission statement on freedom of speech. Is everyone clear? I shall halt the vote because there seems to be some confusion in the Chamber. The ID Group has proposed an amendment for Tuesday’s agenda, of which I have spoken. Mr Bellamy, as I understood, you want this to be included in an item that is already on the agenda. Please can you clarify because I think that is necessary.

name: François-Xavier Bellamy (PPE).
text: Our proposal would be, if all our colleagues accept it, to vote instead on this proposal to include the issue of freedom of expression in the debate that will take place on Wednesday.

name: President. –
text: Mr. River, do you accept that proposal?

name: Jérôme Rivière (ID).
text: If it is clear that, in this week's debate, we will have a debate on freedom of expression in the face of the rise of religious fundamentalism, then yes, we accept.

name: Jérôme Rivière (ID).
text: If Mr Bellamy's proposal had been accepted, we would have complied, we would have withdrawn our request at that time. As soon as it is refused, we want our request to be passed to a vote.

name: President. –
text: The Renew Group has asked that a debate on Council and Commission statements on the breach of Council Decision 2017/2074 concerning restrictive measures in view of the situation in Venezuela – illegal entry on the territory of an EU Member State of a person included in the list of sanctions be added as the second item in the afternoon after the debate on the Mavrides report.

name: Jordi Cañas
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, the purpose of this request concerns the Spanish Government's failure to comply with Decision 2017/2074 concerning the application of sanctions to members of the Nicolás Maduro regime. In the early morning from 19 to 20 January, the vice-president of the Venezuelan illegitimate government, Delcy Rodríguez, remained illegally on Spanish soil for fourteen hours, thus violating the sanctions regime promoted by this Parliament and approved by the Council of the Union.  The Spanish government, after denying the facts, has given more than six different versions, the last of which acknowledged that one of its ministers met about half an hour with Maduro's number two. This breach of EU law also occurred days after this Parliament recognised Juan Guaidó and urged the Council to tighten sanctions against the Maduro regime. In the face of this, we request that this Parliament debate this situation so that the Commission and the Council can report on the explanations received by the Spanish Government and assume, as it implies, whether it considers them sufficient or not. Because it is the Member States that are responsible for enforcing the sanctions determined by the Council and this Parliament, and if they did not, they would be turning these sanctions into wet paper by losing their full effectiveness. Because how effective can sanctions be when any government can breach them with impunity and without any consequence?  The european Union's international credibility and respect for the decisions of its... (the president interrupts the speaker) ... are at stake and this Parliament must debate this. Madam President, I would request a roll-call vote.

name: Javier Moreno Sánchez (S&D).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not think it is welcome that we use this House as a trench to attack the Spanish Government for no reason, because your request, Mr Cañas, corresponds only to partisan interests and I believe that the opposition is made in Congress and not in this House. Having said that, the Spanish Government has reiterated, from the outset, its commitment to the European line with regard to Venezuela. We want a negotiated, agreed exit with free and fair elections. And I would just like to remind you that it is the Commission which has repeatedly reiterated that the sanctions agreed in the Council are implemented by the Member States. I do not see what this Parliament can bring to this situation, it is its own interests, partisan - I have already said this. That's why we're against it.

name: President. –
text: We are dealing here with two Groups with proposals in relation to Vietnam. The Greens/EFA Group has asked that the consent vote on the conclusion of the EU-Vietnam Free Trade Agreement and the vote on the accompanying resolution be postponed to a future part-session. The GUE/NGL Group has asked that the consent vote also on the conclusion of the EU-Vietnam Free Trade Agreement and the vote on the accompanying resolution [and that the consent vote on the conclusion of the EU-Vietnam Investment Protection Agreement and the vote on the accompanying resolution] be taken off the agenda.

name: Emmanuel Maurel
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, we are indeed calling for a postponement of the vote, because the text - both on the free trade agreement but also on the investment protection agreement - clearly runs counter to what we voted on a few weeks ago on both the climate emergency and the European Green Pact. It is an agreement whose "sustainable development" chapter, in particular, is neither enforceable nor binding. So there is a dual language of the European Union that is problematic. But I would also like all colleagues, whatever their political sensibilities, to hear what the European Trade Union Confederation and the many NGOs - almost 100 European NGOs - are telling us about the state of labour law, trade union freedoms, but also human rights today in Vietnam. We cannot be content with vague promises from the Vietnamese government. Today, we need guarantees, we need proof, we need tangible, concrete. We do not have it, and that is why we are asking for the vote to be postponed.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the European Parliament has been calling in our Green Deal Resolution – not long ago, actually, this year – for binding and enforceable sustainable development chapters. Also, the Commission, which was just recently elected, has been saying that the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) are a key part of their agenda. This is the first free trade agreement (FTA) that will come with the Commission’s mandate. However, the FTA was negotiated without such a commitment before Parliament asked, in January, for this binding trade and sustainable development chapter. Also in January, this House voted on a report calling for streamlining human rights into all its policies. However, unfortunately, they’re not being streamlined into the FTA with Vietnam, because we have seen a lot of human rights violations – also just recently with the crackdown of a peaceful protest in January – and we’ve been asking for a firm and sanctionable commitment from the Vietnamese Government to improving the human rights situation. Nothing of this sort has been done, and that’s why we think this needs further commitment, from both the Commission and the Vietnamese Government. Therefore, we ask to postpone the vote on the four reports in total. (Applause)

name: Geert Bourgeois
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, it will be better with the micro, but I have nearly lost my voice so I will try to be clear.  I have to urge you, dear colleagues, not to postpone either the debate or the vote. There has already been a proposal in the Committee to postpone. It was rejected with a clear majority. The Committee chose a compromise: first, to monitor more the implementation of the two agreements, which is also the practice of the International Labour Organisation (ILO); and, second, to ask for more engagement from the Vietnamese authorities. Well, they delivered on the implementation of the ratification of the ILO Convention. They delivered on – and this is a precedent – a joint committee of our Parliament and the National Assembly to monitor the implementation of the two agreements. They delivered – and this is also a precedent – on the involvement of our Parliament in the human rights dialogue between Vietnam and the European Union. Lastly, they delivered on the independence of the organisations taking part in the domestic advisory groups. So it’s also a question of credibility alongside all the other arguments, of course.

name: President. –
text: The EPP Group has asked that a debate on an Oral question on ‘Better internet for children’ be added in the afternoon.

name: Jan Olbrycht
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, on behalf of the EPP Group, I would like to ask to add to our agenda the oral question to the Commission about better internet for children. It is important that 11 February is Safer Internet Day, which was initiated by the Commission in 2004. What we really need is activity to promote the safe access of children to the internet. So that’s why I think my colleagues will share the view that we need this kind of debate, not only among us politicians. It is also important for teachers and educators, so this is why maybe we can use the opportunity of Safer Internet Day to have this debate.

name: President. –
text: The Greens/EFA Group has asked that a Commission statement on the Intervention of four Member States regarding the revision of the EU-Competition Policy be added as the sixth item in the afternoon.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on 4 February, four Member States - France, Germany, Italy and Poland - wrote an open letter to the Commission urging Commissioner Vestager, say, to take a profound look at the competition policy which, I recall, under European law, falls within the exclusive competence of the European Commission, which has quasi-jurisdiction in this area. I think it is absolutely crucial that this Parliament can vote on this letter. It is, of course, open to any politician to feed the opinions he or she wishes. Nevertheless, I find that the tone of the letter and its character, I would almost say, comminatory justify a debate in this Parliament in the presence of Commissioner Vestager. I therefore propose that you hold this debate on Wednesday.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I believe that Mr Lamberts is absolutely right that this Parliament has to rule on competition policy, on that letter and on other debates on the revision of State aid rules. But I think it should do so through the official channels, and exactly next week the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs will vote on the annual report on competition policy and we are just days away from closing the negotiation so that we can vote on that report next Tuesday - which will in turn have to be validated in the next plenary session. I therefore see no reason to advance the debate to this week, when the ECON Commission negotiating teams are working to vote on a compromise text next week - as I say - in committee.

name: President. –
text: The GUE/NGL Group has asked that a Commission statement on the ‘EU-US trade relations’ be added as the first item in the morning. Therefore, the sitting would start at 9.00.

name: Anja Hazekamp
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, in a few weeks' time, the European Commission intends to negotiate a free trade agreement with Donald Trump's administration. The European Commission is negotiating with the United States on free trade in chlorinated chickens, hormone meat, Monsanto's gene crops and more agricultural poison. Allowing this type of product undermines our rules on animal welfare, the environment and public health and penally penally disadvantages europe's farmers. Moreover, Brussels is negotiating without the consent of the Member States: the Council has not given a mandate to negotiate agricultural products with the United States. Moreover, this Parliament has made compliance with the Paris climate agreement an absolute prerequisite for future trade agreements. Ladies and gentlemen, the European Commission is not concerned about this. I therefore call for your support for an urgent debate on the state of play in relation to trade negotiations between Europe and the US.

name: Christophe Hansen (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we, of course, are all concerned about our ongoing relations with the United States. We have to watch them very closely, but we have to do it the right way. That’s why we have invited Commissioner Phil Hogan next week to the Committee on International Trade (INTA). This work should firstly be done by the committees. Afterwards, we will of course have a debate in plenary, but first let the committees do their work as they should.

name: President. –
text: The EPP Group has asked that a debate on the Oral question to the Commission’s ‘Farm to Fork Strategy – the key role of farmers and rural areas’ be added as the first item in the morning on Thursday, 13 February 2020. I need to tell you that this means that the sitting would start at 9.00.

name: Norbert Lins
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has done so. The "From the Court to the Table" strategy is to be presented by the European Commission in mid-to-late March. This strategy affects, above all, our agriculture and our rural areas; their concerns deserve to be heard. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats therefore considers it essential that the central role of agriculture and rural areas be discussed before the strategy is published. Only in this way can important european parliament issues, such as financing, competitiveness and the link with the common agricultural policy, be included in the strategy. That is why the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats is asking for an amendment to the agenda under Rule 158 in order to put the oral question on the subject of 'from the Court to the table' back on the agenda of this plenary session.

name: President. –
text: The last proposal for a change to the agenda on Thursday is from the Renew Group, and they have asked that the debate on the ‘Human rights dimension of the Coronavirus outbreak’ be taken off the agenda.

name: Jan Huitema
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, the outbreak of the coronavirus is a very serious matter, but for the Renew Group, this is not the right topic for an emergency resolution. Urgencies are there exclusively to say something. If there is an act of human rights violations, for example. Also, the situation is still developing very rapidly, so it’s very difficult to come forward with concrete conclusions. Also, we risk, then, ending up with a very patronising stance, while we should focus much more on, for example, coordinating with other countries to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. I would like to ask you to withdraw this topic from the urgencies.

name: Esther de Lange (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I will pick up on the last words of Mr Huitema, who said that there is concern and that, given the fact that developments are going so quickly and citizens are concerned, we might actually need a wider debate on this issue than just to take it off the agenda as an urgency. My concrete proposal, given the fact that developments, both in the area and in the EU, in terms of concern among our citizens, are going so quickly, I would propose to have a full—blown debate, without resolution, on the topic ‘Coronavirus: ensuring fundamental rights and a coordinated European response’, on Wednesday afternoon, by the way.

name: President. –
text: We were talking about Thursday. So this is a proposal to move it back to Wednesday afternoon. I shall ask Mr Huitema how he would react to that proposal.

name: Jan Huitema (Renew).
text: – Madam President, that would be an excellent idea. Let’s do that.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with reference to Article 3(5) and (6) of the Treaty on European Union and Article 158 of our Rules of Procedure, I wanted to inform colleagues of the very serious situation that Patrick George Zaki, an Egyptian student who, thanks to Erasmus Mundus, has been attending the Gemma Master's degree in gender studies in Bologna since September, is currently going through.  A researcher, an activist who has dedicated his life to rights, equality and solidarity and to criticizing the denial of human rights in his country. Landing in Cairo on Friday night to visit his family, he disappeared to reappear the next day 120 kilometers from the capital, with obvious signs of physical abuse and violence, in a courtroom of the Egyptian attorney general, arrested and accused of criticizing the government via social media. Patrick has undergone the same treatment as Giulio Regeni, a case for which the young Egyptian has, among other things, spent himself. Ladies and gentlemen, I call on all the European institutions and the European Union delegation to act and to follow this case very closely, and I would ask you to add a debate on this point. I couldn't pick up... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: President. –
text: Mr Castaldo, I shouldn’t have to explain to you the rules of the House. An important point was raised, but it would be a one-minute speech, not a point of order.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the Commission communication on the review of the economic governance (2020/2553(RSP)). I would like to remind you that catch-the-eye and the blue-card requests can be presented either by using the consolidated way of registration or the electronic system. You will get the instructions in case you need them from the entrance of the Hemicycle.

name: Paolo Gentiloni
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank you and the Members for the opportunity to present here the communication that we adopted exactly five days ago. In this way, the European Parliament will trigger the debate on our six— and two—pack reforms and, in general, our economic governance rules. I think that the targets of this debate are very clear. We have, on the one side, to preserve our stability and nobody should discuss this. On the other side, we have to relaunch our growth and nobody should ignore this. The Commission’s Communication gives a clear and honest assessment on the functioning of these rules in the last ten years. The rules were created as a response to a deep economic and financial crisis and, after ten years, I think we can give a clear picture of how these rules have been functioning.  I think we had good results, first of all, in better coordination of fiscal policies, both on timing and on their content, among Member States, through the Semester and the whole surveillance process. Second, we were able to reduce our deficit—to—GDP ratio. I remember that in 2011, only three countries were respecting the rules on deficit—to—GDP. In the last assessment, not a single country was not respecting these rules. Third, I should say that all Member States that received financial assistance were able to return to the market, with enormous difficulties from a social point of view, but they have, at least, returned to the market. After good results, we have also had mixed results in our ten years’ functioning. First of all, I would say, on the reduction of debt, yes, debt was reduced from an average of 90% to an average of 80%, and this could be a satisfactory level if we consider other global economic players. The United States has 115% debt and Japan has 240% debt. But we know that, in this average reduction, we were not able to reduce high debt in several countries, so the discussion is still open. There were also mixed results because of the complexity of these rules. Complexity could also be an intelligent way to deal with problems but, if complexity is too complicated, in the end, it reduces ownership and confidence from Member States and stakeholders towards our rules.  Finally, we had clear shortcomings, first of all, because we were reducing our public investments. Our public investments are not yet at the level they were 20 years ago. Second, because we were not able to reduce surpluses in countries with a high level of surpluses, and, third, because, in general, we had pro—cyclical fiscal policies during this period and monetary policy is now at its lower bound. If we are not able to have anti—cyclical policies, this creates constraints in our general economic situation. So, good results, mixed results and shortcomings. What next?  I think we live in a very different economic world from the one from ten years ago. We were able to overcome the deep crisis and we had several years of stable growth in all Member States. We have now been in a period of slower growth for a couple of years. The picture for the next months, and perhaps a few years, is characterised by uncertainty, uncertainty for internal reasons – I think we all saw the bad results in the last quarter of last year in some important European economies – and uncertainty due to external factors: trade relations that are not solved, Brexit, which is an open debate, and the consequences of the coronavirus. It is obviously too early to assess them, but for sure they contribute to this uncertainty. In these uncertain times, I think we need a framework capable of avoiding what economists call a ‘low for long’ situation: a long situation of low growth, low inflation, low interest rate. This could be inconsistent with the strategy that we have in the green transition and in the digital transition. For this reason, the debate we are opening is very important, and we will define the scope and the conclusions of this debate during the next months in this process. In conclusion, I would particularly underline two key words. One is ‘investments’. We have to find ways to facilitate investments, especially those connected to the strategy of the Green Deal, which President von der Leyen rightly calls our new growth strategy. Second is ‘simplification’. To promote simplification of these rules is also to promote their ownership. I think that to facilitate investment and make our rules simpler is something that should not divide our discussion into different camps, but is something on which we should work together to find a solution.

name: Markus Ferber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The European Commission's communication on the Stability and Growth Pact contains many wise and correct observations on what is not working properly with the Stability and Growth Pact. The rules are very complex, they are non-transparent, they are sometimes pro-cyclical in their effect, and even in good times – you said that we have now had a period of growth – they have not contributed to a sufficient reduction in deficits and total debt levels. However, the conclusions drawn by the Commission in its key questions and comments for the consultation from these findings have relatively little to do with the problems described. The Stability and Growth Pact does not have a problem of flexibility – the last Commission has already extended what is possible in terms of flexibility; the Stability and Growth Pact has an enforcement problem. The rules do not need to be made more flexible, but they must be applied! And if we want to tackle the problem of excessive indebtedness effectively, then of course there is no point in excluding certain types of expenditure from the debt rules, and that will even have the opposite effect. Let me be clear: debt is debt. Any kind of new debt affects a country's debt sustainability, whether it finances sustainable investment or not. In the end, the question of whether the debts can be serviced and repaid is the only issue of interest to the financial markets, namely those that lend money to the Member States. Before the financial markets turn the tap on money, they will not ask whether or not they have been financed and invested sustainably here. That is why I can only strongly warn against classifying green government spending as good government spending. If we start with this, the path to the next debt trap is pre-programmed.

name: Jonás Fernández
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, welcome Commissioner, in the euro area we have nineteen different fiscal policies; nineteen governments draw up their budgets by trying to comply with the Stability and Growth Pact. But if one consolidates these nineteen policies, in search of the fiscal position in the euro area as a whole, the result may or may not be consistent with the needs of monetary union, with the cyclical needs of monetary union. And that is why we need to reform the Stability and Growth Pact. It is not only a question of improving flexibility for national governments to make countercyclical policies, but above all to give the euro area a consolidated fiscal position in line with the needs in the cycle of our economy. And that's what we need to focus on in the coming months.

name: Caroline Nagtegaal
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, the revision of the rules for the Stability and Growth Pact that we are discussing today is very important. What we are trying to do with this pact is to ensure a stable economy, a sound public financial policy. This is good for all European countries, including those who may not see it themselves. A Dutch folk wisdom reads: "Good example does good follow". But that is disappointing in this respect. Several countries have not used favourable economic time or have not used enough to implement reforms and reduce budget deficits. I would therefore like to give you a few points for this review.  First of all, for the effectiveness of the budgetary rules and the credibility of the European Commission, it is crucial to me that the rules are transparent and can be enforced. Secondly, the rules should be made simpler and less complex. The review should ensure sufficient countercyclical fiscal policy. Thirdly, the rules should not be more flexible or interpreted more broadly, as far as I am concerned. Appointment is just an appointment.  I am therefore also very critical of the European Budget Committee's proposal to place investment outside the scope of the Pact. As far as I am concerned, this is an open invitation to a kind of creative accounting that has already led to quite a bit of drama. Finally, a European stabilisation function is really unnecessary. As far as I am concerned, Member States must absorb the shocks themselves. That is why each Member State must have its own house in order. Well-functioning capital markets would also help to absorb those external shocks. That is why I would like to say to you: let us hurry in the development of the European Capital Market Union.

name: Silvia Sardone
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I must congratulate Commissioner Gentiloni sincerely, because it is not easy to speak for ten minutes without saying anything at all. Not that I was surprised, because I remembered your government, but I have to say that it seemed like the last of the bureaucrats, the classic pd who comes to Europe to take orders from others, in short. Now comes yet another rip-off with the approval of the State Rescue Fund, with the complicity of the Democratic Party and the 5 Star Movement. The Italian Parliament has spoken out against it, Conte has acted alone, he has decided to go ahead anyway, without any mandate, solely to save his chair, selling off our sovereignty. At the last he promised changes that we know perfectly well will never come. A high-debt country like Italy would have no convenience to draw from the fund. We will be like blood donors, in the full knowledge that we have no right to have a drop of blood even at the end of our lives.  I wonder, Commissioner, why no country can have a positive trade balance of more than 6 % of GDP on average for the three years, but can Germany decide to systematically violate this figure? It seems to be in a Europe that is sheriff only when it suits you, practically, only when it suits you. Italy has been blackmailed for years for a bit of flexibility. Then we will fight on the State Rescue Fund. We will fight against an attack on democracy and the savings of the Italians, which will certainly not have our support.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, thank you, Commissioner, the rules in recent years have been applied and have been dogmatic, inefficient. They have helped make things worse in the eurozone and need to be reviewed. I share some of the reflections you make in your communication: they are complex, they are procyclical. In addition, you would add, they are based in some cases on unobservable elements such as the famous output gap, which is totally unobservable, and it is on which we base the entire path of consolidation of national budgets. We therefore need somehow to deal with this debate and I welcome the Commission's doing so even though I think we should go much further.  I want to ask you two things, Commissioner. The first: let us not be afraid, even though we know that in the Council we will find a wall, of opening certain debates like these; we're going to be brave, we're going to put the Council itself in front of the mirror.  And the second: you're going to have to do smart application of the rules if we want the Green Pact to be a reality, because there won't be a Green Pact with strict application of these rules—we all know it—so that second part is also in your hands and it's going to be important that you do so.

name: Eugen Jurzyca
text: for the ECR Group. – Madam President, we have seen a slight improvement in the implementation of fiscal rules in recent years. Since the European debt crisis, most Member States have been able to reduce their debts compared to 2012 GDP. Some politicians are claiming greater flexibility in fiscal rules, which seems to mean, in particular, higher allowed deficits and debts. They prefer the short term, with the vision of re-election in the next elections, and not the long-term horizon that is necessary for the planning of sound public finances and the future of the people. I believe that what we need are not further exceptions allowing circumvention of the agreed rules, but a stronger framework for them, for their management and compliance. We have the financial rules in place for an important reason, which is to limit the fiscal blackness of the Member States and prepare for future crises through low debts.

name: Manon Aubry
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, for the past three months, the French have been demonstrating in the streets in songs, in dances, against pension reform. For the past three months, they have been fighting against a reform that will make them work longer for pensions of misery. This reform does not come out of nowhere, it is directly inspired by the recommendations of the European Commission and its budgetary control procedure. I have here the recommendations made by the European Commission to France, and it is written in black and white, page 6: the reform of the pension system could alleviate the public debt. Understand: we need to save money on our pension system - and that is exactly the ambition of the French system. But the Commission does not stop there. Page 5 reads: the reduction in public debt will depend on the government's ability to meet the spending targets set for the pension system. Understand: Public health is too expensive. The result: 17,500 beds closed in six years and carers on strike for a year, who are crying out for despair at the abandonment of the public hospital. In the Commission's recommendations, this is the case for all of our public services: social protection, the minimum wage level... Savings, more and more savings. And of course tax cuts for the richest and big corporations. Exactly what Emmanuel Macron's French government is zealously applying. This whole European Semester procedure is based on a single objective: the sacrosanct limit of 3% deficit - a rule fixed one day on a corner of the table, which has no economic basis and which is criticised even by the most liberal economists. The European Commission is now questioning the relevance of these rules. It's about time! But if the revision only sticks - as seems to be the forthment - to the integration of the Un Sustainable Development Goals, we might as well pee in a fiddle. It is the whole architecture of European economic governance that needs to be reviewed to meet the two challenges of our time: the inequality crisis and the climate crisis. This revision of the European semester cannot be cosmetic, because austerity will never be ecological or social.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first of all, I thank the Commission for the good piece of work it has presented to us. I believe that the last big changes to the fiscal framework are fully justified to reverse unsustainable fiscal policies in many Member States. The changes that took place have helped the countries to reform economic policy and have brought the fiscal policy in the EU and the euro area  closer to a sustainable path. But the mission is far from completed, because this is permanent work to perform just, responsible and sustainable fiscal policy.  The Member States should find good policies and the funds to promote the policies of the priorities, like the Green Deal. But at the same time, I am sure that increasing debt is not the right source of funding for these policies. Ultimately, after the consultation, I am open both to changes as well as to confirmation of the current set—up of the fiscal framework, depending on the result.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Many critics of the economic governance system call it a straitjacket of the euro. Why? Because it leaves the Member States little room for manoeuvre in political policy, because it more or less imposes on the Member States by forcing them to save money in such a way that it threatens to strangle them. Budget policy, as an essential instrument of economic management, has an important role to play in a balanced, well-being-oriented economic policy, and any future reorientation of economic governance must therefore primarily aim at socio-political progress and at strengthening social and environmental infrastructure. In the fight against climate change, but also for digital change, we need more European Union to have a Europe-wide coordinated investment offensive, and we need more state for public investment. Therefore, an important point for me is that the definition of net borrowing, the net deficit, must be designed in such a way that the golden rule is taken into account, that is, expenditure without public investment.

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her A common currency needs common budgetary rules. But let us not delude ourselves: the reformed Stability and Growth Pact has not made the necessary coordination of public expenditure binding, nor has it made member spending more forward-looking. The rules are so complex that even financial nerds like me can hardly understand them. This complexity gives the EU Commission too much leeway in the application of the rules. This has made the rulebook a policy instrument which, on balance, has had little effect. Worse still, European fiscal rules have brought widespread underinvestment in our public goods. Education, railways, the Internet – everyone suffers from it. Between 2009 and 2018, the government investment ratio actually fell – from 3.7% to 2.9%. However, we need investment-friendly budgetary rules; and we are able to achieve this with a depreciation scheme that favours all investments. Exceptions to the fiscal rules for green or digital investments alone, as you have proposed, do not solve the problem. Because we have the same problems with education, housing and health. That is why two things are now equally important: a consistent orientation towards the future and a simplification of the budgetary rules. Only comprehensible fiscal rules are also strong fiscal rules that can be implemented.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, Mr Gentiloni, a former Commissioner and former Prime Minister of your country — Italy, Mr Pronti — had called the Stability Pact 'stupid'. You were Prime Minister of Italy before you became Commissioner. Serious changes are needed and not just a discussion of the changes. Because we need to boost investment. Because, together with the simplification you have noted, flexibility is also needed. How do we reduce huge social and regional disparities if we do not combine sustainable development with secure public finances? Is it possible to implement the Green Deal with this absurd thorax of the Stability Pact, as it has been implemented for ten years? And why has the Commission been strict only with countries that have excessive deficits and have done nothing for countries that have excessive surpluses and break the rules? We want answers to these questions.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (PPE).
text: Madam President, I agree with Mr Gentiloni that we must do everything we can to increase public investment. I think we're applying the rules. For example, if you compare, the public finances of European countries are much stricter than that of the United Kingdom or the United States — because I suppose such comparisons must be made in a modern and competitive world. I also think that we have achieved a great deal. As a Greek, I can tell you that if, in 2012 or 2015, we said that Greece in 2020 would borrow on such good terms and with the ten-year bond at 1.1-1.2 %, no one would believe us. So I don't see us losing control. We haven't lost any control. But it is precisely because we are in control and because we have succeeded — at great social cost, of course — that we have to organise an investment campaign;

name: Margarida Marques (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Dear Commissioner Gentiloni, I would like to begin by thanking you for your proposal and the opportunity to have this debate here.  The rules of the Stability and Growth Pact show weaknesses. In 2020, a public investment rate below pre-crisis levels is expected in almost half of member states. Public investment is an essential condition for supporting sustainable growth. Long-term sustainability can be compromised. In this current assessment it is important: first, to ensure the promotion of countercyclical policies; second, to find a balance between a less complex and simple framework and, at the same time, flexible as necessary and sufficient; thirdly, to explore the flexibility of budgetary rules, in particular for greener investment, and to understand whether this is sufficient to make the necessary change to the euro area budgetary strategy; fourth, to promote greater transparency with indicators and methodologies that ensure more democracy and greater ownership and accountability by Member States.

name: Damien Carême (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, minus 0.25% for the CAC 40, minus 0.5% for the Nasdaq - every morning on the news, we are asked to do figures that we are trying to make believe are a sign of good or bad economic health. Three per cent deficit, 60 per cent debt, again, these numbers are a golden rule, supposed to show the good health of our economies. But when will we finally look at other figures that are much more important to our common future? The number of degrees in addition, the cost of climate change or the cost of social distress, for example. Etymologically, "economy" means "art of properly administering a house" - and our house burns. A healthy economy, therefore, is an economy that does everything to put out the fire. A responsible economy is one that encourages the transition to carbon neutrality by, for example, taking green investments out of the public deficit calculation.  That is why I ask you, ladies and gentlemen: let us take advantage of the announced revision of the European budgetary framework to get out of the dogma of austerity, to respond to the climate emergency. This is the greatest challenge of this century: let us set rules that do not lead us straight into the wall, but instead allow us to preserve life in our common home. It's up to us.

name: Pedro Marques (S&D).
text: – Madam President, this is a core debate for the future of Europe and of the eurozone in particular. We have managed to stabilise the economic and budgetary situation in Europe as a whole, but I would say that the current economic governance has had a limited and not always positive role in this achievement. We need the margin for long—term growth through investment, particularly green investment. We need a framework that is more concerned about the sustainability of growth, not just short—term budgetary indicators. We need much more flexibility at times of difficulties and particularly countercyclical and not pro-cyclical rules. And we need true macroeconomic equilibrium for all, not just for some. Otherwise, we risk prolonged stagnation in Europe and, one day, we will be condemned to be exporting to Mars, if some countries insist in not correcting their huge surpluses. Tough challenges we have, but the very critical one is ahead of us. Let’s embrace it, Commissioner.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner Gentiloni, the Stability Pact is the web of rules that guarantees the security and prosperity of the European Economic Area. At the same time, however, it must now be the tool for implementing the Green Deal and needs to be adapted as a matter of urgency. The adjustment hears in the name of 'investments'; green, sustainable, he handsomely funded — and from national budgets — investments.  On this basis I would like to ask you two questions directly. Firstly, do you plan to give Greece the opportunity to allocate additional fiscal space to green investments, especially in areas in transition from coal? How will this happen when there is such a high mandatory primary surplus? Secondly, do you think that investments can be made in areas in transition with special tax bands? In other words, by reducing value added tax especially in those areas, so that investors have another incentive to make green investments there and maintain the social cohesion of our regions, such as Western Macedonia and Megalopolis?

name: Juozas Olekas (S&D).
text: – Dear President. Commissioner, thank you for your presentation. I think we really all understand how important the stability pact is for the security of our finances. But I have been provoked to stand up and speak, indeed, of saying that the growth of our future can cross the green course. Are there really those rules that are (and could you comment more) that could limit our understanding of green growth as a challenge, rather than as an opportunity for our economy to grow more. And whether the complexity of the rules does not limit the crucial investment in high technology and science so that scientific achievements can be achieved here in Europe.

name: Mauri Pekkarinen (Renew).
text: – Mr President, thank you to the Commissioner for your presentation. Your message was pretty positive, I paid attention to it. You didn't notice much concern. However, you said that the debt ratio is still 80%. In the EMU Treaty, we have decided that in each country it should be 60%.  Moreover, over the last two or three years, the ECB has apparently been pushing eur 3 000 billion into the market.   And now my question is: Do you see any threats in the market that a similar bubble experienced just over a decade ago would peek around someone's corner? In this respect, do you continue to be calm and confident that the balance will be achieved in the European market?

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, economic governance wanted to create an almost absolute framework of embarrassment to any sovereign development project. As Mrs Merkel said, the idea is to ensure that even if governments change, they never change policy. European Union policies, the single market, the euro have created inequalities and imbalances. Wealth flows permanently to the center at the expense of the periphery, dependent and indebted. When the policies that brought us to the crisis should have been called into question and abandoned came economic governance, to ensure that they were imposed on irons, if necessary. We are paying the price of this, with the continuous draining of national resources to creditors, the lack of public investment, the weakening of the productive apparatus, the degradation of public services. There is no such review or flexibility as to us. We need to get rid of economic governance and the European Semester and the Stability Pact, instruments that tie us to low wages, dependency and stagnation and threaten democracy itself.  Commissioner, I know that the Commission has recently discovered its ecological vocation, but recycling is not even good for us, only the final dustbin.

name: Jutta Paulus (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I find it very interesting to see the verve with which we are discussing the fact that we should exempt sustainable investment from the investment rules. I think that makes a lot of sense, and I very much agree with that. At the same time, however, I find it surprising that this rule of sustainability does not seem to play any role at all in other investments. I am, of course, talking about the famous PCI list, which we will also be debating separately. In other words, billions are being sunk into investments, in fossil infrastructure, which we are proven not to need. We are producing stranded assets here, investments that are lost to European citizens, which are even more likely to fuel the climate crisis. I find it really fascinating that, on the one hand, we are talking about the fact that we may not want to look at sustainable investment quite so strictly, but on the other hand we want to distribute absolutely unsustainable investments with both hands.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, in an economic context quite different from that of a decade ago, with persistently low interest rates and below-potential production, the time has finally come to rethink what is the prevailing approach to the system of budgetary constraints.  The current rules are not able to adapt, in fact, to the needs of the moment. This is not only because of the content of the rules themselves, but also because of their asymmetrical application, which has led to the creation of a two-speed Europe, through the Commission's excessive pressure on public spending and the complete lack of attention to the systemic risks linked to macroeconomic imbalances in some countries. In short, at last, the Commission has also come to the conclusion of the importance of rethinking the current budgetary rules, in order to give more space to states to make investments, to combat unemployment and climate change, through the introduction of a Golden Rule for the unbundle of investments that we want, especially green investments, and even possibly green bonds. The stakes are high. I hope, Commissioner, that this path will be followed because rethinking it would be the last thing the eurozone needs.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I am convinced that what I am telling you, you know. But I want an answer. How do you find solutions? Of course we need to adapt economic governance to the real situation.  As has been said here, Europe is clearly two-speed. We have the euro area, the non-euro zone. We have a Schengen zone, we have a non-Schengen zone. We have states with different economic development. Instead, we have the same indicators, the same deficit. We cannot make investments while keeping a very low level of deficit.  How do we make the dedicated Green Deal fund allocated to areas that are less developed? What are you going to do by modifying this economic governance, in fact, to diminish regional disparities? Because the Juncker Fund has shown us that funds have been concentrated in 4-5 states (this is also the Court of Auditors' report) and that, in fact, regional disparities have increased. That is what we need to respond to by changing economic governance.

name: Clare Daly (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, there’s been a lot of talk from the Commission about reviewing the fiscal policies and the measures taken after the financial crash, but for me there’s precious little really in terms of the impact or the real effect on the citizens of Europe, and for me, the report is really a bit of a whitewash of austerity. I mean, you’re actually proud of the fact that you have reduced excessive deficits, as you call it, but no attention paid to the impact that that has had on citizens: the debts of bankers foisted onto citizens. And the result of that was seen in the election in Ireland over the weekend, where the citizens rose up against economic austerity, against the rules which have prevented investment in social and public housing, with rising homelessness and people’s inability to put a roof over their heads. The Commission says they’re interested in what could be done better regarding economic governance. Well I put it to you: how about changing the EU debt and deficit rules so that they don’t apply, for example, to investment in social housing. You’ve no problem doing it with arms expenditure. Could you not do it on social housing as well?

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I too believe that the stability pact has to be revisited. We’ve got to have a better format. The truth be told, too many citizens of Europe are being left behind because of your strict rules. People say that we need these strict rules in order to have financial security and stability. Well, you know what – financial security and stability for who? Sadly, too many people are being left behind and Member States need the flexibility to take better care of those who most need our help and as my colleague said, in Ireland this weekend, the neoliberal parties that were in government got a real good kicking because they didn’t serve the interests of those who most need it. My last point, on infrastructure and investment: we have been forced into public-private partnerships (PPPs) to do infrastructure, where we pay 15% for money. We can borrow money for less than 1% on the books if you don’t hamper us with a 3% rule.

name: Paolo Gentiloni
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank you all the members of the Parliament very much for their interventions. I think this is just the beginning of a debate that will have in the next five or six months. If I want to find common views in this discussion, I understand that at least on three general things there is agreement. First, that this rule should be reviewed. Second, that we should change the fact that they are too procyclical. And third, that we should try to make them less complex. This is a limited base, but it is a base of bridging differences. We have to avoid the idea of the fact that we have two different ideological positions – pro—stability against pro—growth – paralysing all the chance that we have to review our rules in the right direction. I think that the Parliament can give a strong contribution to bridge these ideological differences. There are strong differences that I perfectly understand, but if we are working on reducing complexity, fighting against procyclicality and changing these rules, I think we will work in the right direction. My last point is this: is all this exercise connected to the main defining objective that the new Commission with the Parliament decided, which is the green transition? My answer is definitely ‘yes’, because it’s very difficult to understand how we will be able to lead this transition without having a strong commitment from the point of view of public investment. This is the reason why I think there is a connection between our targets on the green transition and the review of our economic governance. So thank you again, and I think this is a first step in a discussion that we will continue with the Parliament, with the committees in the next weeks and months.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – The European Commission initiative to review the EU’s economic governance makes sense but by not going far enough, risks being futile. Especially with regards to the eurozone. A major goal in eurozone guidance is that of achieving upward socioeconomic convergence between different communities and regions. The complexity of rules defining such guidance has hindered efforts to achieve the goal. Which is why they should be simplified. Commission proposals on this issue are worthwhile and should be followed up on. But I’m afraid they will not get us far. Stalemate on economic governance results from the incapacity of the eurozone to balance measures which dictate austerity to regions that systemically record structural financial deficits – with measures which have remained soft on regions that show an equally systemic propensity to accumulate surpluses. A monetary zone that functions properly needs to achieve such balance. Clearly current rules in the eurozone are not achieving it. It is a basic reason why economic and social development in the eurozone lags. We are experiencing all the constraints of a common monetary area but hardly most of the flexibilities it could provide. Meanwhile, the pain is being borne by those who are least able to afford it.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on assessment of the revised enlargement methodology proposal of the European Commission (2020/2554(RSP)).

name: Olivér Várhelyi
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I thank the European Parliament for adding this very important issue to the agenda of the plenary immediately after the adoption of the Commission proposal on the revised enlargement methodology. This is a good opportunity here to present our idea, how to enhance the accession process and how to give a credible EU perspective for the Western Balkans. Let me emphasise that for our geopolitical Commission, the full engagement with our neighbours is a top priority. Europe needs to have a strong united voice in the world and it needs to play its geopolitical role to the fore, especially when it comes to its neighbourhood. This is especially valid where we must engage strongly in pursuit of peace, stability and prosperity. This is in our own interest. It is also a question of credibility. The priority of this Commission is to accelerate progress in the Western Balkans, keeping a credible perspective for future accession. Therefore, we are working on three tracks. The first of these is the communication on the revised enlargement methodology, which I will outline for you in more detail shortly. The second track is opening discussion negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania, before the Western Balkans summit in Zagreb. Ahead of the Zagreb Summit, we will complete the picture with the third track by presenting a major economic and investment development plan for the region. The objective will be to speed up the building of a solid and resilient economy and bring these countries faster and closer to our own standards. When it comes to the first track, the revised enlargement methodology is based on four main principles, four principles that should work both for the accession countries and also for our own Member States. First, the process has to be more credible. Countries need to deliver on the reforms they promised, and the EU needs to deliver when they do so. To help credibility, you will see an ever-stronger focus on the fundamental freedoms and reforms, as this is the core for real transformation. This means the rule of law, but also functioning of democratic institutions, public administration reform and economic criteria. The second principle is about putting the political nature of the process front and centre. We intend to ensure top-level engagement with the candidate countries through regular EU-Western Balkans summits and ministerial meetings. We want to involve Member States more strongly and give them better opportunities to monitor and review the process, to support and keep track of the fundamental reforms needed. The third principle addresses the need to make the whole process more dynamic, with a stronger focus on core sectors. Clustering chapters by policy fields will allow for more thorough political discussions on thematic areas. It will also allow us to identify opportunities for early alignment and involvement in EU policies, such as our digital agenda or our trans-European networks in transport and energy. I also want to highlight that when important reforms have been implemented already before the opening, then the timeframe between opening the cluster and closing individual chapters should be limited, preferably within a year, fully dependent on the progress of the reforms. This is an important political offer from our side to the whole region. If they deliver, we will also be ready to deliver. The cluster on fundamentals, rule of law, economic criteria and public administration reform will of course take a central role. It will be the first chapter to be opened and it will be the last to be closed. And sufficient progress will be needed in these areas before other clusters can be closed. The fourth principle is about making the process more predictable for both sides. This will mean ensuring that candidate countries have greater clarity on the conditions they need to meet and what is the positive impact when there is progress, and what are the negative consequences in case of non-delivery. We need clear and tangible incentives to encourage reforms. If countries move on agreed reform priorities sufficiently, citizens should see the benefits of accelerated integration and phasing into EU policies, markets and programmes, combined with increased funding and investments. At the same time, Member States need to be confident that there is reversibility and corrective measures will be taken where reforms go off track. This will be done through more decisive measures, sanctioning and serious or prolonged stagnation or backsliding. Finally, I have to reiterate that while we are strengthening and improving the process, the goal remains the same: accession and full EU membership. In parallel to this, as the second strand, the Commission stands by the recommendations to open accession negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania, and we hope that these can be opened before the Western Balkans summit in Zagreb. Both countries have delivered on what they were asked. During my recent visit to Skopje and Tirana I underlined the importance of reforms and called for their implementation to continue. Both countries have engaged in further reform efforts. At the same time, to be a credible partner, the EU needs to deliver on its promises as well. The Commission will give detailed information on the progress made by these two countries still in February, in order to prepare the ground for the Council for the decision. We are convinced that any further postponement would entail a strong risk, undermining the stability of the entire region. We would also risk further manipulation by third country actors and others offering false alternative narratives. Finally, on the third track, these substantially transformative reforms that the Western Balkan countries need to carry out can be best supported by solid and accelerated economic growth and developing functioning market economies. Therefore, as input to the Zagreb Summit, the Commission would propose a new economic-based policy approach as the cornerstone of a forward-looking agenda for the region. Our objective is to intensify our presence in the Western Balkans, to increase investment and to help to close the economic development gap between us. We have to look at what concrete measures we can take to bring forward investments in the Western Balkans, to enhance access to the EU single market, create jobs and entrepreneur opportunities, improve the business and the investment climate and stop the brain drain from the region. As you can see, this is an ambitious agenda for the region. We will need the very strong political support of this House to deliver it. We collectively have to regain trust and credibility. This means we have to treat our Western Balkans partners more and more as future Member States, which is our commonly agreed destiny. This is for the benefit of the European Union as a whole.

name: Kinga Gál
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support. I welcome the Commission's procedural proposal, which is capable of moving the issue of enlargement in the Western Balkans from its deadlock. It could form a bridge between member states that support the start of accession negotiations and those that are sceptical of enlargement. The new enlargement methodology is effective, results-oriented and sufficiently flexible to benefit Montenegro and Serbia, and has also accelerated negotiations with this key country for enlargement in the Western Balkans. Commissioner Várhelyi should be commended for come up with a well-established solution in a very short period of time, just in time to break the deadlock at the EU summit in March and to start accession negotiations with Western Macedonia and Albania before the EU-Western Balkans summit in Zagreb. Both countries have delivered, and now it is time for the Union to deliver on its promises so that it does not lose its credibility. Any action taken by the Commission to ensure successful enlargement is essential, as the future of the countries of the Western Balkans, the security of our continent and the credibility of the EU are at stake here.

name: Tonino Picula
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to congratulate Commissioner Várhelyi on the document presented and the efforts invested. The new methodologies were set only three months after the European Council meeting at which two Western Balkans countries were denied the possibility of starting negotiations. This demonstrates how European Union institutions can still respond at times of crisis. It goes without saying that the primacy of democracy and the rule of law should be placed at the very centre of the enlargement process by opening first and closing last chapters related to the judiciary, corruption and organised crime, as well as respect for human rights and media freedom.  I agree that the new approach introduces some better elements. Above all, it allows negotiating countries to use European Union programmes before accession, such as the Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T) or the European Green Deal. In essence, the new approach does not differ much in substance from the existing negotiation framework, which became more complex with every new enlargement. It’s also welcome that negotiating countries can already decide for themselves whether they want to negotiate according to the new methodology or not. For example, Montenegro has been negotiating for eight years, and only one chapter remains to be opened. Member States are invited to participate more systematically in the accession process then has previously been the case.  That’s why I hope this document will convince more sceptical Members to open negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania, hopefully at the March Council meeting. It’s clear that the decision to postpone the opening of negotiations directly called into question reform processes in these countries, which have been required for years. That was directly denying support for those who implemented them. The new methodology offers a sustainable model, in that it is now up to Member States to deliver on their promises and thus to restore credibility to the enlargement process as such.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, this time I want to start from the end of my speech, Mr Commissioner, from the failure of last October’s Council. In my opinion, we cannot afford another failure in March. I am in agreement with you when you say that we have to learn our lesson and not promise something that we cannot deliver. But today, we have to see how we can go forward together and deliver on the European aspirations of the people of the Western Balkans, and I hope this time we will not see any last—minute surprises. It is too early to come to a general conclusion on how the new methodology will work, but in order to enhance the effectiveness of the accession process, it should provide dynamism rather than complicating the enlargement process and this must mean a stronger focus on fundamental reforms, the organisation of the chapters in thematic clusters and clear conditionality. I am very much in favour of this new process, but I do not want to see this new idea turn into a new condition that will again leave the region in the backyard of the EU for a long time.  This is what we have tried to propose in our political group. We recently adopted the Renew Europe policy paper on the Western Balkans, which is based on our values and understanding of enlargement. We want the citizens and the societies of the candidate countries to be more closely associated with and benefit from the accession process. We want to integrate our partners there at an earlier stage in key policies, like the Green Deal, digital policies and connectivity, and to give them the chance to reform and benefit long before actual accession. The European perspective is a strong driving force for the reforms of the region. Realising that our group has always pursued a clear and consistent enlargement policy, we believe that reforms related to the EU should go hand in hand with the enlargement process. We need to reform the European Union not because of the Western Balkan countries, but because of the European Union itself.

name: Anna Bonfrisco
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the Commission's political offer to the Western Balkans is laudable, but it will also be appropriate to make a declaration of failure of previous actions, namely the lack of reforms of these states within the framework of the rule of law, the only safeguarding of democracy.  Indeed, unemployment, economic deficits, internal and external imbalances expose the region to adverse economic shocks. But is the rule of law just a parameter, or is it rather a guarantee of the stability of inclusion and coexistence in an enlarged system between us? Is it enough for the peculiarities of Albania? At war with itself, between non-existent corruption, secularism and democratic culture, sophisticated criminal organisations, gaps that are currently unbridgeable. Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the Commission persists in proposing a method but fails to deal with the substance of the issues. It was precisely the method that was the apparent reason why the negotiations with Albania and North Macedonia were interrupted a few months ago, but we all know that the future prospects for the accession of these states were worrying. In all this, in the Commission's proposal, the issue of security is only mentioned, given a clear mandate that the citizens of Europe have given us to protect and defend this Europe. In conclusion, Commissioner, I believe that it is insufficient to support the mere promotion of reforms, because the European Union will not be able to face the many uncertainties of the Western Balkans in the course of its work. Rather, the irreversibility of the rule of law must be guaranteed with certainty as the cornerstone of the enlargement process.

name: Viola Von Cramon-Taubadel
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, we welcome the new methodology on enlargement. The clusters give a new dynamic for the accession talks, but the fact that the cluster on fundamentals has special importance is highly appreciated by us. Without functioning democracy, without rule of law, and even without good governance, there is nothing to talk about it. Unfortunately, democratic institutions are not safe once we see progress. Rule of law and media pluralism have been declining since Serbia started negotiations in 2014, yet we pretend as if nothing has happened and continue the negotiations and other chapters, but without the fundamentals we cannot progress in other fields either. With a new approach, we can move forward when we see progress. The more ambitious countries need to be included in as many EU policies as possible. With this, we could gain back credibility and work on real changes in every citizen’s life in the region.  The southeast of Europe needs to become part of our Green Deal if we want to see Europe climate—neutral by 2050. However, we should keep our promises. Nothing is worse than the disappointment which the Council produced during the last summit in October. It urgently needs a green light for North Macedonia and Albania. Abolishing the visa regime for Kosovo is overdue, as they have fulfilled all the criteria required. A new methodology is only meaningful if we keep ourselves to it as well.

name: Jessica Stegrud
text: On the other: The ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The British flag has just been hauled and europe's greatest failure to date is soon a fact. An extremely large and important player and net contributor leaves the EU, partly because of failed previous enlargements.  However, Brexit is not europe's only problem. Sweden, like many other Member States, has problems with shadow communities, unemployment, wage dumping, crime and housing shortages. Add an impending recession and political division. A healthy organisation had stopped and learned some lessons, humbly analysed and, not least, focused on the problems I have just mentioned. Madam President, I would like to ask my Swedish colleagues a question: how do you justify this enlargement with two countries that have major problems with corruption, the economy and unemployment, when it will ultimately be Swedish citizens and taxpayers who pay the price?

name: Vladimír Bilčík (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his presentation. As the standing rapporteur for Serbia and as the delegation chair for Montenegro, I really welcome the revised methodology on enlargement. I also welcome it as the first step: as the first step in a journey, a journey towards making enlargement a successful European political priority. Our partners in the Western Balkans must regain trust in their European perspective, and engaged communication is the key to this trust. I am therefore very happy that already last week, on a joint visit, we demonstrated this trust in Belgrade, when representatives of this Parliament and you yourself, Commissioner, visited our Serbian partners. Now it is time to bring the Council and the Member States on board. We must be united when it comes to enlargement, and the first key step is to open accession negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania by March this year. Only then can we really engage on the fundamentals. Being united in enlargement means that we can succeed.

name: Isabel Santos (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the enlargement policy of the European Union is one of its most important tools and a cornerstone in promoting democracy, the rule of law, peace and prosperity.
