This proposal to revise the enlargement methodology represents a new moment, after the october desaire, reinforcing the political dynamics of the process of participation and introducing greater predictability in it by betting on the definition of clear objectives, which ensure the taking of decisions based on merit, a fundamental step towards greater confidence. The strengthening of the preponderance of the reform of the institutions, respect for the rule of law and fundamental freedoms within the set of dossiers of the association is in line with the concerns always expressed by the Group of Socialists and Democrats and we therefore welcome the importance given to this theme within the whole of this proposal. But I cannot fail to point out how shy the Commissioner referred to this topic at this meeting, contrary to what happened at other meetings. I would also stress the importance of involving Member States more directly and I hope that a mechanism for increasing incentives for the adoption of EU policies will be built more directly in order to ensure economic and political convergence essential to the success of integration. As rapporteur for Albania, I cannot fail to stress, in a strong way, that we will not accept that this reform can be used to hinder, delay, or impede the ongoing membership processes, especially with Albania and Macedonia, with which Parliament, the Commission and the Council have a commitment ... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker.)

name: Nathalie Loiseau (Renew).
text: Madam President, it was time: the debate on enlargement is finally coming out of the bureaucratic routine in which it had locked itself in.  Expanding our Union is a political choice. It must be assumed as such, both by the candidate countries and by the European Union. I welcome the Commission's proposal which introduces clarity, progressivity, but also more responsibility for everyone in the enlargement process. If progress is made, we must take that into account. If there are setbacks, the consequences must also be drawn. I particularly welcome the emphasis on the rule of law along the road to membership of our Union. The rule of law is not a box that is ticked on a piece of paper that is signed, it is the heart of what brings us together. We already have too many opponents of freedom in our Union and we do not want to bring in more. We will not be content with declarations of intent, reforms announced or adopted on paper. What matters is the concrete, daily reality of defending our core values.  Finally, I would like to warn us that if it aspires to expand, the European Union must be able to reform itself. We cannot welcome new members into a messy house; it has been said for a long time, it is time to take action. The conference on the future of Europe gives us the opportunity, let us seize it.

name: Jérôme Rivière (ID).
text: Madam President, the Commission is proposing a new method to address the problems of new accessions, particularly those in the Western Balkans. A new method of enlargement that consists of replacing 35 chapters with six negotiating themes. The Commission considers these accessions to be key priorities of its mandate. It is not the choice of the peoples. At the Zagreb summit, the Commission, deaf to previous refusals, will again propose to start accession negotiations with Albania and Northern Macedonia. It also intends to promote a comprehensive investment plan for the Western Balkans. Thus, the Commission advocates the grouping of the 35 chapters into six clusters - what an atrocious anglicism - thematic. It will come as a surprise not to see clusters addressing issues such as security, terrorism, illegal immigration, seconded workers — all of these key issues being referred to the background. On the method, this consolidation of the chapters will only strengthen the power of the Commission. Indeed, the Council has so far voted unanimously on the opening, closing or freezing of the 35 chapters. With the consolidation into six clusters, the Council will be less seized and marginalized in the enlargement process. Finally, the Commission wants to take the hand thanks to the investment plan planned for the whole of the Western Balkans. The peoples expressed by their vote in May their wish to stop these successive waves of integration. The United Kingdom has chosen to leave us. You have broken the European project. We cannot accept the constant strengthening of this uncontrolled, technocratic European power. We must stop enlargement, stop dissolving countries into a great technocratic whole, the Trojan horse of globalization. The coronavirus exposing our countries that, on your advice, have relocated everything, including their health security, sounds the death knell for this crazy policy.

name: Tineke Strik (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, we are happy that the Commission has released this proposal as we expect now from the Member States that the adoption of this proposal will lead to the start of the negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania. Can the Commission and Presidency assure us that once this methodology is adopted, the Council will show its green light in May? I hope that all the pressure will be exerted on the Member States.  We welcome the emphasis on rule of law, as well as the flexibility which enables the EU to more effectively support the candidate countries during the process. However, we have some concerns about the procedure to reverse the process without unanimity being required. This makes it easier to reverse the process than to start the process. How can the Commissioner prevent this from leading, for instance, to political arbitrariness in the decision-making and to more insecurity for the candidate countries? It can also be questioned from an institutional perspective that a different legal procedure is applied in the reversal moment from the one applied in the moment of starting the accession. So can you please elaborate on this dilemma?

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Chairman, the proposal for a new enlargement methodology largely meets French requirements and facilitates future Macedonian and Albanian membership negotiations. This compromise is important because potential candidate countries should not pay the price for our internal disagreements. What I find particularly valuable in this proposal is greater flexibility, especially when it comes to sanctions or even suspending negotiations for those who stagnate or regress in meeting the criteria. As a rule, accession to the European Union is a lengthy and transforming process. There are major challenges ahead for countries going through this process for which we need to be understanding, but on the other hand we must remain consistent in insisting that the criteria are met and that equal rules apply to all. Only in this way can the EU maintain credibility and remain a desirable destination for all the unintended countries of Europe.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate the Commissioner. Commissioner, last week you presented the new methodology for enlargement, hoping to send a positive message to the candidate countries and hoping to appease the concerns of the Member States. The reactions coming from both Member States and from the Western Balkan countries are very positive, and your work will be crucial to prevent a repetition of the blocking of accession talks.  I strongly welcome the two key concepts in the methodology: credibility and political steering. The Western Balkans need a credible accession perspective with appropriate European engagement based on the lessons learned. On the other side, it is up to the political leadership of the candidate countries to demonstrate their commitment to join the EU by enforcing fundamental political and economic reforms, assisted by the European Union and inspired by our recommendations.  As the co-rapporteur for the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA III) and a directly elected representative of EU citizens, I expect in the future more involvement of the European Parliament in the accession process, and the acknowledgment and implementation of Parliament’s resolutions. These resolutions, adopted by the majority of this House, focus on the progress of the way forward for these countries. We are facilitators for the enlargement, and we are the strongest advocate of the Western Balkans within the EU institutions. Therefore, we expect our resolutions to be heard, discussed and implemented.

name: Andreas Schieder (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Balkans are part of Europe – with all its contradictions, but above all with the many similarities that exist in the Balkans. One of these commonalities is this great hope, which the young people in the region in particular place for Europe. In other words, we must encourage and support reforms, and that is what the new rules that have been presented today must do.  At the heart of this is the rule of law, that is, the rule of law, media freedom, minority rights, clean administration, a strong parliamentary democracy. Rule of law, however, will only be strong if we succeed in removing all doubts within the European Union as to whether the rule of law is being respected – that is, if we have implemented the rule of law, the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary to such an extent that we can lead everyone by example.  I welcome the new rules that have been presented: they are structured, clear and comprehensible. This must therefore also lead to the March Council giving the green light – a green light that negotiations with Northern Macedonia, which has, above all, undertaken such important and deep reforms, and with Albania, can be started and started. That would be the strongest sign that the Balkans desperately need.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (Renew).
text: – Madam President, the EU enlargement policy is one of the most empowering and successful policy instruments that we possess. If the proposed methodology will succeed to streamline the accession process, then it was worth approving. However, success is embedded not in a smart methodology, but in a strong political will. From the EU side, it is a clear will to enlarge our European family, from the aspirants – a commitment to fully fulfil the membership criteria. We must preserve the integrity and inclusiveness of the enlargement process. The same rules must apply to all candidates. Moreover, the candidate countries should reach the membership league with their hard work and no major concessions. Maintaining this understanding as well as mutual trust is a key for bringing neighbouring countries into our European family. This strategic approach has to be immune to political manipulations.

name: Nicolaus Fest (ID).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Why did the British leave the EU? Because they wanted sovereignty over their country, but also because the EU has been breaking its central promise for years, namely the promise to increase the prosperity of European citizens. That is not the case. Indeed, youth unemployment is dramatic in many countries, in fact we are technologically lagnitatined in many areas, productivity is actually falling, and the rescue of the euro and the associated zero-interest-rate policy have made many Europeans poor. But you take no notice of this, as if Brexit did not exist, as if the yellow vests did not exist in France. Now you also want to take in a number of Balkan countries – of all places! All these countries are quite far down the transparency index, so they are highly corrupt in a word, and all will be in the pockets of European citizens as transfer recipients. The enlargement of the EU to include other countries at this stage is another sargnagel for its existence. If you first solve the EU's economic problems, you should look further.

name: Lukas Mandl (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we have lost Great Britain and Northern Ireland, and that weakens Europe. We should do all that we can not to lose the Western Balkans as well. The Western Balkans are not yet Member States but anyway they are European states with a European identity. The new methodology for enlargement and accession was an extra homework, I would say, an extra homework for a small minority of Member States in the Council who had surprised all of us with the blockade of enlargement. Of course the six countries have to do a lot. They have to help each other more, they have to fight corruption. But the negotiations with Albania and Northern Macedonia have to start as soon as possible, even before the election in Northern Macedonia. Elections in Montenegro and Serbia are running but Serbia has to recognise Kosovo as well as Kosovo has to withdraw the tariffs against goods and services from Serbia. We have to strengthen the European Union against other powers in the world by enforced work on this enlargement. I thank you, Commissioner, and Commission President von der Leyen for also quickly setting up this new methodology. Ceterum censeo the United Kingdom should become a Member State again.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: Madam President! I would like to start by praising the Commission for the actions that have been made here with adjustments in our enlargement strategy. I think it is very good that you have listened to the concerns that were in relation to the current admissions strategy.  It is absolutely crucial that more emphasis is placed on the fact that the candidate countries actually comply with, or are working to strengthen their rule of law. It has proved to be absolutely crucial that it works, otherwise you should not be able to start filming, nor should you be able to be recorded.  I also think it is important to say that it is a good thing that, in principle, we should be better able to pause negotiations or actually stop them if it turns out that the candidate countries are not complying with the rules, and I think that is absolutely crucial. Because these changes make it easier to also say 'yes' to opening negotiations with Northern Macedonia and with Albania.

name: Klemen Grošelj (Renew).
text: – Honourable Chair, the proposal for a methodology embodies all the weaknesses and advantages of the European compromise. It is thus a compromise that allows the European Union to continue to develop and strengthen while not hindering the enlargement process.  It is a compromise that, on the one hand, strengthens the possibilities and sets the conditions for EU reform if it is defined by the Member States and if citizens support it in the context of the Conference on the Future of Europe.  But it is also a compromise that alleviates the fears of some Member States against enlargement.  At the same time, it sets the EU's enlargement framework for the Western Balkans, which provides more credibility and predictability for all involved in the process, both for EU citizens and for candidate countries and their citizens.  The whole enlargement process puts this compromise into a qualitative new framework that will enable the progress of each candidate to be monitored effectively and in real time, rewarding progress and strengthening the negotiation process, while giving the candidates a predictable and clear framework for convergence and integration into the European Union.  However, given the sharpness of the requirements and conditions in the methodology, there is a serious possibility that candidate countries will fulfil the fundamental conditions and values set out in the methodology better than many Member States.

name: Andrius Kubilius (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it is very clear that in this House the majority agrees that enlargement until now has been one of the most successful EU policies, which contributed to extending the area of democracy, peace and prosperity across Europe. The prospect of EU membership always was, is and will be in the future a fundamental incentive for reforms in applicant countries. That is why, what the Commissioner proposed in the Commission’s communication, I consider as a very important strategic and a good step forward, making the whole process, first of all, more credible. Of course, credibility depends, first of all, on the efforts of applicant countries to reform themselves, but it also depends on the responsibility of the EU Member States. The whole process cannot depend on one or another EU Member State, which can block the whole enlargement process without any serious arguments. The qualified majority vote should become the rule in the whole enlargement process in order to make it more credible. Mr Commissioner, I’m absolutely sure, your efforts to make credible enlargement happen will have credible and strong support in this House.

name: Andor Deli (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first and foremost, I must commend the fast and efficient work of the new Commission, and especially you, Commissioner Várhelyi. In my view, 2020 will be a decisive year for enlargement policy. If things go well this year, we could have at least one candidate country that is ready for full accession by 2025.  Looking at the first reactions in the Western Balkans and also in the Member States, there is a positive anticipatory attitude on both sides and I think that’s a good sign. The new proposal can make the accession negotiations more political but also more efficient, especially with the help of the thematic clusters, which will definitely make the opening of chapters faster, and if a cluster is closed, by allowing access to certain EU funds, there would be a tangible difference for the citizens and also for the companies in the region. I would also commend the flexibility of the system, as it can be used for countries such as Serbia, which is already well advanced in the negotiations. The cluster mechanism could significantly speed up the process. I wish you all the best and you can count on our support.

name: Tomislav Sokol (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, yes, I truly welcome this proposal.  We all know that Southeast Europe is essential for the European Union. Just look at the map and see that it is the only space actually in this part of Europe that has not yet become, means included in the European Union and is surrounded by countries of the European Union from all sides. It is also a fact that the geopolitical interests of different countries have often been reassessed in this area: Turkey, Russia, the Islamic world, etc., and of course in this sense the European perspective for these countries strengthens the European Union itself and also strengthens those countries themselves. Of course, this does not mean that they should enter unconditionally. It takes an individual approach to each country and it is necessary to honor the very countries and those governments that are truly pro-European, that is, which are pro-European and not only on paper with their works.  In this regard, I welcome once again this amended negotiating framework, I welcome credibility as a new emphasis. (The President took the speaker's word away)

name: Milan Brglez (S&D).
text: – Madam President! Following the Council's October error, which led to the blockade of the enlargement process, the revised enlargement methodology is a logical move by the Commission. Unfortunately, however, it remains, or maintains, a top-down approach, and thus preserves existing political elites, even if they are part of the problem and not part of the solution, and gives too little role to both citizens and civil society.  It means that the greater role of the Member States within the enlargement process, including the greater responsibility they will be able to show at the impending summit, and I hope that they will not again abuse their national interests, as they have done so far. I certainly think that the European Union must not lose credibility and play with the European perspective of the Member States, and it must also take the rule of law seriously if it wants to demand it. Finally, we need a credible and transparent process for both sides.

name: Valter Flego (Renew).
text: – Dear Chairman, Respected Commissioner, enlargement policy is one of the fundamental policies of the European Union and every body, every organisation that is not expanding, that is not advancing, but is being cocooned, which is closing, is failing. For this reason, I give one great support to North Macedonia and Albania in their European path and I want us to give them the green light even before the Zagreb Summit. And to begin their European journey. I argue that we need them, but also other countries that want to join the European Union, accept them, help them reform themselves and give them strong support in this. Dear Commissioner, peace and security not only of the Western Balkans but also of europe as a whole have no alternative.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I too am of the belief that the European Union should be more accommodating and a little bit less judgmental of the countries that want to join. There is no doubt that how things are organised in some of these countries can leave a bit to be desired, but things leave a lot to be desired in how we organise things in our own countries as well. For example, corruption is very blatant and on the surface in many of these countries, and we are critical of it – and rightly so – but we’re sometimes less critical of corruption in high places and big business in our own Member States. To give you an example, in Ireland, where we still have a ‘bad bank’ called NAMA, the manner in which they operate has probably cost the state about EUR 20 billion, but that’s fine and it’s almost legitimate. We need to be a bit more consistent in how we approach these new countries who want to join.

name: Traian Băsescu (PPE).
text: – Madam President, congratulations, Commissioner, on the new preparation scheme for the admission of the Member States to the European Union. I think it will be much more effective and predictable.  I would, however, make an observation. The fundamental issue of these states is to be the rule of law before becoming a member of the European Union. At the same time, they are required to move to a market economy and to achieve the functional competitive market. This is why corruption is growing and the experience of our countries tells us this. We cannot make major privatisations until we have a solid rule of law, a justice capable of overseeing privatisation processes.

name: Robert Hajšel (S&D).
text: – Madam President, yes, Macedonia has also changed the name of its country to accommodate the European Union, but it has not yet received an invitation to negotiate because the French President, with the support of Denmark and the Netherlands, has blocked the process of opening these negotiations. I think that this was a very bad signal, and I therefore welcome the European Commission's initiative, which will certainly restore, at least in part, our credibility as a global player, at least to satisfy the countries that are applying for membership and to enable them to do so when, of course, they meet all the prescribed criteria.  Likewise, this new methodology will allow this process to be more dynamic, to be more transparent, more transparent, that is, that states always know what they are up to, what they should do, and that they will no longer be able to see such uneasy surprises as they did in the autumn, when these negotiations were due to start and not started. I think there is also a guarantee for the Member States that ... (the President took the floor from the speaker)

name: Katalin Cseh (Renew).
text: – Madam President, I say to the Commissioner: welcome to Parliament and I would like to congratulate you on the new enlargement methodology just proposed. I was especially glad to see that you proposed on multiple occasions an objective criteria to evaluate the state of the rule of law in these accession countries. I am wondering, do you think this criteria could be used to evaluate existing Member States as well? I know a lot of your colleagues in the Commission are already working on this project, maybe you could be helpful on that? Unfortunately, Ms Judit Varga, the Justice Minister of Hungary, dedicated an entire opinion piece on Euronews to claim that there are no such objective criteria to evaluate the rule of law, but maybe if you have a talk with her, maybe you could convince her otherwise. I have two questions for you: in your opinion, what would happen if existing Member States scored lower on the rule of law evaluation compared to candidate countries? Also, do you have a proposition on how to safeguard the rule of law once Member States have accessed the European Union in order to prevent democratic backsliding?

name: Clare Daly (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I think it is a little bit ironic that we’re having this conversation just a week after losing a major Member State ... that we’re looking at a new enlargement methodology. I think a period of reflection may have been a little bit more worthy. Because, let’s face it, while we know that rule of law and fundamental rights are in the accession criteria, everybody knows that these rules are bent regularly by some countries, depending on who you are.  But what can’t be bent, and what is not negotiable, is the neoliberal ideology at the heart of the Union, this is sacrosanct. The market economy and competition. And I don’t think that’s for the benefit of people in Albania or Macedonia, no more than I think that it is of the benefit to people in Ireland. In actual fact it was the failure of these neoliberal policies that actually led to many of the people who voted for Brexit. It’s the reason why so many people in Ireland turned out this weekend to vote for left-wing parties in an historic rejection of neoliberalism. If we want to build the union... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Domènec Ruiz Devesa (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for your presentation. I have no objections to the new methodology, in fact, that's fine with me. I also agree with the majority of the House that we would have to give the green light to the accession process, to the opening up of the accession process of Albania and Northern Macedonia, for the reasons that have been said. But I also think it is important to take into account - and it has not been said so far, either in the Commissioner's presentation or in the debate – the constitutional dimension of enlargement. We cannot continue to expand the Union if we do not deepen our political union at the same time. That means, in particular, that we cannot continue to decide important matters, such as foreign policy, by the rule of unanimity in the Council. We shouldn't do it with 27 and we shouldn't do it with 29 or 30 or 35 states either.

name: Irena Joveva (Renew).
text: – Honourable President! We all point out practically one and the same – the urgency of reform. union as such, as well as a lot of the process. That without reforming the Union, enlargement will not even make sense, of course true. But it is also a fact that the enlargement process has been misused for one interest or another. This must no longer happen, and I may be naïve, but I hope that this recast methodology will be different now. Because, in my opinion, all the requirements, including France, have now been met for the start of the pirstop renegotiation with North Macedonia and Albania. I will not praise the revised methodology, but only for that reason, Honourable Commissioner, because I would first like to see how it works in practice. However, I will not be able to see this until the two countries have been allowed to start negotiations. So – we cannot and should no longer just demand and give anything, that October mistake was more than enough.

name: Olivér Várhelyi
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all, I thank this House for the debate. I also thank this House for the renewed commitment to the Western Balkans. This is a very important sign that we need to send to the region. It is also clear from the debate that you all want a credible perspective for the Western Balkans to become EU Member States. This is also a very important political message that we are able to deliver today already.  I received several questions on the new methodology itself, but also on how it is linked to the possible opening of accession negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania. First of all, of course, new methodologies are proposed to make way to opening accession negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania. Therefore, this is – as I have said – part of a bigger strategy in which the second element is actually to deliver opening the accession negotiations. When we were designing the whole structure of the new methodology, we were very clear that there are no new conditions. This is a question that I received from many of you. We’re still working with the Copenhagen criteria and those are unchanged. They are unchanged, but they are going to be enforced better, more inclusively and more effectively through the better participation not only of our Member States, but also of our public. This continues to be a merit-based process. This is what I have been describing to you, meaning that if there is delivery, there is going to have to be a delivery on our side. However, it also means that if there is backsliding, we would have to take steps in terms of going back to the whole process. The idea of the whole methodology is to tackle the substance much better, much more effectively, and in a more transparent manner.  I also received a question on how it is possible to start accession negotiations – the Member is no longer here – with countries that have high unemployment. Well, this is exactly why we have the third element of the strategy, which is the Zagreb package – the economic development package. We would want to create growth and jobs locally so that people can get jobs and create strong resilient economies for the whole region.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Andrea Caroppo (ID)
text: in writing. To be welcomed, Commissioner Várhelyi's proposal for a review of the enlargement methodology in order to increase credibility and give new impetus to the EU-Western Balkans agenda is still lacking. Making the enlargement process more credible, more political and clearer is laudable, but these must not remain petitions of principle. If possible, before the opening of negotiations with Albania and North Macedonia and before the Zagreb Summit, the Commission should say, how concretely to involve the Member States more, through what instruments and methods of operation; likewise, it should clarify how to make effective the need for citizens to appreciate the benefits of EU membership; this is the decisive point of any stable and lasting accession. The Commission should focus more on the substance than on the method. Given that the process of developing the laws of the countries of the Western Balkans, towards the real protection of fundamental freedoms, is still lag behind, the issues of discussion announced by the Commission are absent from security, legality, the fight against organised crime and all kinds of trafficking, issues that our citizens are calling for as a top priority. Similarly, the Commission cannot but discuss with the candidates the same commitments on the environment and the fight against climate change made by the Member States.

name: Ramona Strugariu (Renew)
text: in writing. – I welcome the Commission's new methodology on enlargement and hope that its adoption will facilitate the opening of accession negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania. The revised methodology can achieve the transformative potential of enlargement policy. However, we must have the courage to directly confront the phenomenon of the capture of the state by the ruling elites in the countries of the Western Balkans. Our enlargement policy must address the citizens of these countries much more concretely and applied to the citizens of these countries. We must also support critical voices, whistleblowers and civil society \u2012 they are our natural allies for the implementation of the reforms required for accession. The European Union must give voice to the citizens of the region against regimes that for decades have only been mimicing reforms. Pro-European political forces need to be strengthened and we need to be much more rigorous in making funding conditional on the concrete steps taken to carry out reforms. I am pleased that the new methodology gives a central place to the rule of law and fundamental rights. It is essential that all States aspiring to membership behave in the letter and spirit of European law. Situations such as the forced expulsion of teachers or activists, political asylum seekers, to countries such as Turkey should not exist.

text: – The following is the question for an oral answer to the Commission on Automated Decision-Making Processes: Ensuring consumer protection and the free movement of goods and services, presented by Petra de Sutter, on behalf of the Committee on internal market and consumer protection O-000008/2020 - B9-0007/2020) (2019/2915(RSP)). name: Petra De Sutter
text: author. – Mr President, the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) formulated a couple of questions regarding automated decision—making processes in anticipation of the European Commission’s initiatives on artificial intelligence (AI), which will be presented in Parliament next week. For our committee, it is of utmost importance that in any future initiative on the matter, we do guarantee not only the free movement of AI-enabled goods and services, but also the trust of the consumer in these new goods and services because the applications are numerous and encompass virtually all sectors of the internal market. We are witnessing rapid development of AI technology. Consumers are being confronted on a daily basis with systems that use automated decision making, such as virtual assistance and chat—bots on websites, and as is the case with all technological advancements, this provides us with opportunities as well as challenges.  AI and automated decision making offers great potential in terms of innovative and higher quality products and services, but at the same time, various challenges need to be addressed in order to realise this potential. First and foremost, services and goods using AI and automated decision making create the risk of consumers being misled or discriminated against, for example, in relation to differentiated pricing. Will consumers be aware of the fact that the price displayed on their screen was adapted to their estimated purchasing power? The same goes for professional services. If important decisions are automated and thus carried out without sufficient human oversight by highly skilled professionals, are consumers aware that decisions affecting their professional, financial or personal lives are in fact not made by humans, and if they feel wronged, will they be able to demand a human review? Will a human, ultimately, be responsible for final decisions or will they be able to reverse them? So my first question to you is: how is the Commission planning to ensure that consumers are protected from unfair or discriminatory commercial practices or from potential risks entailed by AI—driven professional services?  Secondly, we risk that the existing EU product safety and liability frameworks do not adequately cover new AI—enabled products and services. Do concepts such as defective products and the legal provisions built around these adequately cover situations in which harm is caused by products operating under automated decision making? As is the case with other products and services, we should ensure that businesses and consumers are protected from harm and receive compensation if it occurs. This is important in order to ensure secured free movement throughout the single market. Therefore, our second question is: what initiatives may we expect from the Commission side to ensure that the EU safety and liability frameworks are fit for purpose? In that respect, we should ensure that market—surveillance authorities and other competent authorities possess adequate means and powers to act. This is especially important when competent authorities, businesses and consumers do not have access to clear information on how the decision was taken. How will the Commission ensure greater transparency in this respect?  Lastly, talking about biased or unlawfully obtained data sets, the IMCO Committee stresses the importance of respecting regulations such as GDPR when it comes to the collection of data, but also looking at non-personal data use, barriers and requirements. This is something we can and should address at this stage of the design. We should build in these safeguards – privacy by design. So I want to ask: how is the Commission planning to ensure that only high quality and unbiased data set are used in automated decision—making processes?  Dear Commissioner, as I said at the beginning, AI offers great potential in many aspects of our daily lives and many fields of the internal market, yet it confronts us with many new and unknown risks. We should address these risks in an adequate and timely manner because the trust of the consumer will be crucial for the acceptance of these new technologies in our society and economy. I thank you in advance for your answers on these very topical and societally important questions and I, and with me the whole IMCO Committee, look forward to the presentation of your plans next week.

name: Thierry Breton
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President De Sutter, thank you for your question, which is more than a question, since in fact it covers the whole panorama of what we have been working on for several weeks and even months in the Commission for several weeks and even months, concerning the issues you have raised, and in particular, of course, behind, underlying it, everything about artificial intelligence , data management in a digital economy that will radically change our internal market. The question you are asking, in fact, is how this evolution - this revolution, some will say - will actually change consumer behaviour, but also allow us, and that is what we are working on, to consolidate our entire internal market. For this, of course, the first word, the key word which was, moreover, quite present in your speech, Madam President, is obviously to create a climate of trust. It is true that today there is distrust of artificial intelligence. Our citizens are asking questions, often legitimate, and we are here to try to provide answers — effective answers. It is in this spirit that, as you have pointed out, the Commission will present on 19 February a white paper which will be a kind of targeted consultation, on which we will obviously express our positions, but which is also the way to continue the debate we have this evening and to extend it to listen to all of you, but also to be able to bring solutions together to this absolutely essential development which is now marking our time. First of all, it is obviously a question of properly framing the rules for the development of artificial intelligence in Europe.  On the other hand, it is also a question of ensuring that these rules allow us to foster the emergence of a European artificial intelligence industry.  We have worked a lot, with my colleagues, with all my colleagues, over the last few weeks, and together we really need to ask ourselves the question - as you mentioned earlier - of course, algorithms, when it comes to artificial intelligence, but also the question of data. It is obviously the data that is, I was going to say, the fuel that will allow us precisely, by training them through specific algorithms, to develop specific applications that will obviously intervene in the lives of our fellow citizens. So the interest we're going to have in data, on value-added data, is going to be very important in the communication we're going to do. I would still like to point out, in particular in response to a number of your questions, Madam President, that, of course, we are not starting from scratch. A lot of work has been done, including legislative work, including in this Parliament, of course. First, consumer protection legislation. It also covers business practices, as you referred to, using automated decision-making processes, which can also be invoked in the case of discrimination. Similarly, the regulatory framework now requires professionals to inform consumers, when the price is personalized - as you mentioned earlier - on the basis of an automated decision-making system.  I would also like to mention, of course, the RGPD, which has been rightly talked about and which requires that an impact assessment be carried out when the processing of personal data is likely to pose a high risk to the rights and freedoms of individuals. There are still other requirements that apply to automated decisions made in the context of, for example, e-recruitment. It is obvious that we will have to ensure that there is no discrimination, and therefore understand how these algorithms work, simply so that they respect the whole corpus of European values to which we are so attached. And of course, everything about human interventions that must, once again, allow us to eventually challenge the decision, allow our citizens to challenge the decision if they consider that they are entitled to do so. Finally, I recall the so-called Platform to Business regulation, which was adopted last year and imposes transparency obligations on the ranking carried out by the algorithms of online platforms and search engines. There are a lot of things, but of course we will have to move forward and I would like to say that we will obviously use all of this. We will also reflect together on the adaptation of the General Product Safety Directive, the Directive on machines, as well as the Radio Equipment Directive. The automotive sector is also going to be a very important topic in terms of artificial intelligence and automatic decision-making. Legislators, as you know, have already instructed the Commission to look into the issue of the approval of connected autonomous cars, so we will continue to do so. It may also be necessary to make some clarifications to the Directive on General Product Responsibility in light of the development of emerging technologies and the circular economy. Finally, as you know, the preparation of the Digital Services Act, which we are working on, will allow us to examine with greater attention a series of algorithmic processes, for example recommendation systems, moderation algorithms, or, of course, a very important subject which has been extensively debated in this Parliament, online advertising. There is also a point, if I may, about professional services. The proposed expertise must not only be based on traditional qualifications, but also on a new kind of combination of skills combining information technology, knowledge and, of course, expertise in each sector. I would also like to point out that the white paper on which we are going to be working, which will be brought to your attention, will be followed by action in the fourth quarter, as envisaged in the Commission's work programme, and that, of course, it is from this perspective that we really want to be able to work with you. I know that many of you, ladies and gentlemen, have been working on these issues for several months or even years now. It is quite enriching for us, and for me in particular, and so through the white paper, we will have a platform to continue these exchanges.

name: Pablo Arias Echeverría
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, the European Commission has placed artificial intelligence as one of its priorities for this parliamentary term. As we all know, artificial intelligence has multiple practical applications with enormous potential to improve the functioning of our societies and economies. To do this, and that is why I am the first supporter to prioritise it in the European Union, but we have to be vigilant.  We already lost the train digitally when in its anteroom we led the technological market with brands like Nokia, which saw how they lay behind for not paying attention and above all for not looking from the right perspective. Europe was left off the hook. Today we cannot afford to return to the same thing with artificial intelligence. To address this challenge, we must ensure the trust of our consumers. We Europeans are not like Americans or Asians, here we put privacy and transparency before any digital experience.  We must ask ourselves: What does the European Union want to achieve from artificial intelligence? How does the European Union intend to achieve this? And, above all, for what purposes? From here, we ask the European Commission to ask these three questions before starting any initiative and to find the right answers.  Transparency should be the cornerstone of any initiative related to this technology. Without it, consumers will not trust and will not achieve their development or therefore the competitive advantage it can give us over our competitors. Only if we pay attention, look from the right perspective and are agile, lead the development of artificial intelligence and create the ecosystem that we Europeans ask for and need.

name: Maria Manuel Leitão Marques
text: on behalf of the S&D Group- Mr President, machine learning still has difficulty in performing tasks that we consider easy. For example, a neural network whose purpose was to distinguish between dogs and wolves learned to differentiate them, not by what normally distinguishes these two animals, but only through their environment. Thus, the images that had grass were classified as dogs and those that had snow like wolves. This example may seem harmless, but it is based on the same learning mechanisms that are implemented on digital platforms and that make decisions in an automated manner. They are the ones who recommend certain products or services to us, make one more visible and hide others. These mechanisms, of course, can also be used with collective benefits, including to improve our public services, if we have some ethical, regulatory and governance precautions. In this resolution, we therefore advocate the need to ensure greater transparency to the algorithms that feed that learning, in order to provide security in the choices of consumers and, above all, trust when they interact with automated systems knowing, for example, whether they are talking to a ChatBot or a human behind that system. We also warn of the impact these systems can have on product safety, as the Commissioner has already said, and on the rules on liability in the event of a defect. And finally, we stress the need for the data, the databases used to train these algorithms, the crucial point, as you mentioned, to be of due quality and to be auditable, with clear governance rules to ensure, as far as is technically possible, the removal of any bias. Mr President, Commissioner, when we walk through the forest, we should trust the system that warns us: don't worry, it's a dog and not a wolf that's approaching.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, I very much welcome the fact that this new Parliament will adopt the first resolution on artificial intelligence (AI). I’m sure it is not the last one. Automated decision—making is already affecting our lives. It is making our lives easier with new and better services, and making mundane tasks take up less of our time. If done correctly, they also have the possibility to reduce human bias and human errors in the decision—making process.  But as with any new technology, there will inevitably be legal and ethical questions raised that we must be aware of. Most of these issues can be addressed with the current rules; others may need to be adopted, but we need a measured approach. We need to resist the temptation of over—legislating too quickly for these fast—evolving technologies. This would not only hinder innovation and developments in Europe, but also create more problems than it would solve. Equally, we must not generalise our approach. The rules governing algorithms should be proportionate to the risk taken in using that algorithm. There is a difference between the algorithm of a power grid and the algorithm in a video game. To conclude, while humans must always be in the driver seat, let’s be guided by our heads and not by illogical fears.

name: Virginie Joron
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Antoine de Saint-Exupéry said 'eyes are blind, you have to look with your heart'. Today, in our research on the internet, in our everyday life, robots, algorithms scrutinize our activity, analyze us. This is called profiling. Two hours on the internet, and we are offered a trip, a husband and a state-of-the-art car. Can they be trusted with these automatic treatments? Is the price the normal price? Is our data protected? Are our thoughts and desires to be exploited in a virtual world?  It is therefore essential that the criteria and algorithms used by the applications that help us, marry us or follow us to work are transparent and controlled. We can over-relied on an automated system or not enough. Unfortunate accidents caused by autonomous vehicles can be considered cases of too much confidence. Tomorrow we will see more and more driverless trucks on our roads and in the event of an accident, who will be held responsible? Who will compensate? The consumer must always be responsible as a last resort and be able to reverse the automatic decisions made by computers or robots.  With regard to the proposed text, this resolution lacks a crucial point: it does not say anything about the concentration of data within a few non-European companies and our necessary emancipation in this area. We do not believe that consumers have been adequately protected from damage caused by defective products by the Brussels directives. As you know - for more than 30 years, companies have inserted small written disclaimers into their contracts. For all these reasons and to date, we do not believe that it would be more effective for Brussels to decide the risk management criteria of artificial intelligence, but we believe, on the other hand, in our French engineers.
