Education and occupation, housing and work, buying goods and news are affected. But it is up to us to decide what influence they have, what data the machines judge and what they decide – and what they do not. We want artificial intelligence to really serve everyone, and we can now set the course for this – with a clear 'yes' to artificial intelligence, which serves climate protection and sustainability, but also with a clear 'no' if it discriminates against people. Because we know that every record collected in an unequal society has a discriminatory effect. For example, women are currently paid less and do more caring work. This fact feeds into the data and leads, if not corrected, to women's incomes, which will continue to be poorly or even less paid. We must resolutely oppose such cases of injustice by law. In the European Union, we have the right to safe products and services. But this right is only worth something if we can enforce it. That is why our supervisory authorities need extensive powers to check the legality of algorithmic systems. Europe now has a unique opportunity to create a legal framework based on our democratic values and could be a model for the world. Let us approach this great project with courage.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: for the GUE/NGL group. – Mr President, the rapid development of artificial intelligence technologies and automatic decision-making poses a huge challenge for our society. Both in terms of law, morality, the future direction of mankind, and the internal market. In binary code, we can find the same ailments as in society. Services and goods using artificial intelligence and automatic decision-making carry the risk of misleading, discriminating or even harming consumers, e.g. in relation to differentiated prices. Thus, artificial intelligence and automatic decision-making may not lead so much to some flawless society of rationality, but perhaps rather to anchoring the current unjust social state. A state in which greed, deception, and bending of the law win.  We should therefore work to protect consumers from unfair or discriminatory commercial practices or from the risks associated with professional services using artificial intelligence. Automatic decision-making processes should be transparent and subject to supervision by competent authorities, which should have adequate means and powers to do so. It is necessary to set standards and targets, inter alia, in the field of data quality and to eliminate distortions in all data set by introducing safeguards. The European consumer must not be at the mercy of automatic decision-making processes. It must be protected and therefore the Commission should act.

name: Miroslav Radačovský (NI).
text: – Mr President, I support Parliament's resolution on automated decision-making processes in relation to consumer protection and free movement and goods and services. Council Directive 85/374 has been providing consumer protection against damage caused by defective products for 35 years and, in view of new automated processes, it is essential to redefine terms such as damage, product, defect, product defect. It should be borne in mind that when making online purchases, the consumer does not communicate directly with the service supplier. The damage is closely linked to liability for damage and, in particular, to the question of the burden of proof, where liability should be objective on the part of the supplier and the supplier should always bear the burden of proof. Updating these concepts is necessary, skut.. the updating of these concepts really needs to be given due, professionally qualified attention and not subject to possible lobbying pressures. This is very important for consumer protection as an entity always in a weaker position. However, it is also necessary to deal with the new definition of the concepts of complaint, right of withdrawal, return of postage. It must simply always be obvious to the consumer which entity may, even in any litigation, claim his consumer rights.

name: Tomislav Sokol (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, technology has been evolving at an incredible rate in recent decades. I, though I belong to the younger generation, sometimes I can't really believe what things are possible today and which weren't before.  In particular, this applies to artificial intelligence. While, of course, it brings a number of benefits in the field of science and technology, which is primarily to reduce the possibility of human error, it also leads to various new possibilities of manipulation and misuse of collected information about consumers. Voice, fingerprint and facial recognition, automatic text translation, autonomous vehicles and home robotics are all benefits we have today from the development of technology and artificial intelligence.  However, there are many problems already mentioned here in the debate, which legislation at EUROPEAN Union level should be addressed. In doing so, we must note that it is always the right and legal system that is casking for the development of technology and this should be taken into account. Of course, there is a need for balance, on the one hand not to present additional and too great restrictions on the development of entrepreneurship, especially when we see how far Europe lags behind the United States and some other parts of the world, but at the same time ensure full consumer protection.  In this regard, I would certainly emphasise the principle of prohibiting aggressive advertising, as it must not happen that analyses of individual consumers' personal data, such as gambling addicts, offer new opportunities to access sites with similar content or offer unfavourable loans to indebted citizens. These are things that are certainly inadmissible and that we have to fight.  Of course, personalized prices that are also made according to someone's profile are also dangerous and represent a form of abuse that needs to be combated. In the end, one must always maintain control over the autonomous decisions of the system, especially in the field of law and medicine.  So we need a balanced approach, a balanced approach, not to create hysteria, but also to address all possibilities of manipulation in the right way and bring regulation in the right way that will take all competing interests into account.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: Mr President! We have probably only seen the beginning of the importance of artificial intelligence for our society. Artificial intelligence offers plenty of possibilities, but also lots of pitfalls. When we talk about consumers, there is no doubt that I believe that the consumer is entitled to know what automatic decisions are being made on behalf of the consumer, but also on what data basis. I think it is really important that we have the opportunity to gain insight into this as a consumer. That is why I also believe that in the future work here in the European Union we must have looked at whether there is no need to strengthen EU consumer protection legislation. I believe that much more transparency, better protection of the consumer, is needed, and there is also a need to ensure that this automatic decision-making process becomes more objective. It will be exciting to look at and I think we should look at the possibility. We're already doing this. In the last parliamentary term, we made some changes to legislation for platforms – price portals are a good place to start. However, I believe that we need to go further than that and we must focus on protecting the consumer more with more transparency.

name: Stéphane Séjourné (Renew).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I have a minute, so I am addressing a comment and a question. The point is that, indeed, for the first time in the history of our industrial revolutions, artificial intelligence was not thought out with its regulations and innovation came from the private sector, unlike the great industrial revolutions where the state had a great deal of control over infrastructure and where the cost of building infrastructure was high. Ai has therefore developed, which raises the question for us, the legislators, to get to the bottom of legislation that, year after year, needs to be reviewed according to the uses of this artificial intelligence. This is what, in my opinion, raises the question of trust, in particular, since usages are developing, that, paradoxically, the public power puts a lot of money into innovation and that, paradoxically, we are chasing regulation, behind uses and innovation. I would add on this point, because perhaps that is what drives this European Parliament resolution, that we need to find the right balance between the competitiveness of our companies, public confidence in new technologies and our ability to be forerunners, not followers in globalisation. The white paper may answer some of these questions, and of course we want to work with the Commission on all these points, but we are waiting to know more in the next few days and weeks.

name: Edina Tóth (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The Digital Single Market creates new opportunities to boost the economy and improve quality of life through artificial intelligence, including automation. Mobile and automated platforms are increasingly coming to the fore thanks to the development of digital services. AI-based technology therefore affects all sectors of the market, which presents not only many opportunities, but also many challenges. I believe that consumers should be properly informed about how it is possible to make the right decision without human intervention. To give just one example, it is increasingly the case that in the medical, legal or technical field, decisions are not made exclusively by specialists, but are taken in an automated form without human intervention. Ultimately, all consumers should have the opportunity to contact specialists who will review the correctness of the decision. It is therefore important that technological progress alone can never fully trigger the human factor. The potential of the internal market is still not fully exploited, so I believe that further measures need to be taken to ensure effective digitisation by placing the population, consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises at the heart of the single market.

name: Evelyne Gebhardt (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Yes, these are major challenges that we have as a way of making decisions, because they are far from neutral per se. In the end, there are very big questions, ethical questions, which we also have to answer. That is why it is important and right that we discuss this. The algorithms on which they are actually based are not created out of nothing, but are created by people who are, of course, not neutral per se. Nor is the way they are fed neutral.  And that is why one of the most important questions in this context is transparency – that citizens, consumers and consumers can also know what this algorithm is being created from and what data has actually been used to offer me this decision, which I should perhaps have when i buy a refrigerator, why I should take one brand and not the other. to take a very small topic. When it comes to driving – a car that has been automated in the UK, where there is a left-hand drive requirement, will create a problem in our right-hand-driving states. Here, too, we must pay attention to what will be done in these areas in the future.

name: Karen Melchior (Renew).
text: Mr President! Not everything that sparkles is gold! And not all automatic decision-making processes are artificial intelligence. That is why I am pleased that today we are not just talking about artificial intelligence, but about all kinds of automated decision-making processes. Many in our single market already use automated decisions, and more people are coming in – and that's good. That is why it is important that the framework we now set applies to all the technology we are going to see, and not just the buzzword of our day: artificial intelligence. Why do we have to do that? We have to do so because a decision does not become infallible from being taken by a computer. Technology is shaped by the same fallacies and prejudices that we humans ourselves are subject to. That is why the technology must be artificial. Maybe it's a bit vintage to talk about code, but we should remember that the responsibility for a code's decisions never lies with the code itself. A decision taken by a code must still be accountable to a person. When a decision is made by a computer, it still has to meet the same requirements as a decision made by humans. The decision must be explainable and defended. In fact, we may be able to make greater demands on automatic decisions than the human ones. We must dare to question the decision, even when we get the message: 'Computer says no'. I look forward to the Commission's reply and to the forthcoming White Paper.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I have listened with interest to your opening statement. It is great that you are preparing and presenting a White Paper on automated processes and artificial intelligence. We have also paid close attention to this issue in the last parliamentary term in the IMCO Committee.  It is great that the President is opening up this topic here, because the debate must continue, and while in the last parliamentary term we rather addressed specific sub-issues related to automated processes, such as the issue of driverless cars, I think that the issue of comprehensive EU-wide legislation that sets out clear rules for the problems associated with the use of artificial intelligence must now be addressed. Some have already been said here, consumer protection. An issue that I consider extremely important is the setting of rules for dealing with liability relations. Who is responsible to the consumer for damage or other negative consequences caused by a product that is controlled by artificial intelligence?  These are things that we are only partially answering today, where we do not have a clear comprehensive European answer, and it is up to you to prepare such legislation. I am not in favour of over-european legislation, but I believe that, in this area, in the area of modern technologies, automatic technologies and artificial intelligence, European uniform regulation is necessary in order to continue the free movement of goods and services that are somehow linked to artificial intelligence.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, algorithm-automated decision-making has an increasingly predominant role to play in our societies and in our lives. While they allow a quick and certain outcome of a decision, there are many things that need to be corrected to protect citizens and consumers, particularly the most vulnerable, who can often also be seriously damaged by errors in the process. Think of a wrong decision in the medical field or the rejection of a mortgage by a bank.  We therefore call for algorithms to be transparent and impartial, to be designed taking into account the diversity of our societies, and also to be based on up-to-date and high-quality data. We call for citizens and consumers to be informed when they are faced with automated decisions, so that they are always reviewable by a human being and revocable, and for European legislation to be fully implemented and adapted where necessary to take account of possible gaps in consumer protection.  The European digital route is and must necessarily be based on people and not on profits. We therefore call on you, Mrs Breton, to work accordingly in accordance with these principles.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I want to say that I welcome this debate, which was opened by the rapporteur. I like her approach, which she's trying to be complex.  When it comes to automatic decision-making itself, there are undoubtedly a number of advantages. Progress, innovation, modern technology, I could make a fairly extensive list here, but I must also add to the list of disadvantages, risks that are associated with automatic decision-making, which requires the stunning perfection of such machine decision-making code based on programmed algorithms. This is indeed an extraordinary difficulty and there are consequences. It has already been said here, insurance, the question of liability, and I also think of the punitive sanctions that will then be triggered from this.  We will set the tone for a number of Member States, and I think it is good that a White Paper will be created here and that we have chosen this comprehensive approach. I welcome this debate, but I think we are still at the beginning.

name: Valter Flego (Renew).
text: – Dear Chairman, Respected Commissioner (addresses the Commissioner directly), AI aims at a better life and work for all of us. And she should serve absolutely everyone.  Of course we see the greatest application in transport solutions, in health care, in agriculture, in marketing, etc. But I think the most important thing is that consumers need to be confident in the decision-making process and that's why we need to ensure maximum transparency of this process. That is why I propose a new term, namely the label "reliable artificial intelligence", which would allow maximum trust of citizens in such processes, but also reflect clear procedures and standards, security and transparency.  It is important to preserve the personal freedoms of every consumer citizen, and artificial intelligence must be a welcome innovation full of trust of all consumers and without any possibility of any manipulation.

name: Patrick Breyer (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Code is law – that is, what is written in machine code is in many cases as good as legislation, and therefore: Bad code is also like a bad law.  This means that today we are no longer just dealing with the situation in which algorithms really make decisions, but in many cases it is the case that algorithms make decisions or decisions are based on information calculated by algorithms. This situation must not be underestimated, because the number displayed is impressive – even for a person who may theoretically make the decision – but so far we are only protected or there are only certain guarantees of transparency for the decisions taken by machine.  I think that needs to change. In future, we also need transparency where algorithms influence and dictate decisions, because that a person decides must not only be pure fiction and theory, but must also be guaranteed in practice.

name: Thierry Breton
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, quite honestly, I do not know many parliaments in the world where we can have a debate of this quality on these subjects today. Beyond our partisan differences, we have all shared, basically, the same questions, the same feelings, the same wills, the same wishes. Deep down, I'm holding one thing back. In this evolution - this evolution that will last, I am not afraid to say, years or even decades, I remember that what the whole of your Parliament shares, and with it the Commission, is the place of man, the place of the human being, respect for our values, respect for who we are, the integrity of our decisions, the understanding of the phenomena that surround us , the intelligence of situations: what happens? Who makes the decisions? Will it change my life? Can I continue to intervene? Can I still turn against a body that has made a decision that is not right for me? All of these questions, ladies and gentlemen, are indeed included in this white paper. I say it again, it is called the white paper on artificial intelligence, but this is only the beginning of our reflection on what I myself have called reflection, the structuring of a new space in which we now work, in which we form, in which we are distracted, in which we exchange, which is the information space. It is superimposed, at the bottom, on the three other spaces that have gradually contributed to forming what we are today, to also organize our life in society: territorial space, first, of course, and then, with conquests, maritime space and airspace. And today, the information space. So yes, artificial intelligence is one of the first elements. I share a second observation, which you all share, and which I am delighted about because it was a fight that I also fought myself. Through the applications that we are going to have to manage, which will shape our decisions and our lives, artificial intelligence applications, or, as you yourself, Madam President, automated decision-making, there is data. We all share this too: no data, no artificial intelligence.  We've been a little too inclined to focus on algorithms, those lines of code, as you said. It's not vintage, the lines of code (maybe tomorrow, moreover, it will no longer be lines of code, when we are in quantum computing, it will be different processes). Today, this is what allows us to work, with this intimate relationship between modeling our environment in the form of 1 and 0 (soon, it will be qubits) and, precisely, the decisions we are ready to make. But behind that, of course, there is data - it has been evoked, by some of you, with the parable or metaphor of the wolf and the dog in the forest. But what did you mean by that? You obviously meant that when you take data that characterizes an animal in its natural environment, if you take the same animal in another environment, obviously, you are going to have differences in the application of the algorithm and therefore the process of what is called the learning phase, machine learning, which will integrate all this data. Yes, data is essential, and that is also the fight we want to fight with the Commission, with you, to define how to characterize this data and our European data. Some people say, I have heard it on the benches of your assembly, that we must not miss this turn. We may have been late, but I don't think so. I do not think we are behind in terms of technology. But in any case, this shift, of this data, we must not miss it. You are right, because the data that is before us and that will allow us precisely to feed intelligently, with data that contains our values, is obviously all the new processes before us, the industrial data, the so-called 'B2B', the public data, the data that will obviously come from the world of health - so important for all of us - , transport... All this data is in front of us. Every 18 months, the number of data that now constitutes the world's information portfolio doubles. So, of course, we must not miss this wave. That wave is precisely what we want to do in the Commission. Several elements: first, of course, do not regulate too much at the exit. It's too early. Today, we are talking about artificial intelligence, an exploitation data, tomorrow we'll talk about something else. On the other hand, we must be careful that everything that comes out is totally compatible with our values and gives citizens the freedom to choose. Remember what I just said: choose. Freedom of choice. Don't be trapped in an algorithm, a system, a data manager, a platform. Having the opportunity to maintain this choice is a fundamental value in the information world. We have to work on it. To have the opportunity to find, in these solutions, what we are attached to. Finally, of course, having the opportunity to do so in complete security - legal security of course, ethical security, but also information security, cybersecurity. These topics are absolutely essential. Through the reflection we propose, there will also be a reflection on infrastructure. We need infrastructure to store this data, to house applications - selective applications, smart applications. We also need to have control over our information systems, supercomputers, learning machines that will drive this data month after month. We must also have the capacity to project ourselves into the technologies of tomorrow to maintain this sovereignty and maintain what makes our difference, that is, the ability to choose, throughout the chain, what will increasingly condition a part of our lives, while being extraordinarily attentive to what shaping the fourth information space , which I was talking about earlier, is superimposed entirely on the foundation of values that make up our European continent.

name: Presidente. –
text: I would like to inform you that I have received a motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Article 136(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is over. The vote will take place on Wednesday.

name: Presidente. –
text: The following is the debate on the Commission's declaration on SMEs and better regulation [2020/2521(RSP)].

name: Thierry Breton
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, without transition from the world of data to the world of SMEs , but there is a transition, in fact, because the data world will shape many of the economic activities on our continent and will, I am absolutely convinced, inspire many of our small businesses, so important for our entire economic fabric.  President von der Leyen reminded us here, moreover, in this Chamber, not so long ago: SMEs represent all that is essential and all that is good in our economy. We know the numbers; you know them like I do. It is an extraordinarily dense fabric, extraordinarily important, made up of women and men entrepreneurs, entrepreneurs who, for almost all of them, have created their business and work night and day fighting to develop it - also fighting against the barriers, whose role it is to us to make them diminish.  Ninety-nine per cent of European businesses are SMEs, accounting for two thirds of our jobs. It is clear that SMEs must therefore take our full attention. That is why, in the context of my responsibility, since I am in charge of the internal market, it is absolutely essential to ensure that our SMEs can precisely benefit also from some of what we have just talked about, but also from the major issues that will shape the evolution of our continent, in particular the European Green Pact which will change many of our behaviour and the way we act. , to produce and consume. So, to help all SMEs, first of all there is an important element: the President of the Commission has asked me to appoint an EMS envoy - I am not sure how to translate this into French - a representative of SMEs who will allow me, precisely, to be the link between SMEs and the whole portfolio for which I am responsible, by being constantly on the ground and by bringing us up to all the problems that exist on the ground and that could perhaps be easily eliminated to ensure that energies move forward.  To do this, of course, we will have to legislate a little better for SMEs; there are still too many constraints that enclose them and hold them back, which in turn limit the fluidity of the internal market as SMEs in their ability to use this internal market. So better regulation also means applying the one-in, one-out principle to any new regulation: making sure that when you propose new regulations, you get one. The aim, of course, is not to deregulate, but to make our laws more flexible, more agile, better adapt to the current environment of SMEs, especially in the digital age, so that SMEs can benefit from all that this evolution will bring in terms of change in the way they work, but also to produce and establish a relationship with their own customers. SME tests are already part of the regular evaluation, impact assessments; we must continue them: again, we must move forward by looking at what is working well, correcting what can be done, and this is something that I intend to develop precisely with the help of this famous representative of SMEs. The new strategy we are working on for SMEs must give them a stronger voice in the Better Legislation initiative, and we want to propose a number of actions in this regard. I would like to say, moreover, that we are working closely with Vice-President Eef-ovi in this regard.  Our overall objective is to ensure that all of the Commission's proposals are designed on the basis of the principle of 'think first in small', starting from where value is created on the ground, at the SME level, and then going up, not the other way around. As I said, we really need to give a much bigger role, a much greater focus to the cumulative impact of legislation when introducing new obligations. I've been through it myself — it wasn't yesterday, but I was a small business creator and I know what it's like to be the loads that often make you feel like you're strangling, putting yourself - I've experienced it physically — with your head under water. Now we really need to help businesses, and digital is going to help us change that. We are extraordinarily fortunate to have a single market of 450 million consumers, a single market which is in fact governed, as was said in the previous debate, by common values, by common passions and also, of course, by common rules, common standards. That's our deal. Many envy us, for that most of the thing; that's what that makes our difference. It is because there are, too, that we know how to respond to those who knock on our doors, or to talk with those who want to leave us. This market is our base. It's our common good. It must also, of course, be the instrument available to SMEs.  Too many barriers still exist today, far too many. It is difficult for a small business to sell its products outside the borders, I know that. We must therefore work very hard in this area to ensure that this extraordinary opportunity represented by the internal market is open to all of our SMEs. It is true that digital technology will help us considerably. We can already see that some very large players benefit from what digital can bring to platforms for the sale of their products or services in a cross-border way. Here it is: this transposition, I want to lead it for European SMEs. I would like to conclude by saying that it is essential, with regard to the quality of our legislation, to also mention the regulatory review committee, which is responsible for monitoring the quality of impact assessments. This is very important for the SME world. Major assessments and quality assessments accompany the Commission's proposals. So it's an essential instrument. Again, as a former SME entrepreneur, I know that it is very important to be able to be listened to and, when new legislation is created, to be able to say, "Wait! Now it's fine. There, it's not okay; Well, why don't we change that a little bit?" It will be an obviously independent body, listening to its stakeholders, not an advisory committee. I believe it will be essential to have a positive or consistent opinion of this body in order for an initiative to be presented to the Commission for decision. It is a very important and, I believe, quite innovative instrument, which will help SMEs to tell us about the problems they face and parliamentarians and the Commission to solve them. So that's what I wanted to tell you to introduce this debate. This is an absolutely crucial issue. Many opportunities in the world that are open to us, many challenges too, and I look forward to the terms of your debate so that I can then provide some answers.

name: Henna Virkkunen
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank Commissioner Breton for presenting the views of the Commission. SMEs are really the backbone of our economy. They represent 99% of all businesses in the European Union, so their role is crucial when we speak about jobs and growth or innovations or competitiveness of Europe. I’m very happy that the new Commission has now many excellent goals to improve the position of SMEs in Europe. EU regulation needs to better help our SMEs to scale up, drive and expand. I would like to stress three points here. First of all, better regulation, which is the main topic of today’s discussion. I would like to put a very specific question to the Commission: how will the Commission measure implementation costs of European Union legislation ex ante and ex post so that the compliance costs for SMEs are reduced, while at the same time safeguarding environmental, labour and social standards? And because I know that Vice-President Šefčovič is responsible for this – better regulation, I would like to ask if it’s possible to receive a written answer to this specific question. But then two other points related to your portfolio, Commissioner Breton. First of all, I am very happy at the introduction of an SME envoy, which has been Parliament’s request for a long time, and it would also be good to hear where the Commission is planning to locate the announced SME envoy in order to oversee all relevant DGs and services. The third point is more for the preparation of the SME strategy, and it’s about late payments, because this is something that we are now hearing very much from the SMEs and stakeholders: that they have bigger and bigger problems with late payments, and that often the big companies – big customers – do not respect the timelines. I hope that the Commission will address the problem of late payments when preparing the SME strategy, because better enforcement of the Late Payments Directive is needed so that SMEs too can benefit from the Directive.

name: Patrizia Toia
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the programme you have brought here for a strategy for SMEs can only be attended and welcomed. On the contrary, I would say to you that we look forward to starting work on these issues, after years in which we have called for a strategy for businesses and SMEs without having any results. I must tell you that the first point for creating good regulation is also to reassess the issue of criteria for defining SMEs. I would remind you, Commissioner, that Parliament recently gave its opinion on this point, before consultation, and confirmed the current criteria, especially the number of employees, and all those elements that must not weigh down the reality of small and medium-sized enterprises, bearing in mind that in some countries the company is even very small, even micro and even familiar. On the strategy in general, I would like to remind you, also as cosme's rapporteur, of a number of points. Firstly, the work you are doing on value chains is very important; as many small and medium-sized enterprises as possible must be integrated into these strategies in order to strengthen their structure, to qualify their work and to involve them in the issue of neutrality and transition. Secondly, the dialogue between business, research, schools and universities to promote appropriate training is now too weak, especially in some countries. There is also this point in the strategy, because good legislative instruments do, but content to promote skills and training to support SME staff. Finally, innovation, digitalisation and scale-ups are essential points of this strategy and we are sure that it will take them into account.  I don't see good standards separated from good content. Good rules and good legislative procedures, good preventive and impact assessments cannot ignore the content that we will put as the focal content of the strategy.

name: Martina Dlabajová
text: for renew. – Mr President, Commissioner, thank you for the positive that has been said. It's a good thing we're holding the bar so high and we have such big ambitions. It is with great tension that we all expect the European Commission to present its vision for a European industrial policy that will bring a new impetus for economic growth, go hand in hand with innovation, stand firm and face the challenges before us. I understand we're still looking for the best way to do this. For example, we have devoted countless discussions to the role of multinational companies, we have also addressed what needs to be done to create successful and dynamically developing companies in the EU. Some colleagues here in the EP see it as the need to adapt the competition rules in order to allow the expansion of really large European firms, the so-called European champions, who would be able to compete with players in global markets. But beware, but let me remind you and emphasise one important thing: no large company has emerged as a large one. She always had to work her way up, she always had to start somewhere. Europe has one important advantage in this regard, and that is the enormous potential that our small and medium-sized enterprises hide. The figures are clear, these firms have shown positive trends in recent years, whether in creating added value or creating jobs.  I wonder, therefore, how the European Commission wants to address the call for the need to have really big players capable of global competition in the European market, but at the same time not to forget small and medium-sized enterprises, which undoubtedly deserve genuine support to prosper and grow, both in the internal market and in the international market. Once again, I would like to say that I welcome the efforts of the European Commission and you personally to focus on small and medium-sized enterprises. However, I wonder how you want and how the Commission wants to ensure that the Think Small First principle, the principle of taking into account the needs of small and medium-sized enterprises, is actually included in all the initiatives put forward by the Commission.

name: Presidente. –
text: Two information, first we are still in the round of initial statements of the political groups and therefore, according to the rules, at this stage there is no blue card procedure.  Secondly, we are late on our schedule and therefore I cannot guarantee at this time that it is possible to have the catch the eye procedure. I ask you all to keep your time of intervention.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, in the European Union, small and medium-sized enterprises account for more than 99% of enterprises and two thirds of private sector jobs. Their creation and competitiveness must therefore be encouraged, as they are an essential lever for economic development. This is all the more important because the rise of digital and artificial intelligence is an opportunity for them. Let's help them take advantage of this opportunity to enable the most inventive of them to become the economic giants of tomorrow. The European Union must therefore put its economic policy in order. It should facilitate their access to finance by encouraging banks to lend to them, including by providing them with loan guarantees. It must also create the conditions for fair competition in the European market, but also renegotiate free trade treaties that place too much importance on large companies. Finally, it must simplify the allocation of financial aid, the complexity of which often discourages companies that might be eligible. In conclusion, I am quite sceptical, Commissioner Thierry Breton, about the Commission's real desire to improve things, because your idea of appointing a 'Mr SME' seems to me to be a gimmick.

name: Damian Boeselager
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for coming here and talking about this very important topic. I am very happy to hear that you are an entrepreneur and founder yourself. I am as well. I founded a political movement so it was in a bit of a different sphere, but I’m also a huge fan of innovation and competitiveness. I also therefore welcome better regulation, especially decreased uncertainty. We know that especially for smaller businesses and start-ups it’s really hard to keep up if there is legal uncertainty, regulatory uncertainty, so I hope we can get better at that. But I also see, like my colleague from Renew, quite a boring trend: that we want to weaken competition, or at least, as the governments in Poland and Germany (my own country) and France and Italy have said, and that is exactly the opposite of innovation and competitiveness. So I hope that we can safeguard, with the Commission and Parliament together, the competitiveness of all the small players by not weakening competition.

name: Antonius Manders (PPE).
text: – [inaudible] debate, then what is then the sense of sitting here?

name: Presidente. –
text: Your point of protest is noted, but I haven't made any decision on that matter. This is a guideline that all colleagues know about the management of blue cards that are not granted in the initial interventions of the political groups, therefore, in the first round. That's a well-known rule.

name: Eugen Jurzyca
text: for the ECR Group. – Mr President, what small businesses need is less bureaucracy, a simple tax system, good law enforcement and protection of competition. The adoption of many positive measures is thus in the hands of the Member States. However, in order for businesses to be able to operate successfully across borders, they also need a functioning European market without unnecessary barriers. One of these barriers is access to finance, which is still problematic outside the Member State concerned. In this respect, clearer rules for the European capital market will be a positive step. With a measure of this type, both small businesses and European consumers will benefit from it, as both groups are economically in the same boat.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, small and medium-sized enterprises are the backbone of the European economy and also reflect important business traditions that are widespread in our territories. However, because of the size of the limited resources, they are often penalised by inadequate constraints and rules. The creation of a regulatory and administrative framework favourable to them is an objective that we support in order to offer them new tools to meet the challenges of a globalised economy. The defining challenge is fundamental, the inclusion of specific measures for micro-enterprises is also fundamental, and the opportunity to decline these principles is immediate. We want to strengthen the InvestEU programme to provide more support for investment in SMEs and also a new Commission industrial policy strategy that leverages innovation, internationalisation and access to credit.  We often hear, ladies and gentlemen, that the European Union is too far removed from the everyday reality of small businesses. It is good that we also remember this in this House. Filling this gap is in the interests not only of businesses but of our entire social fabric.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner Breton, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to join my colleague Henna Virkkunen in asking you and Vice-President sefsovic to answer our questions in writing. Firstly, on the SME filter: the Commission is currently voluntarily applying the existing SME test in its impact assessments. What is the specific way in which this test will be converted into the announced actual SME filter, and how do you intend to remedy and improve the current shortcomings of the SME test so that the SME filter becomes an effective tool? Will the specific impact on small and medium-sized enterprises actually be assessed in the future when carrying out comprehensive impact assessments on planned legislation? And the SME filter should be binding and truly independent. I have the following question here: what about the European Green Deal, will it be included? I certainly believe that the legislation on the European Green Deal will have a significant impact on small and medium-sized enterprises. On the question of 'regulatory control committee': so far we have three independent experts – here we need to strengthen this committee and actually see that we are coming to an independent review body. Finally, on the third point: gold plating – things are often tightened nationally, regionally, and we have to see that this gold plating does not take place. Finally, Commissioner, I would like to say what you said at the beginning about the SME envoy, the 'one in, one out' principle and the question of 'more parliamentary say': full support for the PPE-DE. If the legislation is better, the PPE-DE is at your side.

name: Nicolás González Casares (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, small and medium-sized enterprises make up 99% of all European businesses and generate 90 million jobs. Therefore, they are the backbone of our economy.  And the Commission has really proposed a specific programme — the single market programme — which has only EUR 1 billion; it doesn't seem like the line to be followed before, say, a strategic factor.  SMEs must be a priority in Community policy and I hope to see that priority in the European industrial strategy that we will decide in the coming months: with concrete, measurable and fundamentally ambitious objectives to provide us with the necessary tools to attack the Green Pact and to give muscle to the digital revolution. And finally, it's fine to create positions, but what we need is a powerful financial framework that will give our SMEs oxygen in the face of the challenge that comes in the coming years.

name: Liesje Schreinemacher (Renew).
text: Mr President, last Friday I spoke to Hans. Seven years ago Hans had an innovative idea: an online ticketing platform. His company grew from an attic room to a large office of 1 200 square meters. Great! We desperately need these entrepreneurs with courage and vision in the Netherlands and in Europe. Hans told me that he was happy with a harmonised European approach, but the tangle of rules now makes it almost impossible to comply with everything. A common complaint when it comes to doing business across borders. Administrative regulatory burden, hard-to-obtain financing and access to other markets are barriers faced by these entrepreneurs. That is not the intention, of course, because being able to do business across borders is one of the eu's most important advantages.  In short, European policy must stimulate entrepreneurship and meet the specific needs of the workplace.  Finally, I would ask the Commission to include its own 'one in, one out' principle in these plans, because for every rule that is imposed, one must also disappear. (The speaker responds to a "blue card" question in accordance with Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Antonius Manders (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – Mr President, thank you very much for your kindness, and Commissioner, thank you. I want to ask Ms Schreinemacher, because she gives an excellent example of how the burdens are for SMEs in the internal market. Perhaps an idea: what do you think of the idea of introducing a legally-binding arbitration for SMEs that SMEs can initiate, together with the national SOLVIT, and that the ECJ will take a short-track decision until, at the end of the procedure, the Member States will say ‘no’ or ‘yes’. What do you think of this idea? Perhaps Mr Breton can answer there too.

name: Liesje Schreinemacher (Renew)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you Mr Manders for your question. I don’t know the details now of your proposal and I wouldn’t know how it would fit in the Dutch or European justice system, but I do think the fact that you are making it easier and less time-consuming as a means to start and finish the legal procedure is a great idea. I’m happy to hear what Commissioner Breton has to say about this and how the details would work, but yes, I would support any way of making it shorter.

name: Gunnar Beck (ID).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Small and medium-sized enterprises, or SMEs, account for 56% of the economy across the EU and employ almost 100 million people. They have little access to the financial market; Bank loans are therefore essential. The Green Deal is more of a pretext for printing money without end than environmental protection, and the Capital Markets Union is helping big banks and investors who have been swimming in money since 2011, while SMEs are groaning under credit shortages. The printed money goes into unproductive financial assets and real estate, not into the real economy – consciously. The Green Deal, the banknote press, and negative interest rates are destroying wealth and distributing what remains for the sake of a financial system that continues to fool citizens and SMEs. Unfortunately, the EU is part of this system.

name: Robert Roos (ECR).
text: Mr President, I have read carefully the new EU SME strategy. Sincere intentions, but entrepreneurs are opinionated people. They have their own vision. They are not guided by a government, but they are not, I would almost say. An entrepreneur doesn't have time for that, but doesn't feel like it either. I speak from experience, because I was an entrepreneur before I entered this house.  But you can help SMEs, and not by devising 50 action points, but by removing regulations. In this way, Mr Trump stimulated the US economy. For each new rule, eight lines have been deleted.  Therefore, please also be a good fit for taxonomy. This will indirectly create a lot of additional regulatory pressure for SMEs. And if you really want to introduce rules, I have two for you: make it easier for SMEs to access public contracts and to make it compulsory for SMEs to be paid within 30 days.  (The speaker responds to a "blue card" question in accordance with Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tomislav Sokol (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – You mentioned many problems that SMEs are facing, but I think most of these problems are actually at the level of national legislation, especially national procedural rules and national taxation rules. So my question is: do you think that, in order to get rid of these kinds of obstacles, we need to harmonise national taxation systems and procedural rules at the European level? Because the only way to get rid of many of these obstacles is to have one common rule at European level, which would get rid of these kinds of national obstacles. So my question is: do you think that we need more harmonisation at the EU level?

name: Robert Roos (ECR)
text: "blue card" answer. No, I absolutely do not think that is the solution. In any case, we are opposed to taxes that are regulated by the European Union, which is a matter for the Member States. But it's not just taxes, it's GDPR regulation and all sorts of things that are just very burdensome for SMEs. This is not just about taxes. But taxes are a national matter and we certainly do not want to undermine that.

name: Κώστας Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Mr President, the small and medium-sized enterprises you refer to are in practice some of the most dynamic small and medium-sized enterprises that you do care about, which do not include the self-employed — without staff or with 1-2 staff — whom you treat as a 'structural problem'. Over time, it has been shown that any funds left over from the food of large groups and given to self-employed people are not able to reverse the impasse of re-employment, savage taxation, debts to the tax office, banks and insurance funds. They do not negate the law according to which 'the big fish eats the small', all the more so because the liberalisation of services and hours and the regulations of the European Union reinforce the tendency to concentrate the big ones. The tax reliefs of the New Democracy government do not upset the image in Greece, which shows that the little ones will fight for survival. The only way out is to fight self-employed and micro-professionals, not only for immediate relief from the unpopular policy of the European Union and governments, but also for the social alliance with the working class and small and medium-sized farmers in order to overthrow their monopolies and power.

name: Markus Pieper (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We already have the feeling that small and medium-sized enterprises are very important in the Commission. Vice-President Breton, Commissioner for Industry and Internal Market, Research and Innovation Commissioner Gabriel – everyone is committed to businesses, and this commitment almost always has to do with money: Horizon, Structural Funds, venture finance, Capital Markets Union. Thank you for the many good suggestions for SMIs. Today, however, I have also learned – and therefore express thanks to Mr Breton – that funding is not everything, that funding is not everything, that small and medium-sized enterprises need framework conditions. We need an internal market without foreclosure, we need legislation with little bureaucracy, we need a digital economy with fair and secure access to data as a raw material, we need a green deal with a carbon leakage process and impact assessments, especially for small and medium-sized industrial enterprises. SME policy is therefore much more than financial support. Finally, two points: firstly, we want a Commission that thinks more of small and medium-sized enterprises in a cross-sectional way. Mr Breton, thank you very much, but that is not enough for us to do so. We want it to be Mrs von der Leyen, it must be a staff office directly with the President of the Commission; otherwise, it will remain fragmented. Secondly, we want a redefinition of SMEs. Owner-managed mid caps are the backbone of the European economy. Here, however, there is no staff department as in large corporations; mid-caps also need deregulation. This, too, is an issue for the Commission not just to link small and medium-sized enterprises with subsidies. The framework conditions for small and medium-sized enterprises are much more important.

text: – Sur President, żgur li taqbel miegħi biex l-industry tagħna tibqa' kompetittiva jeħtieġ li nadattaw. Strateġija ġdida għall-intrapriżi żgħar tiddetermina ir-rwol tal-Ewropa fis-suq globali. name: Vlad-Marius Botoş (Renew).
text: – The small and medium-sized enterprises are a significant part of the European Union's economy. It is therefore natural to ensure that legislation does not make it difficult, on the contrary, to help maintain on the market and develop these very important economic actors.  It is worrying, however, that in Europe, a large number of SMEs close less than a year after its establishment. The cumbersome legislation, the lack of staff specialising in legal matters, burdensome access to funding, extremely harsh controls in certain Member States and \u2012 must recognise the corruption of the state apparatus at times are decisive factors in the failure of micro-enterprises. It should not be forgotten that even European funds are inaccessible to SMEs in different Member States, because of indicators that cannot be met in certain areas or because of the very cumbersome procedures of application and implementation.  A study is therefore needed to show us clearly what are the reasons that lead most often to the bankruptcy of start-ups and what are the ways in which they can be helped. Last but not least, I would like, Commissioner, to ensure that improved European legislation is quickly implemented in the Member States, respecting the letter, but above all, the spirit of the legislation.

name: Gianantonio Da Re (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission has done little to link the funding needs of small and medium-sized enterprises with the financial instruments guaranteed by the European Union. Furthermore, most beneficiaries are unaware of the financial instruments guaranteed by the Union and the Commission has limited knowledge of the financial needs of the beneficiaries. This is what the European Court of Auditors stated in its 2020 report No 02 published on 22 January. The debate on better regulation in favour of small and medium-sized enterprises requires an in-depth knowledge of the business sector, which is very absent today. Our small and medium-sized enterprises do not need more regulation, but a reduction in administrative burdens, financial instruments to support their competitiveness and appropriate trade protection measures against social and environmental dumping. More tax concessions are needed on socio-environmental investments in order to adapt their structures. A coherent response must be given to the new needs of the business system in order to ensure that businesses operate in a stable regulatory and economic environment, addressing the factors that hinder growth and innovation, less bureaucracy and more efficiency. The speaker is a small businessman: more facts and less talk.

name: Beata Kempa (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! Small and medium-sized enterprises are the backbone of the European economy. This has already been highlighted here on several occasions. But numerous internal and external constraints, such as bureaucracy and strict rules on doing business, can make it very difficult for entrepreneurs to run a small business. Creating a business-friendly regulatory environment is a long-term goal of the European Union.  But what does it look like in practice? In practice, however, the Union is creating a mobility package which kills competition between companies in the transport sector and causes the collapse of thousands of transport companies, e.g. from my home country of Polish, while increasing transport costs between Member States. EU regulations are market-driven, restrictive and dictated by the particular interests of member states. According to experts, deregulation and release, e.g. in the services sector, would bring growth of 1.8% to the European economy. And it is precisely towards the opening up of sectors and deregulation that the European economy should move today.

name: Pilar del Castillo Vera (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, it is a pleasure to see you around here. Well, at this point in the debate we all know that 99% of businesses in Europe are small and medium-sized enterprises and that more than 90 million workers work in small and medium-sized enterprises. A lot has been said, and I'm going to focus on two that I don't think have yet been mentioned and have a really important impact on the possibility of SMEs taking advantage of and optimizing all the benefits of developing digital technologies. On the one hand, the issue of digital infrastructures. The European Electronic Communications Code 4G, fibre and 5 G is currently being transposed and implemented. Networks are essential for you to take advantage of this digital transformation. The Commission has the competence to observe whether implementation is appropriate and it is essential that it does so. And secondly, something that permanently whitewashes the European Union. Training is required to manage data; Training means training, we need an action plan from the European Union that is ambitious, has clear objectives, can be measured and pushes each member country to close this delay in training and digital training. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Damian Boeselager (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – I really like your idea of improving digitisation and training for SMEs, also to digitise further, especially since the Data Strategy is coming up. My question here is: where do you see the role of the EU in helping this digitisation to actually get the right set of data, to measure it and to be able to share it and to analyse it?

name: Pilar del Castillo Vera (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – There are many initiatives. On the data, the Commissioner we have at the moment also has overwhelming experience and, moreover, in the previous debate he has spoken extensively on this issue. We are going to have a European strategy on data and there we will be able to discuss it.  I've referred to two because I think they're essential. One is already underway, which is the European Electronic Communications Code for the development of fibre and 5G networks. And the other is absolutely essential: what can the European Union do to make training, digital training a reality and not be behind us in many cases? Well, the answer has to be found here. The answer, to begin with, must be given by the European Commission.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: Please keep to the time. As my colleagues inform me, we're back on schedule by 20 minutes. Therefore, from now on I will not allow blue card questions to run smoothly and not last until midnight.

name: Maria Manuel Leitão Marques (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in 2005, in Portugal, a service called "Company on time" was created. It allowed to open a company, on average, in forty-five minutes and thirty-six seconds, when before it took fifty-five days. Better regularing does not mean, thus, regulating less, does not mean unprotecting consumers, workers or the environment. It means using technology and even artificial intelligence to eliminate useless procedures, making life easier for citizens and businesses. This effort for simpler regulation is especially relevant for small and medium-sized enterprises. Large companies have and can fund compliance departments. Small businesses cannot afford these tasks without harming their business. Leaving small businesses behind, sunk in bureaucracy, is also leaving a lot of economic initiative and job creation behind in the European Union.

name: Markus Buchheit (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. A lobby has spread here, and this is the lobby of the flowery destroyers of wealth with particular aversion to large corporations, but then also with indirect negative consequences towards small and medium-sized enterprises. Our Green colleagues here, in particular, believe that the state can solve economic problems better than competition itself through intervention. However, this is not the case. We have also known for years where the problems lie in the area of small and medium-sized enterprises, particularly in the area of tax burdens and bureaucracy.  The Green Deal and the CO2 tax will place an increasing burden on small and medium-sized enterprises in the coming years. Bureaucracy affects small and medium-sized enterprises more than large-scale industry. The item on the agenda is therefore completely missed. It should not be "Better Regulation" but "Less Regulation". Finally free the middle class from its state shackles and let it become what it once was, namely the engine of our employment and our economy.

name: Jorge Buxadé Villalba (ECR).
text: – Mr President, in Spain, as has already been said, small and medium-sized enterprises make up 99% of the business fabric. However, despite their importance, they continue to face the problem of disproportionate tax burdens, growing bureaucracy and difficulties in accessing finance, as well as additional costs, such as the rise in the interprofessional minimum wage applied by the new social-community government, which will cost 2,000 euros per year for each employer. We want Spanish workers to have higher wages, so that they can access decent housing and be able to start a family, but not at the expense of SMEs, but that it is the State that assumes the reduction of social burdens. More pay for workers, but the same performance for the employer. That's the common good. No one can be surprised if in Spain seven out of ten companies die before the age of five. Any initiative to improve legislation is going to be welcome, but let's be brave. Improving regulation means eliminating rules, not one by one, five to one, lowering taxes and social contributions, removing locks and opening up secure avenues to financing.  In short, no new strategies are needed. The usual: freedom and security.

name: Maria da Graça Carvalho (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, small and medium-sized enterprises are the basis of the European economy. However, they continue to be subject to a huge national, regional and European bureaucracy, sometimes even antagonistic. Simplification is essential. I therefore welcome the Commission for having enshrined the central objective of reducing the bureaucratic and regulatory burden snatifies the economic development of SMEs. In addition to the regulatory plan, there are other determining factors for the success of companies. The need to create a genuine European internal market that gives companies in the different Member States the opportunity to assert themselves on an equal footing. Access to European funds should also be transparent, with more information and simpler rules. We must promote compatibility between the rules of the different funds, such as the 'Horizon of Europe' and regional programmes, in order to maximise opportunities for SMEs. Finally, less bureaucracy, a bigger and more open market, better access to funds. Three challenges to give SMEs the conditions they deserve.

name: Johan Danielsson (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Small and medium-sized enterprises are, of course, extremely important to our economy, and cutting red tape and simplified rules is important for their growth. Let me be clear, however, on one point: this work must never mean a deterioration in workers' rights. The principle of 'one in, one out' introduced by the Commission therefore makes me a little worried. In order to compensate for all new rules by exempting businesses, especially SMEs, from corresponding EU regulations in the same areas, for example, do not work in the field of health and safety at work. The EU's work environment must be made more ambitious. New initiatives must be taken, and they cannot be destroyed by the removal of existing health and safety legislation at the same time. So let us avoid the forthcoming parliamentary term from initiatives that we had from the previous Commission's term of office, which proposed that derogations from health and safety regulations should be applied to companies with up to 250 employees. Such proposals are totally unacceptable.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Chairman, SMEs are the backbone of the European economy and their well-being is of enormous importance to the Union, Member States and European societies. In order for such companies to prosper, it is important to create a good business climate, keep the tax burden within reasonable frameworks, facilitate their joint appearance in public procurement procedures, reduce administrative burdens and strengthen lifelong education and make it accessible to their employees.  Ambitious public policies, such as the union's new green policies, must not be broken over the backs of small and medium-sized entrepreneurs who cannot afford it. High administrative requirements and parafiscal levies are a serious dam to the development of entrepreneurship and therefore it is important to make an impact assessment for each new regulation.  The European Union and the Member States can do the most for SMEs by get out of their way. That is why I support all initiatives that have deregulation and facilitation of business at their core.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I consider it very important that the European Commission prioritises small and medium-sized enterprises when developing its programme. We know that these firms have a key share of our economy and are also the most vulnerable. I know from the discussions with entrepreneurs, which I also regularly conduct as President of SM Europe, that bureaucracy is one of the main obstacles to the development of their business. Not only at national level, but at European level. We know that a small entrepreneur has enough to do to run his business, and he doesn't have the time or the desire to follow everything new that's being accepted. I therefore applaud the European Commission's anti-bureaucratic initiative, the 'one in, one out' principle, that is, one existing regulation is repealed, but we should not just stay with this. Small entrepreneurs need much more support. Firstly, they need better access to investment capital, aid for exports outside the Union and, last but not least, access to public contracts with a guarantee that they will be paid for their work. Secondly, they also need a helping hand in the transition to the digital economy, because they do not have the staffing or technical capacity to cope. Thirdly, they also need to learn and develop, which is why it is important to extend the programmes that will enable them to do so. For all of them, I can only mention 'Erasmus for young entrepreneurs'. Small entrepreneurs often go to the bottom of their powers to grow their businesses, employ people, create values and draw from them the whole of society, so it is our duty to help them.

name: Marek Paweł Balt (S&D).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Small and medium-sized enterprises face different challenges. They should be supported through a new strategy, given a helping hand in financing objectives that will be useful for the future of the European Union as a whole. One of the Commission's main objectives is now the Climate Neutrality Plan, which is extremely ambitious. We need to support small and medium-sized enterprises to become involved in new initiatives, innovation, green technologies, green education or the development of the circular economy. Subsidies for existing companies are insufficient. We spend EU funds on the unemployed, on starting a business, but in many countries unemployment is no longer a problem. The development of small and medium-sized enterprises and the sustainability of jobs in SMEs are becoming a problem. The small and medium-sized enterprises sector does not have the money to further develop and ambitious measures that would allow fair competition, which best represents their average lifespan. Increasing the amount of project grants for small and medium-sized enterprises will make better use of their potential. That is why we must make every effort and support these companies and their activities so that they can operate in conditions of fair competition.

name: Jörgen Warborn (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Strengthening the conditions of the small business owner is perhaps one of the most important tasks that we have at the moment. Europe is lagging behind in the global market, and that is why we need to launch a strong political programme to strengthen competitiveness.  After all, the Commission has promised to introduce the 'one in, one out' principle. For each new rule that is introduced, an old rule should be deleted. This is a good first step, but in practice it means plus minus zero – and it is by no means enough if Europe is to become the best in the world at business. I, and Swedish entrepreneurs, would like to ask the Commission a question: why are you content with plus minus zero? We must set a much bolder target than the status quo. In addition to 'one in, one out', I and the EPP Group want to reduce the small business owner's regulatory burden by 30%. Europe's small business owners should know that Me and the Moderates are on their side against bureaucracy in order to strengthen the business environment.

name: Enikő Győri (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Micro, small and medium-sized enterprises are not only the backbone of the European economy, but also its growth base. These companies are currently struggling with a lot of difficulties, such as bureaucracy and a wide variety of regulations. It is therefore essential that we do everything in the internal market to ensure that only reasonable expectations are maintained against them and, where possible, to make their lives easier. We know that the Union has serious competitiveness problems. The 2019 Global Competitiveness Index also notes that East Asia is currently the most competitive region with Singapore at the top. The companies of these States, i.e. our SME rivals, do not have to comply with a number of requirements and therefore start from a more advantageous situation. Another challenge – there has been a lot of talk here – is to keep up with third countries at the forefront of digitalisation and technological innovation. This requires know-how and resources. Commissioner, the debate has shown that we agree on this goal, and now we would very much like to see the details, the implementation. Can we expect the Commission to examine all legislative proposals in advance in terms of how it affects competitiveness and SMEs, and that is what it means for Parliament? Because SMEs: the costs of any rule change are disproportionately more difficult for them. I therefore ask that you get to work and introduce the SME filter, so that we can give them, SMEs, a better chance and thus the success of our economy.

name: Pernille Weiss (PPE).
text: Mr President! Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Breton. Thank you for this debate. To take good care of his backbone, it is important for a human being, and that is essential for the European Union.  As a former nurse and owner/manager of my own business for 12 years, I know a little about both.  I have two specific questions: firstly, unfortunately, many SMEs are seeing the burdens they are struggling with stemming from the final stages of trialogue negotiations. They simply don't get caught and wiped out. What will the Commission do to avoid this more effectively in the future? My second question is what will the Commission do to strengthen green SMEs' access to and activity in the global market through EU trade agreements? Many SMEs have plenty to do with the opportunities and challenges of the single market. And many people think the practices of trade agreements are difficult and time-consuming to work out. However, the climate challenges create the need for the mass of green technologies developed, particularly by SMEs, to be brought quickly to a level where they can realise the difference they can also make to the climate outside the EU and thus also to European competitiveness.

name: Sandra Pereira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, small and medium-sized enterprises often appear in the European Commission's speech almost always for the purposes of justification, whether regulatory or deregulation, which actually serves very different interests from those of SMEs, which are, for the overwhelming majority, very much oriented towards national markets. That is why they are the first to suffocate when the national internal market is asphyxiated and the first to suffer from the monopolistic dominance of the key sectors of the economy resulting from the liberalisations decided by the European Union or the financial domination of private banking which will be accentuated by the banking union. It is also on behalf of SMEs that it is necessary to regain public control over strategic sectors of the economy, guiding them to economic development rather than the predatory profits of large economic and financial groups, and breaking with the constraints imposed by the European Union, ranging from liberalisation to the Stability Pact, just to name a few.

name: Радан Кънев (PPE).
text: – Dear Mr President, the European institutions must protect small businesses from the greed of their own governments, from excessive administrative burdens and from an excessive tax burden.  In this important debate, my proposal to you is to address the second question and consider introducing a minimum, universal value added tax threshold in the European Union. For example, not less than EUR 100 000 threshold for compulsory VAT registration in each European country, because in my home country the VAT registration threshold is below EUR 25 000, which means that any entrepreneur who does not conceal income is obliged to register. That's just not fair. I also propose that we consider maximising VAT rates for food and tourism services across the Union, for example 10 per cent, to ensure fair competition within the European Union between small entrepreneurs.

name: Robert Hajšel (S&D).
text: – Mr President, yes, the implementation of the so-called Green Pact or thus the transition to a greener and more digital economy will be a heavy burden on small and medium-sized enterprises, which, on the one hand, are the backbone of our economy, but are also very vulnerable to crises that may occur in the near future. But what do small and medium-sized enterprises need? In particular, law enforcement, they also need a good tax system and protection of competition. They need a good legislative framework, and it is therefore good that the European Commission is coming up with this initiative. Consequently, they need a stable legislative environment, because small and medium-sized enterprises do not have the capacity to absorb quickly any new changes that would be shrug-off. It is therefore also good that the European Commission has acceded to the rule with one legislative measure adopted, the other rejected or therefore deleted. Because this, this bureaucracy, is perhaps the biggest burden for small and medium-sized enterprises. They also need access to finance, and here are the various funds, and we need to adapt these funds to their needs.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I don’t accept for a minute that good regulation is a problem for SMEs. I’ve been in business all my life. I’ll tell you what is a problem: mindless, stupid bureaucracy is a problem for SMEs. But in actual fact, when it comes to good regulation, it’s the lack of it that actually can damage SMEs a lot of the time. For example, we don’t regulate our banking industry properly, and that can be a huge problem for SMEs. They give you an umbrella if the sun is shining and they take it back off you if it starts raining. There are energy costs. Very often there isn’t good regulation on how it’s monitored by the state. Local authority rates in Ireland are killing small business. Rents: there’s no proper regulation of rents in Ireland. I don’t know what it’s like across the rest of Europe, but it’s this lack of good regulation that is really damaging SMEs, and it goes without saying that a lack of real good positive government support is also a problem. They give it to foreign direct investment but they won’t give it to their own indigenous industry.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Our companies, our companies suffer from excessive bureaucracy, as has been mentioned several times. I would like to give a specific example, which is a major nuisance for many small and medium-sized enterprises in my home region, Bavaria – namely the so-called A1 certificate. That is the proof that must be provided when performing in another European country. You have to show that you are in a social security system. And if my master carpenter from Traunstein goes to Salzburg and has to install a cupboard there, he has to carry this A1 certificate with him. Otherwise, if he cannot present them, he will have to pay a heavy fine, a large fine. So that really creates dismay and anger without end. Commissioner, I am counting on you.
