You are digitally savvy, let us set up an online clearing system for these A1 certificates in Europe, so that it is easy for someone who controls to combat undeclared work: they log in and can then check online whether there is an A1 certificate here, yes or no. That would be a great thing if you could do something like that.

name: Clare Daly (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I’m very glad that we’re talking about SMEs. They employ more people, they generally pay more taxes – or certainly they do in Ireland – and the environment that they have to work in is incredibly hostile, particularly when we compare it to the manner in which foreign direct investment and multinationals are treated, and indeed the supports given to the agricultural sector. Now in Ireland, SMEs almost have to pick up the tax bill that the multinationals don’t pay. They’re the ones who take the hit when the economy goes into austerity, and they’re the ones who carry the can for that. It’s an affront to them that the Irish Government would take legal action in order to say that we shouldn’t collect EUR 13 billion in tax from Apple: monies that could be collected in order to invest in small and medium-sized businesses. I would like to echo the points made that one man’s bureaucracy is another man’s regulation, and while we do not support bureaucracy in any way, regulation and good standards are important in terms of employment, in terms of environmental protection. But critically, small and medium businesses need to be supported.

name: Thierry Breton
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for this very rich debate, which obviously shows me that, from where you come, you are all faced with quite similar problems concerning our SMEs, which constitute, as has been said earlier, the most active economic fabric of our European continent. I repeat a few words that have been shared on all the benches of this Chamber: late payments; Integrating SMEs into value chains Financial assistance too much bureaucracy Access to credit need for more specific training, particularly in the area of digital developments. You all share, indeed, the same concerns. I will try to respond quickly to all these subjects that you have mentioned and which will obviously be part, for many of them, of the plan that we will propose with regard to industrial policy, as it is true that the value chains on which an industrial policy is based worthy of the name must integrate, from start to finish, , our entire SME fabric.  Firstly, a question on the assessment of costs, which we are talking about, of course, with my colleague, Commissioner 'Ef-ovi'. The guidelines already explain the methodology and the next communication "Better Regulation" (which, I remind you, will be presented in April) develops precisely the principle one in, one out. Above all, I emphasize one point: what needs to be assessed is the cumulative costs. obviously, this must feed into our impact analysis, but we have to be clear: a lot of the burden comes from national laws, as we all know. With regard to the SME emissary, who will be an emissary, I have not yet decided, the exact framework has not yet been decided and I have several solutions, which I am thinking about today. One thing is certain: I very much hope that this person is close to me, with access, of course, to a specific team. At the same time, this person will have to be fully available on the ground, as I said earlier, to meet and listen to all SMEs on the continent. Moreover, as soon as I have decided on the choice of the person, I will come, if you agree, ladies and gentlemen, to present to you the architecture of this operation.  Delays in payment are an absolutely essential subject, which you have talked about a lot, both of you. It's a subject I'm looking at closely, of course. It must be integrated into the full understanding of the value chain. There are, of course, delays in payment, and there is also the increasing reliance of SMEs on larger contractors. That's all you have to look at very carefully.  To go quickly, some have mentioned it, it is true that an arbitration solution can be interesting. It can be examined; I do not know if the mechanisms that were proposed can work. But it is a subject, indeed, that I have known myself. It is true that many SMEs do not dare to go to court because they know that it is too long, too expensive and that, in the end, it is done to their detriment. Arbitration procedures are often interesting solutions, which I will consider.  Important point on over-regulation, or gold plating. We have to be very careful with the fact, again - as I said earlier, but I repeat - that a lot of the burden on SMEs comes from national laws, especially when they transpose European directives. They must be identified and notified. At the moment, only three countries are doing this, which is obviously very little, and I want to do more on this point. I will come back to you on that, but, yes, we have to move much faster on that. Access to funding is an absolutely essential issue. It will be even more so in the context of the digital transitions and the green pact, which has also been much talked about in this debate. We obviously have regional funds, I would remind you anyway, because it is very important: COSME, with 30 billion mobilized to support 500,000 SMEs over seven years, is quite important. But also InvestEU, which guarantees loans and improves access to finance. The SME window is 11.2 billion, or one third of InvestEU's guarantee instrument. of course, that is not enough, but we still have important instruments for the development of our SMEs. A question about the SME filter: the SME test that already exists is part of the impact analysis, so it only comes at a certain point in the decision. But, again, it does not affect the choice of the supported option in the impact analysis. Responsibility for the SME test is decentralized. The future SME filter is thought to intervene at all stages of the procedure, in order to identify proposals that could be barriers for SMEs. The aim is also to involve all the Commission's services, in connection, of course, with the future SME emissary.  Very important remarks were also made on access to public contracts and public procurement. This is obviously a very important lever - 14% of the economy. It is therefore a lever that needs to be used more and I absolutely agree that more should be done to allow SMEs to have privileged access to public procurement. When I talk about SMEs, this is also true for start-ups, so it is an area that I look at carefully, particularly with regard to the legal framework for public procurement, in order to determine what more can be done and how.  One last point, but one of which I have also mentioned a lot in my opening remarks, concerns the internal market. Our SMEs must be able to benefit from this internal market. It is really absolutely essential. As I said today, unfortunately, it is clear that they often have to rely on one or two platforms, which are not, moreover, of European origin, and which become for them a kind of gate keepers for access to the internal market. This is really something that needs to get our full attention.  We must therefore ensure that digital transformation enables our SMEs to find new markets beyond their national borders. I also noted some interesting ideas about the fact that our administrations need to digitize, particularly with respect to Form A1. It's an important topic. We have done that in a lot of states for automated tax levies, which is much more complex, so we should be able to do that at the national level.  Finally, a topic that has mobilized a lot of debates tonight: the one in, one out. I would remind you that the principle should not be mechanical. We are looking closely, of course, at what will be removed. It is not a question of using this instrument to deregulate, of course, much less to compromise the protection of workers. It is simply a question of seeing what has evolved. As we said earlier, we are in a rapidly changing world, particularly under the pressure of digital technology, but also under the impetus we want to give our continent on the green pact. In all this context, in an equally more geopolitical evolution of the balance of power that binds us to other continents, it is something that must be looked at, and therefore must be modernized. That, ladies and gentlemen, is what I could tell you tonight, at the conclusion of our work. I see that there is a lot of interest. So I'll give you an appointment to present our industrial strategy where, of course, there will be a lot of talk about SMEs.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 171 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D)
text: in writing. – They are small and medium-sized, vulnerable to untimely change and pressure, but they have a strong national footprint. It must therefore be protected by single, simplified and easy-to-apply legislation. I ask you today if there is a strategy for this and what are the first three measures you will put into practice to encourage these small and medium-sized enterprises to develop, create new jobs and adopt a green strategy?

name: Beata Mazurek (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Small and medium-sized enterprises are a hugely important element in the economy, they form the basis of it, and 99% of companies both in Poland and in the European Union as a whole belong to this sector. This segment is a leader in job creation and it is therefore essential that EU regulations are simple, transparent and stimulate competitiveness and innovation. Preserving free market and equal rules for all Member States is crucial at EU level, not an attempt to impose bureaucratic barriers to the functioning of the SME sector. A great example of effectively taking care of the interests of small and medium-sized enterprises is Poland, where the current ruling formation has introduced a number of facilitations and transparent rules for the sector. It is worth mentioning, for example, the Constitution for Business, the institution of the Ombudsman for Small and Medium-sized Enterprises, the numerous simplifications in the conduct of business and fiscal relief for those who start it, as well as for those who already run their own business. Better regulation for SMEs is a guarantee of Europe's economic success. Let's do everything we can to make it happen.

name: Andżelika Anna Możdżanowska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – SMEs account for 99.8% of all companies in Poland and 90% across Europe. Small businesses don't have the resources and time to respond to new regulatory burdens on an ongoing basis. The entrepreneur needs a stable law, simple and understandable rules. The law cannot be created only by officials. We need to think small and listen to entrepreneurs at every stage of legislation. Before we introduce a new load, let's apply the one-on-one policy and remove the old one. Let us reach for good practices from the Member States.  In Poland, we have introduced the "Business Constitution", which is the foundation of changes in the legal environment for companies, and the initiative "Simple Language" in offices. There is also a Black Book of internal barriers that are burdensome for entrepreneurs. Good regulation is only possible through dialogue between officials and entrepreneurs. A better law is the sustainable development and well-being of every citizen of the European Union.

name: Rovana Plumb (S&D)
text: in writing. – Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the European Union face challenges related to increasing the level of competition worldwide, the emergence of new business models, digitalisation, climate change, the deployment of new technologies in both the industrial and services sectors and the development of the circular economy. The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development cannot be achieved without SMEs, given their huge importance for social, economic and environmental development. At the same time, without them there can be no just transition to a sustainable economy that contributes to job creation. Efforts to bring in other regions, communities together for the sustainable transition, must be continually intensified so that no one is left behind. Legal coherence and ensuring adequate financial sources will help strengthen the commitment of all parties to society. Governments and social partners can work together to provide business information and advice on green business practices, eco-innovation and regulatory systems. We need tools and mechanisms to ensure a level playing field at European and global level for European SMEs, in particular for technologies of strategic importance to Europe.

name: Susana Solís Pérez (Renew)
text: in writing. SMEs are the engine of our economy as they account for 99% of EU businesses, and their role is crucial when it comes to jobs and growth, innovation and competitiveness. The new proposal should create a favourable environment for a European entrepreneurial ecosystem to emerge, facilitating the entry of new products and services to the market. The European Green Pact needs to take into account the specificities of SMEs by making them the protagonists of the ecological transition. In addition, legislation needs to be more agile, and better adapted to changes in digitization. On the other hand, it is necessary to energize the relationship between research centres, universities and the private sector, and invest in digital skills, qualifications and requalification to ensure that no one is left behind. It is also essential that funding in Europe improves, as almost 45% of companies are currently leaving the EU because there is insufficient funds to scale up and transform startups into large European unicorns. Finally, we need a strong financial sector that bets on European ideas. It is no longer possible to lose ideas, companies and human capital. Let us bet on innovation and entrepreneurship.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on - the oral question to the Commission on the revision of the guidelines on trans-European energy infrastructure, by Cristian-Silviu Buşoi, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (O-000012/2020 - B9-0008/20) (2020/2549(RSP), and - objection pursuance to Rule 111 of the Rules of Procedure: Union list of projects of common interest (2019/2907(DEA)

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi
text: author. – Mr President, the regulation on guidelines for trans—European energy infrastructure lays down rules for the timely development and interoperability of TEN—E networks, identifying the trans-European energy infrastructure priorities which need to be implemented in order to meet the Union’s energy and climate policy objectives. It also identifies projects of common interest needed to implement those priorities.  The TEN—E regulation sets priority corridors and thematic areas of trans—European energy infrastructure and provides guidelines for the selection of Projects of Common Interest (PCI). The first list of PCIs was established by a delegated act in 2013. Now we are on the fourth PCI list, which was adopted by the Commission on 31 October 2019 with 151 PCIs. As reflected in Parliament’s first reading position of 17 April 2019 on the proposal for a regulation on the Connecting Europe Facility for the period 2021—2027, the co—legislators provisionally agreed that the Commission should evaluate the effectiveness and policy coherence of the TEN—E regulation. For that evaluation, I would like to remind you that the Commission should consider inter alia the Union energy and climate targets for 2030, the EU long—term decarbonisation commitment and energy efficiency as a first principle.  I’d also like to stress that the TEN—E regulation was adopted before the adoption of the Paris Agreement. Energy plays a central role in the transition to a net—zero greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions economy, and therefore efforts to continue decarbonising the energy systems are necessary to enable the Union to reach its ambitious target and be world leader, while at the same time ensuring a coherent and inclusive transition of other sectors, maintaining the security of energy supply in the Union and coping with an increased demand for electricity.  With the aim of achieving its climate and energy goals and enhancing innovation, sustainability and growth, it is at the same time very important to remain competitive worldwide. The Union needs an up-to-date, high—performance energy infrastructure that is future-proof, cost-efficient and can provide a security of energy supply, including diversification of root sources and suppliers. Priority corridor scenarios, as well as eligibility criteria, should follow the evolution of the energy system and continue to be consistent with Union policy priorities, in particular in the context of long—term decarbonisation pathways. Adequate infrastructure, deployment and energy efficiency projects and policies should be used in a complementary way to help reach the Union’s objectives and targets. Building on the success of the Energy Union, we need to strengthen our efforts to improve energy efficiency, speed up deployment of clean energy and technologies, increase interconnectivity, and also of course further integrate our energy single market. In its resolution of January on the European Green Deal, Parliament called on the Commission to revise the TEN-E guidelines before the adoption of the next PCI list. The Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) welcomes the announcement in the European Green Deal Communication that the revision of the TEN—E guidelines will take place in 2020 and asks for a clear timetable.  As regards the fourth PCI list, new gas infrastructure under the fourth PCI list is designed to last at least 40 to 50 years, and in some cases even longer. May I remind you that the very same infrastructure will be able to be used in not so many years from now to transport biogas and hydrogen, and also – during the transition phase – gas pipelines and interconnections, which play an important role in ensuring the energy security supply, affordability and sustainability. We need a balanced and realistic approach to achieve our common goal of carbon neutrality, and I would like to remind you that we still have 41 coal regions to support and sustain in a just and inclusive transition.

name: Marie Toussaint
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, something is wrong. The planet is dying and, report after report, experts remind us that we must give up fossil fuels to stop the climate runaway. However, far from its ecological commitments and in total contradiction with its declarations of good intentions, the Union is preparing to declare a priority list of energy projects, more than a third of which are fossil gas projects. There are 103 of us today asking you to review the copy. This list is scientific nonsense, an economic error and, above all, a political fault. This is scientific nonsense, because it has long been known that 84% of the fossil resources known today should not be used. This is an economic mistake, because continuing to invest in extremely expensive fossil projects hinders our ability to focus our investment efforts where the need for financing is so great. No, really, something is wrong when the Union wants to inject almost 29 billion euros into climate projects. Accepting this list would be a political fault, finally, because the list proposed to us is dangerous for the planet, and therefore for the people who inhabit it. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, we must review the TEN-E guidelines and the criteria that accompany them as soon as possible, so that Europe can never again invest in fossil fuels. But we already need a new list of projects excluding fossil fuels for the next two years. Colleagues, let us make no mistake about the meaning of history. In the aftermath of the war, Europe was built around steel and coal and wanted to build peace on growth. It is now around green industries and the exit of fossil fuels that we must build Europe. Our prosperity must necessarily combine sobriety and justice. Ms Simson, you could have -you should have turned your back on this proposal from your predecessor and chosen to become the Commissioner of the real Green Deal. Dear colleagues, I know that many of you have doubts about this list. It is time to express them and to act accordingly. It is time to change the model to protect the future, it is time to dare to take strong action. I call on you on Wednesday to choose the green pact, to choose ecology, to choose the future and to reject this list.

name: Kadri Simson
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, two months ago I presented my views on the future of the Trans-European Networks – Energy (TEN-E) Regulation before the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE). This evening I have the opportunity to address this important issue before this plenary.  In the Green Deal Resolution adopted in January, Parliament stressed the importance of modern, clean, secure and smart new energy infrastructure for delivering the European Green Deal. I share the same vision. Turning this vision into reality requires making the TEN-E Regulation adopted in 2013 fit for Europe’s future energy system and fully aligned with the European Green Deal.  If we want to make Europe the first climate-neutral continent by 2050, we have no time to lose. As you know, the Commission was due to carry out an evaluation on TEN-E this year. I have decided to accelerate this evaluation and in parallel to start work on a revision of the TEN-E Regulation in order to present a legislative proposal in December 2020.  The overarching objective is to design a future-proof framework that will allow us to fund the infrastructure we need for the European Green Deal. The focus will clearly shift to deploying clean energy across the whole economy in the most efficient way. By 2050, the share of electricity in the total energy consumption is expected to be more than double. We need electricity infrastructures and innovative technologies such as smart grids, offshore wind and hydrogen that works. Also carbon capture, storage and utilisation and energy storage.  The new framework should in particular look at promoting sector integration, and I will consult widely stakeholders in the preparation of the proposal. And of course I will involve Parliament early on.  I commit to speed up work as much as possible, but we cannot risk cutting corners. That’s why December is our targeted date for adoption. I hope Council and Parliament will be able to process this proposal quickly, as they have done for other priority proposals in the past. But it is possible that the new regulation will not be in force in time for the adoption of the 5th projects of common interest (PCI) list in fall 2021. In this case, I intend to already ensure that the process for the selection of the 5th list of projects of common interest will already reflect the European Green Deal priorities. That means, firstly, that the sustainability criteria for all candidate projects will be strengthened to take better into account for each project its CO2 and methane emissions.  Secondly, I will strive to integrate more energy transition projects in the 5th PCI process, in particular smart clean CO2 infrastructure projects. I commit to work closely with the Member States and project promoters to help bring forward these projects. And, thirdly, I will strengthen the involvement of Parliament during key steps in the selection process, including the regional groups. I intend to establish a continuous political dialogue with you and the ITRE Committee. I will be guided by the objective to include more innovative projects enabling the transmission of renewable and decarbonised gases and projects enabling the smart integration of electricity and gas networks.  Finally, the oral question asks how we will approach the funding from the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) of the projects in the 4th PCI list. The PCI label is a precondition for CEF funding, but not a guarantee.  While respecting the current rules and procedures, the Commission will ensure that the European Green deal will provide the background against which the selection process for PCI funding will be assessed. I note that already the CEF Regulation governing the financing of PCIs gives priority to electricity projects over gas. Honourable Members, I have set out my views for the future of TEN-E. In this light, I hope that Parliament will vote in favour of the 4th PCI list. The list includes key infrastructure projects that sustain the increasing share of renewables, address the remaining energy security challenges and underpin the modernisation of an integrated infrastructure. Electricity projects make up three quarters of the 4th PCI list. An objection to the 4th PCI list would mean that the 3rd PCI list remains in force, a list with 40% more gas projects than the new list. As a consequence, key electricity interconnectors and energy transition projects such as the North Sea wind-power hub, new smart green projects and new CO2 network projects would not be eligible for funding under the Connecting Europe Facility.  I have set out how I intend to work on an energy infrastructure policy fit for the future. I will work closely together with Parliament. I count on your input and support for making the TEN-E policy a driving force for Europe’s climate neutrality transition.

name: Maria da Graça Carvalho
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, I call for an urgent revision of the TEN-E Guidelines – a revision consistent with the energy and climate objectives in all the five dimensions of the Energy Union: decarbonisation, security of supply, internal energy market, energy efficiency, more research leading to affordability and breakthroughs in low-carbon technologies. The European Commission has recently published the fourth list of projects of common interest. This list is based on the current guidelines, not taking into account the new climate ambition. On Wednesday we are voting on an objection to this list, but we must not forget that if the fourth list is rejected, we will fall back on the third. That list includes 40% more gas projects than the Commissioner just said, compared with the fourth. It is much less ambitious in terms of climate change goals. The revision I’m asking for is also an opportunity to reassess some of the PCIs. The Commission should consider the crucial needs of certain regions, as is the case of the projects of the Iberian Peninsula and other regions in Europe.

name: Miriam Dalli
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, we are discussing today concrete projects that should be in line with what we were discussing just a few weeks ago in this same Chamber: the European Green Deal. In our quest to move towards carbon neutrality by 2050, we need to make sure that we invest in the proper infrastructure today. We can do this with the full understanding that different parts of the EU have different realities, but at the same time also understanding that investments need to be made in cleaner sources and not locking countries’ reliance on fossil fuels. In the full list of energy projects that we are discussing, there are still fossil fuel projects, including oil—supply projects. I understand that interconnection projects are necessary to ensure security of supply and solidarity among Member States, which until today are still disconnected; however, this 4th list goes further and opens the door to heavy investments in completely new fossil fuel pipelines and infrastructures. Things have changed drastically since the fourth Projects of Common Interest (PCI) list was drafted, including in the formation of Member States that makes the European Union as a whole, and this has to be taken into account, something which is clearly lacking in the formulation of this list. Now, going back to the 3rd PCI list is not what we need, but money should be invested in projects that can really help us move forward in the right direction. It is for these reasons that the European Commission needs to carry out all the sustainability assessments required to ensure that money is invested in projects that can really make the European Union carbon neutral by 2050. It is only if we do this that we are really making sure that we have projects that are in line with what we want to achieve with the European Green Deal.

name: Morten Petersen
text: renew group. Mr President! First of all, I am pleased to see the Commissioner back safely after visiting my home country here last week. And I hope that the Commissioner has had a good opportunity to see how the green transition is being worked on, for example with the expansion of offshore wind in the North Sea.  Because this is just an example of an area where cross-border investment in green infrastructure is needed. Cross-border green investment, which should be the focus of these projects of common interest. After all, this is the only way we can have a real internal energy market by tying the markets together. And the green transition is urgent, as we all know, a political movement that requires us to act. This also applies to the way we invest, and not least what we are investing in, which is why the discussion we are having tonight about the so-called PCIs is incredibly important.  Of course, it is no good that we invest incorrectly and that we invest black instead of green. And we must be careful not to invest in projects that risk ending up as 'stranded assets' in English, and that is why, on the renew side, we want to push as much as possible so that we can change the basic criteria for investment we make to ensure that the investments are in line with the Paris objectives. We would also like to ensure that the European Commission uses its opportunity to assess all projects so that we ensure that they meet these very objectives, and I am pleased to hear the Commissioner's commitment to speed up the process in relation to the revision of the basic criteria, because it is urgent precisely so that we can ensure that we invest green and not black.  And let me just say that I am quite in line with what has been said earlier: this fourth list is preferable to the third list, but we must make sure that we revise the very basic criteria, which is important for the green transition.

name: Markus Buchheit
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We are a representative of the people, and therefore we are ending lobbying interests such as the Green Deal. What really matters to the citizens are essentially two factors: firstly, a cheap and, secondly, a secure energy supply. An essential objective must be to guarantee security of supply, and this is clearly about diversification. Dependencies on individual players should be avoided. Security of supply must rest on several pillars, and Nord Stream 2 could make a significant contribution to this. Together, of course, with LNG terminals and better connections to other projects for gas supply from abroad. When I hear that too many gas projects are being included in the TEN-E programme by the Greens, but that the same group is also calling for the closure of coal-fired power stations and that nuclear power is also on the verge of being phased out in countries such as Germany, I wonder whether you want to leave the supply to consumers solely to the whims of nature. At the same time, however, we also need cost reductions, especially in the electricity sector. It is unacceptable for private companies to turn over past investment failures to the taxpayer by jumping on the funding opportunities of the TEN-E programme. Moreover, one thing must be quite clear: gas and electricity supply is a highly sensitive, indeed strategic, area of our infrastructure, where we must not allow it to become a mass of blackmail – neither by foreign states, as in the last case of China in Germany, nor by companies such as 50Hertz.

name: Bas Eickhout
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, thank you Commissioner. I have to say, when I read the Green Deal of the Commission, it reads very promisingly. It’s talking about bringing Europe on a new path to a new economy, and it’s talking about a move away from harmful subsidies. And then at the same time, you are defending here the 4th list of these projects of common interests, which are fossil subsidies. You are here defending just more fossil subsidies. Where is the Green Deal promise of a new path? Where is that? Even you acknowledged in your speech already that everything will be better when we do the 5th list, but for now we have to accept the 4th list. That’s not how I expected a new Commission with a new ambition. And to my colleagues who are saying: well, okay, it’s not ideal but let’s do it for now – are those the same colleagues who said a couple of months ago: ‘there’s a climate emergency, we need to act now’? And now we say: oh, let’s just give more fossil subsidies to fossil fuel projects which will make us more dependent of a gas lock-in and will not bring us to a climate-neutral economy that is so desperately needed. This is really a mistake: you can change it. That was the old Commission. The new Commission can do better now.

name: Robert Roos
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, the construction of the trans-European energy network is designed to ensure security of supply by exchanging surpluses and deficits between European countries. A great investment in essential infrastructure. The proposal also covers high-pressure gas pipelines, but our green colleagues in this house see nothing in gas and want to see investment in this infrastructure scrapped.  But how naïve is that? They do not want nuclear energy either. Only solar and wind energy, but with that choice you always need a backup, in if there is no sun and wind. The Green colleagues must recognise that gas-fired power plants are the best solution. We must continue this investment because affordable energy and reliable energy supply are necessary for our economy. With these gas networks, we have also solved the problem in the Netherlands and eight million households can maintain their gas connections. Then we don't all have to work on such a crazy heat pump.

name: Sira Rego
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, this debate would certainly have been unthinkable a while ago and it is surely possible, in part, to the push of young people fighting against climate change on the streets. And for this reason too, from our group we have today considered talking about the objection to projects of common interest, because we understand that in some cases they are not justified ely economically or environmentally.  An example: the Biscay Gulf interconnection project. A project of enormous economic cost that only guarantees the benefit of oligopoly lobbies, and that will in no case solve our country's energy problem.  That is why what I ask you to do is to be told of that spirit, of that common sense of youth fighting on the street, and that we make public money destined for projects that serve to sustainably develop our territories.

name: Ignazio Corrao (NI).
text: – Mr President, as one of the 17 MEPs who supported the veto against the 4th PCI list during the last vote in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE), I can unequivocally confirm my intention to vote against this list again. After the many nice words and promises I heard on a greener future, it would be interesting to see the results of this objection, because we have to be clear: by allowing this 4th list, we would once again be in favour of a future made of fossil fuel. By allowing this list, we would spend billions of euros in investments that could become obsolete in the not-so-distant future. By allowing this list, we would go against the aspirations and dreams of thousands of young people who, in recent years, have taken to the streets in an awe—inspiring call for a better, greener future. We cannot just ignore that. We can’t answer passion with indifference and inaction. We can’t lose credibility. That’s why I confirm my firm support to this objection and against this 4th list of Projects of Common Interest, which is nothing but a betrayal of the new generation, who want fewer words but real change.

name: Markus Pieper (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We all want the energy transition as soon as possible. That is why the PCI list also contains proposals for the development of cross-border electricity networks. We are really expanding network bottlenecks at the borders wonderfully. PCI thus makes a decisive contribution to a genuine European internal market, which we so badly need, especially for renewables. PCI is also preparing for the hydrogen age. To do this, we need investment in gas networks and gas storage facilities. We need gas as a bridge for the energy transition, especially in Eastern Europe. Switching from 80% coal to renewable energy, as in Poland – of course, this can only be done with flexible gas-fired power plants that provide energy security. Dear colleagues from the Greens, how can we be against it? The Greens say that we are not investing in fossil fuels, we are not investing in gas, we are rejecting the list. This is pure populism to get nice headlines in the greater mainstream. You are well aware that an energy transition only works with this list, with gas infrastructures, with new electricity grids. However, you are also well aware that this list will, of course, receive a majority in the European Parliament. They want to stay nicely clean, others should do the dirty work. We like to do this because we take sustainability and responsibility seriously.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we realise that this list also contains critical points and, of course, also legitimises doubts. However, we believe – at least as far as my opinion and the views of the members of ITRE and my group are concerned – that there is some balance on this list today and that it also takes into account sources that are undeniably useful in the transition phase.  I would add that this is an indicative list, that not all projects will be approved, and so if the priorities have changed we will also be able to work on this list. It should not be taken as cast gold. And then the prevailing consideration, and legally no one can deny it, is that if we reject this list, the third list, which is undeniably worse, is undeniably against environmental objectives.  So the point now is to work to ensure that in the next list there is first and foremost a full involvement, Commissioner, of Parliament, and above all work, between now and the resolution that will be presented in March, so that we can also grasp in this time all those elements that can also not only modify and perhaps revise the projects or put the most critical projects at the bottom of the priorities. , but also to decide how we must work to ensure that in the next choices there is strict compliance with the environmental objectives and the issues posed by all our choices on transition and decarbonisation. But for these reasons we believe that it is wrong to reject this fourth list by taking up the objection.

name: Christophe Grudler (Renew).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we must develop our cross-border energy networks to ensure that our citizens have accessible, safe and sustainable energy. If we vote for the objection and therefore against the list, the 2017 list will be active with 53 gas projects, compared to only 32 for the new one. This fourth list is not perfect, but it goes in the right direction, that of the Green Pact. 98% of new projects are good, environmentally friendly projects. Let's not block them. We must also stop the populist psychodrama: no, gas infrastructure does not only carry fossil gas. Tomorrow, they will carry decarbonized hydrogen, biomethane, green gases. We need it. So, yes to this list and together let us improve the consultation and the criteria with the Commission, with Parliament, to draw up the fifth list of 2021, on the road to the Green Pact.

name: Jutta Paulus (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to put a few things straight: it has now been said several times that the third PCI list is much worse than the fourth. That is true, no one has disputed that. But the point is this: the major gas projects that were on the third list have either been completed or have long since been abandoned. In other words, if we fall back to the third, it is not so bad from the point of view. And I would like to make a little more difference: it seems that no one here has read the Artelys study, which has just been published, and the Energy Advisory Agency makes it quite clear that in order to meet our gas needs by 2050 and to be able to transport green gases and hydrogen, which has all been mentioned here, we do not need a new infrastructure. In other words, this EUR 29 billion is stranded assets, as has already been said, and we should better invest this money for a real energy transition, and that is what I am asking you to do.

name: Izabela-Helena Kloc (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Trying to stop the fourth LIST of PCI shows ideological blindness. This list is the result of an 18-month consultation with various stakeholders, including representatives of consumer and environmental organisations. In fact, it was approved by the ITRE Committee by rejecting the blocking resolution by a large majority. Opponents of this list should simply respect this result, especially since the data on energy production are unambiguous. According to a new study by think tanks Agora Energiewende and Sandbag, coal energy production in the European Union fell by 24% in 2019. About half of energy production has been replaced by renewable energy sources, but the other half has been replaced by gas. These figures clearly show that even the most ambitious plans cannot leave gas behind. The countries of Central and Eastern Europe understand this logic. Their energy mix cannot be changed overnight. Gas will remain here for decades to come, whether you like it or not.  Yet ideological... (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Marc Botenga (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I believe that we need to change the rules urgently. Today you present us with a list of a few dozen investments in polluting fossil gas. Billions of euros in energy are in danger of killing, because it is poison for the environment, poison for our planet, poison even for our air. You are proposing to invest our money, taxpayers' money, in poison, rather than taking that money and putting it in renewable, clean energy. I don't understand that. There is a second aspect that bothers me. Last week, I spoke with your colleague from the Commission, I asked him the question and what did he say to me? First, he told me that I should not take what he had written too seriously. Then he told me that you were going to tax more. That, to me, is unacceptable. We're going to sell poison to people and we're going to tax them on this poison. They're going to pay twice. Please stop this, change the rules.

name: Ivan Vilibor Sinčić (NI).
text: – Dear Chairman, we are talking about strategic projects for Europe here, but we must say how they affect our fellow citizens and households.  Here I will mention a project that unfortunately denies this Green Deal of yours, and also denies Europe as a space for the rule of law. Namely, under point 6 point 5 of this list there is an LNG terminal in Omišalj on Krk. It is an uneconomic, opaque and undemocratic project. The project is against the spatial plans of the municipality and the County of Primorje-Gorski Kotar, the project is against the will of the citizens of the municipality and the county.  This project shuts down the Aarhus Convention, which allows citizens the right to access information, which gives them the right to be decided in such environmental matters. How the project ended up on this list is unclear because it takes interest from at least two countries for it to be here, and apart from two public Croatian companies, no one has come forward. So it's about two and a half billion cubic meters of cubic gas that we have nowhere to store, no one to sell to, and nowhere to spend. And worst of all, Article 12 of the special law defines that if losses are to occur, and they will, they switch to users. (The Chairman terminated the Member)

name: Tom Berendsen (PPE).
text: Mr President, we face a complex task and we can only achieve our goals by making wise choices step by step. For example, it is a wise choice to invest in viable and affordable solutions and not to wipe technologies off the table because they simply do not fit into a particular ideal. An example of this is CO2 capture and storage, a technology essential for making the industry more sustainable. I therefore like to see that investments are being made in this type of project in the North Sea. It is also a wise choice to invest in the transition from coal to gas in certain parts of the European Union. This is a step that cannot simply be missed in order to make a viable and affordable transition in certain parts of the European Union. It is a wise choice to invest in European infrastructure. We must tackle this at European level and not in the Member States individually, because soon each Member State will be able to fill in how energy is generated. But together we can ensure that we complement each other, absorb each other's peaks and troughs and increase efficiency, energy security, flexibility and affordability. But, ladies and gentlemen, let us not forget this: the European Union cannot do this alone. To combat climate change, the rest of the world will have to participate. The only way we can inspire them is to create a viable and affordable transition in Europe and make sensible choices.

name: Robert Hajšel (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I understand the concerns of all my colleagues who say that it is not good if we reinvest in projects that also include fossil fuels. On the other hand, it must be said that this fourth list is progress against the third list. Indeed, the third list contained more than 40% more gas projects than 40% more, and it must also be said that this fourth list therefore contains less by 40%, and also contains many more electrical interconfectors, as well as intelligent electricity networks. I know it is not, it is far from this fourth list to be perfect, but it is a good way to start meeting those objectives that we have set out in our Green Deal. However, it must be said that by approving this fourth list, we must insist on the Commission to come forward with a revision of the regulation on trans-European energy networks, which sets out the criteria for how to select these programmes and how to select projects for the future. I am also in favour of the fifth list including, above all, those projects that focus on the use of renewables and, of course, electric inter-inter-inter-sectors and, of course, all smart grids. That is the only way if we want to fulfil what we set out to do in our green deal.

name: Martin Hojsík (Renew).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would be so happy if we would have time to wait until the new 5th list comes out and it’s going to be all green and better, but we should listen to the science. We all say  that we listen to the science and not to the people on the street, so let’s listen to the science. Let’s actually realise that we don’t really have that time. We don’t have time to wait for the 5th list. We actually have to use every euro we have for the transition. We cannot afford a stranded investment that we’re going to face in a number of those projects on the 4th list. Of course, the situation is not black and white. What we see is an increased number (of course it’s the 3rd list) of good projects. So what should we do? Yes, I believe we should reject this list, and it’s up to your Commission to immediately then come up with a new version of the 4th list: a version that would be climate-proof and Green Deal-proof. And I hope this is something that you can make for the Europeans and for the planet.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, honourable Commissioner, I deeply regret that the European Parliament has the right only to reject or approve the whole list of projects of common interest without distinguishing between specific projects. Although I share my colleagues' concerns about the still significant investments in gas infrastructure. This time, I will support the fourth list because it contains an important project for electricity synchronization with Europe for the Baltic states. This is not just a geopolitically important project. In the future, it will also help to expand the wind potential in the Baltic Sea. As regards the forthcoming fifth list, I would like the transatlantic energy infrastructure guidelines to be amended so that in the future the European Parliament can also select itself in the list of projects. That there would be no mere between approval and rejection. Thanks.

name: Manuel Bompard (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, let me tell you a story. It is that of a European Commission which, driven by the mobilization of young people for the climate, claimed to make the ecological emergency its priority. She dressed in a green dress and made many good promises; she even gave them a nice name, the green deal, to show how serious she was. But the Commission found itself very embarrassed when the time for decisions had come. Increase emissions reduction targets? Let's not go too fast! Revising the Common Agricultural Policy? Too late, the project is already complete! Stop funding fossil fuels? Another day, perhaps... Instead, the Commission proposed supporting new gas projects. However, the studies she had done were clear: a reduction in natural gas consumption was essential to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050. But we shouldn't disturb the friends of the gas lobbies. This Wednesday, our Parliament can put an end to this sad fable. By voting our objection, you will refuse to fund anti-ecological projects and put a stop to the Commission's double-talk. Let's finally be consistent.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The Green Deal can only work if we ensure a stable and affordable energy supply, and that requires an energy infrastructure. And the energy infrastructure necessarily includes the projects listed on your fourth PCI list. I strongly support you, Commissioner, with regard to the proposal you have put forward. It is absolutely right that we should also continue to support and promote gas projects. Gas is a transitional technology, a bridge technology that we cannot do without. Mr Pieper mentioned it: a country such as Poland, which is to phase out coal-fired electricity generation. Yes, so what kind of world do we live in? Of course, as a transitional technology, we need gas. That is why I consider it responsible and can only support you for relying on this bridge technology. With regard to the hydrogen technology that needs to be developed, we may also need the cables for this. It is not true that everything is already built – God forbid. When I look at my home region: in Bavaria, not one kilometre has yet been built in the south and south-east, and of course we also need these projects. So, Commissioner, I very much hope that you will get a solid majority for your proposal tomorrow. Our group will support your proposal. And I would simply ask my fellow Members to approach them with a sense of proportion. Those who want the Green Deal must also give some countries the opportunity to rely on gas for a transitional period, and for that we need infrastructure.

name: Mohammed Chahim (S&D).
text: – Mr President, unfortunately, we can only object to or accept the current projects of common interest (PCI) list as a whole. We do not have a say on individual projects, and I have many objections. First, no environmental assessment has been undertaken. What are the effects of the current list with respect to the European Green Deal and ambition of this Parliament? This list will lock us into fossil fuels for the next decades. It would be irresponsible to spend billions of taxpayers’ money on these projects. Second, talking about the taxpayers’ money, the current PCI list contains more than 20 UK projects, of which 6 are not linked to the EU at all. Should we really pay with our taxpayers’ money for projects between the UK and Norway while we know that many regions in Europe need that money for their transition? The only way for us to get an adapted list is to vote against the current list. We need a list that serves the European common interest, and is in line with our ambition towards a sustainable Europe. So, colleagues, vote like I will  – for the objection.

name: Ville Niinistö (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, three months ago in this Parliament, in this House, we declared a climate emergency. A month after that, the Commission came forward with its answer: the Green Deal. It was supposed to be ambitious climate leadership from Europe, and now we are here today looking at a list where we continue funding fossil gas projects on a massive scale. If we are honest about it, this is nothing more than self—betrayal. This is not the climate leadership that our youth and the climate movement are expecting of us. So the Commission has to think again about not continuing the policies of the past, but instead investing in the future. The UN Environment Programme’s Emissions Gap Report called on the EU to refrain from any investment in fossil fuel infrastructure, including new natural gas pipelines. We are locking our emissions to a level which is unsustainable for decades to come. So I appeal to the Parliament that we vote down this list and start a Green Deal today rather than just talking about it.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, this vote is a defining moment for this Parliament. The projects of common interest list of energy infrastructure projects contains 55 fossil fuel projects. The recent Artelys report on gas supply security in the EU, commissioned by the European Climate Foundation, acknowledges the role of existing gas infrastructure in protecting the EU’s energy security, and the report says the new gas projects on the PCI list are not necessary. Therefore, we risk wasting EUR 39 billion of unnecessary money on gas infrastructure projects. Gas is not a transition fuel and its total greenhouse gas emissions surpass those of coal. We should acknowledge, as well, that the PCI process is legally unsafe and is leaving itself open for legal challenge in the Member States due to the reckless behaviour of the Director—General for Energy in compiling a list of projects without taking on board the climate impacts. If we vote for this, it just means that we don’t give a damn about the Paris Agreement and that the Green Deal is a load of nonsense.

name: Pernille Weiss (PPE).
text: Mr President! Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Kadri Simson, once again the green transition has become a battleground of words, not about the right and responsible solutions for the environment and the climate, but rather about political profiling.  We are now hearing school examples of green populism when it comes to the fourth PCI list. It is sad and it is a bad thing for the green transition. The fourth PCI list includes, among other things, the so-called "North Sea Wind Power Hub", a collaboration between Denmark, the United Kingdom, Germany, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, Ireland, France and Luxembourg. A project that has the potential to deliver around 20% of EU energy consumption. Therefore, if we reject the fourth PCI list, this project will be postponed in unknown time.  Opponents of the fourth PCI list are unhappy with the gas projects on the list. This is despite the fact that gas is an important energy source in the transition to a fossil-free future. In fact, the new list has only 32 gas projects, compared with 53 on the old one.  Let us now go pragmatically to the green transition, it is too important for populist snap solutions. The fourth PCI list is an important step towards a sustainable future of security of supply and green jobs.

name: Nicolás González Casares (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Simson, this whole debate can be avoided if the next list is really consulted and planned with this Parliament. It is sometimes also eye-catching to see how countries that do not meet their renewables targets by 2020 want to give lessons to those they have fulfilled, yes they are meeting, and they want to tell us how things should be done in the future. Renewable cabbage people can't say that abandoning coal is so simple and that we can't use gas. Therefore, we need to plan for that future. More than 60% of our final consumption is fossil energy, and that's what we need to change in the next generation. And we have to do it fairly, avoiding frustrations in all directions. We need to advance renewable energy, electrification, smart grid development, sectoral coupling and connections for offshore wind energy. Do we achieve any of these objectives by rejecting the fourth list and returning to the third list? My answer is no. We're not going to have any more electrical projects, let alone. We will not guarantee more smart network projects, but less. It is not to guarantee fewer gas projects, but to put in more pipelines. Therefore, let us not transfer misleading messages to citizens. We must align ourselves with the European Union's climate objectives, ensuring energy security for the Member States and, moreover, working for neutrality with ambition, but also rigorously. Decarbonizing our economy is a process we have to do among all.

name: Henrike Hahn (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, you have just told us that you want to make progress as quickly as possible in the PCI process. As quickly as possible, that is not enough for us. The European Commission is presenting us with a PCI list of energy projects that should be in the common European interest. And what do we find on it? 32 fossil gas projects. This list binds us in Europe for decades to fossil energy, against the Green New Deal, against the requirements of the Paris climate targets and against the European Parliament resolution on the climate emergency. This list sinks billions of taxpayers' money into a fossil-fuel grave, a Europe that, according to the same European Commission, wants to be climate neutral by 2050. This is totally absurd! We want this PCI Stone Age list to be rejected and a new processing of THE TEN-E regulation, not as quickly as possible, but now! We want fossil natural gas projects to be replaced by electricity projects, smart build and renewable energy projects. We want climate protection to be at the heart of the Commission's future industrial policy strategy, with a separate chapter on renewable energy. That is what we want this week, here and now, and quickly.

name: Ciarán Cuffe (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, we declared a climate emergency; now the hard work begins to deliver on the Paris Agreement and increase our ambition to reduce emissions by 55% by 2030. We’re not going to do this by building terminals for importing fracked gas. We’re not going to do this by increasing leaks of methane. If projects of common interest don’t protect our common home, if they’re not Paris compatible, then they must be scrapped. So let’s power-up offshore wind, invest in energy efficiency and retrofit every home in Europe over the next 30 years. Lower fuel bills, saving the planet: it’s a win-win. What’s not to like? Commissioners, back to the drawing board. Fáilte mhór and welcome to my new colleagues in the Green Group here in Europe and a big shout out and comhghairdeas to my newly-elected Teachtaí Dála in the Irish parliament in Dáil Éireann. Let the green wave continue.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for In my opinion, the proposal to reject the fourth list, which came to light after several months of consultation and work, including legislative work, and which is a balanced list because it takes account of climate objectives, but also the need to ensure energy security, is incompatible with common sense. Indeed, you do not look at the whole of Europe because they come from one country or at least from those countries that are doing quite well economically. Moreover, this proposal does not take seriously the legislative arrangements of the last parliamentary term. Most of you are in Parliament for the first time and have not participated in those negotiations, so I would remind you that this is, among other things, the Clean Energy Electricity Package, in which we have obliged the Member States to increase the number of cross-border connections and to switch to less carbon-intensive sources of electricity. This has already been mentioned that we must indeed be able to make an energy transition, a proper transition from coal to gas and, therefore, a less carbon-efficient economy than before. This seems quite obvious to me, especially as it is about projects of strategic importance.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner Simson, security of supply, diversification of energy sources and low-priced energy for citizens and industry are the main axes on which we must move with a view to the transition to the carbon-free economy in 2050. The transition process needs to be supported by projects of common interest, but also by the transition fuel that is natural gas. Countries that determine the success of the Green Deal project, such as Germany, rely on the energy security offered by natural gas. The fourth list of projects of common interest includes EastMed, IGB, FSRU in Alexandroupolis and the gas depot in Kavala. They are all projects of transition and of great geopolitical importance. They cover security of supply in Greece and it is necessary to do so in order to be able to move on the road to complete de-lignification. It is important that these infrastructures can be used for both hydrogen and green natural gas. Not to shoot our feet today; not to return to the third list; not to deprive countries that do not have the economic potential to proceed with the transition in the best possible way.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Mr President, I must confess that I understand the citizens who are no longer trusting us, the elected representatives of Europe. During this session, the European Parliament will have to vote on a trade agreement with a dictatorship, in the name of human rights. And today we have a list of the Commission, a list of 29 billion infrastructure for gas projects, in the name of the environment. So I confess that it is difficult to navigate. It is well known that fossil gas contributes to a quarter of global warming. In addition, the fossil gas you want to support is a gas that supports fracking, highly polluting and dangerous to air, water and health. Let us be consistent with our commitments and the commitments that are demanded not only by citizens, but also by scientists. Hundreds of IPCC scientists are asking us to take action now. Let us reject the list, but also, Commissioner, come as soon as possible with a change in regulations and with a revised list.

name: Clare Daly (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President. I agree with colleagues who said that this is one of the most serious decisions that this Parliament has been faced with. If we don’t reject this list, then it will stand as a monument to our hypocrisy. Because what we’re looking at is Member States who committed to stopping subsidising fossil fuels by 2025 actually agreeing to commit and tie us – lock us – into that dependence for 40 years. It is utter lunacy when we’re supposed to be committing to being carbon neutral by 2050, and you simply can’t do it if we agree with this list. Projects which have been assessed as being unnecessary and unviable. A waste of EUR 29 billion that could be used elsewhere, and scandalous projects like liquid natural gas, importing fracked gas into Ireland. And I genuinely believe that the PCIs are legally unsafe, as there hasn’t been an assessment of the climate impacts. And can I ask what the common interests are on the list, when they’ve been put together with so much pressure from the Trump administration, be it through tariffs on the auto industry or the military presence on Polish soil? It’s a long way away from an independent, environmentally-friendly energy policy.

name: Eleonora Evi (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, either the new European Commission understands that it has presented a totally wrong list, and therefore understands the mistake and withdraws the proposal and proposes a new one that is truly climate proof and future proof, or the Green Deal is a big lie. Today, using public money, european citizens' money to finance projects that are still linked to fossil fuels is something crazy and unacceptable. Building infrastructure today that will soon become stranded assets makes no sense. Building infrastructure today to transport gas with all the ones that already exist, with demand falling, with the forecasts that the European Commission itself makes in all the long-term strategy scenarios that indicate a reduction in demand of up to 90 %, makes no sense. If at least we here in the European Parliament want to be credible to the citizens, we cannot approve this list presented by the Commission. We absolutely must reject it and we cannot afford to make mistakes, because we have no more time.

name: Kadri Simson
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I say to the House: Members, I have listened very carefully, and what I can say is: I heard different views on the project list. But there was one common thing, a common call for more climate action and increased ambition, and the Commission shares your call.  We are committed to make Europe the first carbon-neutral continent by 2050. And I’m glad that most of you expressed support for the Commission’s plan to revise the TEN-E Regulation by December 2020. Because a modern, secure and smart energy infrastructure will sustain this energy transition and help us roll out the large-scale deployment of energy from renewable sources.  With a future revision, we intend to bring the TEN-E framework fully in-line with, and fully supportive of, Europe’s climate objective. We will be supporting investments that help to bring about more renewable energy solutions and new technological innovation.  On the 4th PCI list, I hope you can see this list as another step forward, a cleaner energy infrastructure system. It supports key new electricity projects that help us step into more renewables and the digital potential of our grid. We will have, clearly, the European Green Deal in mind when addressing the funding of projects from this list and other self-regulation. This list is not a guarantee.  However, it is clear to me that the 5th PCI list will be a very different list. Two years after the launch of the Green Deal, sustainability criteria will be thoroughly applied for any projects, including gas candidate projects.  The sustainability tests to pass to be eligible for funds will be stronger, and this Parliament will have a greater say in project selection than its predecessor.  I look forward to our cooperation and future dialogue to make our common vision for tomorrow’s energy infrastructure a reality. And a more modern TEN-E Regulation will help us fund the right projects to deliver a cleaner, more secure and more competitive energy system for Europe.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote on the objection pursuance to Rule 111 of the Rules of Procedure on the Union list of projects of common interest will take place on Wednesday 12 February 2020 at 12 noon. The vote on the conclusion of the motions for resolutions on the oral question to the Commission will take place during the March 2020 part-session. Written declarations (Rule 171 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. – Recent decisions by the European Parliament have provided the basis and the European Union's obligation to approach climate change in a responsible and prudent manner. We therefore need an energy transition that does not lead to an increase in consumer energy and food prices and does not impair economic competitiveness. Climate protection efforts should therefore be ededient with the maintenance of security of supply and access to cheap, reliable energy. In this process, pci list 4 is an important step forward. The list includes a record number of renewable energy projects as well as natural gas infrastructure developments essential for the Central European region. Natural gas plays an indispensable role in the region's decarbonisation efforts. Finally, I consider smart grid projects to be particularly important, which will promote the integration of renewable energy sources across Europe. The implementation of the investments on pci list 4 would lead to the creation of an integrated Pan-European network by 2025, which would also achieve the objectives of the Energy Union. Overall, I agree with the projects on the list, as they simultaneously help climate protection, increase the competitiveness of Member States and ensure security of supply.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. – The EastMed pipeline and the Euroasia Interconnector cable are included in the Projects of Common Interest under the 4th Eu energy list and relate to designs in the Anne region. Mediterranean. The development of such energy infrastructures is vital for achieving security, stability and prosperity in the region. Anne. The Mediterranean can become an alternative source of gas and electricity supply to the EU, making a significant contribution to the EU's energy security. After all, in the previous plenary we voted on a report which mentions energy security as an important factor in achieving the EU's strategic autonomy. Turkey's geostrategic developments and aggressive behaviour make it more urgent to proceed with these projects. Furthermore, the promotion of these projects does not go against our climate change targets. Natural gas can be an alternative source for the transition period until we reach the target of a carbon-neutral Europe by 2050. The EuroAsia Interconnector electricity interconnection will end the energy isolation of Cyprus; the last EU Member State that is still energy isolated. Any attempt to delete the list does not contribute to the objective of climate change, but will have significant economic and geostrategic negative effects and possibly more widely subversive.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is one-minute speeches in accordance with Rule 172 of the Rules of Procedure.

name: Tomislav Sokol (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, last week in Brussels we attended the start of work on the European Cancer Plan. And indeed, it was a phenomenal event where we heard a lot of stories from people and practice patients that showed how much the European Union can make a difference in this sense.  However, I hope it's not all that's left on words. In this regard, I would emphasise that the European Union has the same regulatory and financial instruments to actually make the fight against cancer a reality and to achieve quality results in this regard. One of the biggest problems is, as far as fighting cancer is the uneven availability of health care in different regions. In this sense, large differences exist between Central and Eastern Europe on the one hand and Western and Northern Europe on the other.  And I hereby call on the European Commission to take these differences into account, to invest through cohesion policy and other instruments in the development of centres of excellence for the treatment of diseases in central and eastern European countries in order to truly enable and achieve this equal access to healthcare for patients in all EU countries.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Morocco is a preferred partner of the European Union and in the case of the Canary Islands and Spain also a neighbouring country. Having said that, the European Union cannot accept under any circumstances that Morocco unilaterally approves a new maritime delimitation of the waters of the Eastern Atlantic together with the Canary Islands, which undoubtedly affects Spanish competition over those waters.  We are not dealing with a minor matter, nor in the face of a purely bilateral matter. This is a clear violation of international legality and United Nations resolutions. This is an attack on the territorial integrity of a Member State. There are no lukewarm statements. You can't wait to see what happens. The European Union must make an active commitment to curb any unilateral action by Morocco.  And from the sea to the land. I am also extremely concerned about the agreements between London and Rabat on the quotas and entry prices of the tomato - but we will talk about that in the immediate future. In this my first speech in plenary, I demand that the European Union take action on both matters.

name: Traian Băsescu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the other day I had the feeling that the strongest thing we need is solidarity. 5G technology gives us the opportunity to show our solidarity.  For this reason, in order not to create discrepancies between Member States, I propose that the Commission consider achieving a uniform implementation plan throughout the European Union, with the use of a technology strictly produced in the European Union and with strictly issued regulations at European Union level, valid for all States. I am convinced that such an approach will strengthen cohesion between all the States of the European Union.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to address the subject of cohesion policy, because I think this is one of those backbone policies in the EU and it is really irreplaceable in its importance to a number of EU Member States. I would first of all recall the point of the cohesion policy, because its purpose is, in particular, to eliminate the disadvantages suffered by certain regions, weak regions, and to help their growth. Also, of course, for the new countries for fulfilling all the EU standards that were met in the accession talks, this subsidy rule is given, or this support, which comes primarily from direct payers. It is very dangerous if this policy, which actually contributes to eliminating differences, is weakened, and this is what the new multiannual financial framework looks like, unfortunately. I really want to warn against this weakening of cohesion policy, because it can dig up very profound differences. Of course, if the reduction is objective as a result of Brexit and other reasons, I understand that, but I think we should stand up for a cohesive policy as the backbone of the EU.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I wanted to inform my colleagues and also the Representative of the Commission that the Czech Senate, the second chamber of Parliament, has adopted an amendment to the Criminal Code, on which I have worked with my colleagues, which tightens penalties for animal cruelty, tightens up the issues of so-called multiplication plants and generally addresses the issue of criminal law and the issue of the animal as a living creature. In the debates that took place in both houses of Parliament, as well as in the professional public, it is clear that this topic is a European issue and that individual countries cannot protect sufficiently effectively the animals that are transported in horrific conditions across Europe today, especially from the so-called new EU countries to the old countries.  These are especially so-called pets, and although at first glance it may be a marginal topic, it is a very serious topic. These are huge tax and economic evasion, and the European Commission needs to start taking this seriously at last and finally start tinging with this. So my aim here is to call on the European Commission to start working on this issue.

name: César Luena (S&D).
text: – Mr President, this legislature is going to be that of the European Green Pact and also that of the fair ecological transition. There is political commitment, there is agreement, but, ladies and gentlemen, at this point I wanted to reflect on the House: there must also be resources. Speeches are very important, essential, but we have to reinforce them with resources. I want to draw attention to several aspects. The sustainable investment plan will need more funds; the Fair Transition Fund will need more funds. And besides, both, greater clarity and precision in their functions and structures. Changing the productive and economic model, in order for sustainable change to really take place, will need tax reform. Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, we now know the challenges and objectives, but we need more resources, more funds, more precision, more clarity and, above all, a new environmental taxation.

name: Robert Hajšel (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in order to ensure a just transition of our economy to greener and more digital, we must do everything we can to ensure that this transition is fair to all. This means that it will not be paid by the most vulnerable populations and that it will not be paid twice. This means that they will not receive any assistance from the European Union, and at the same time energy prices will rise. We have to take care of all this. At the same time, we have the instruments put forward by the European Commission are the right step forward. This is also, for example, a fair trance fund. Here again, we must ensure that the money from this fund is put where we need it most, namely those regions that will be most affected by this transformation and those people who will suffer the most. We really need to be able to help these regions, but also the countries that, together with these regions and in cooperation with the European Commission, will develop these transformation plans, which must be a success.

name: Sara Cerdas (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we are currently working on the new programme for research and development, Horizon Europe. This programme will train our young people and provide them with skills for the most different professional areas and research. We hope that these skills are transmitted by the education system. Member States should therefore take advantage of the European Union's instruments for research and innovation in order to provide pupils and teaching staff with skills that are adapted to the real needs of the world of work.
