I recently had the opportunity to meet with companies linked to the research and innovation area of Madeira - an outermost region - who rightly said that today's needs are not the same as in the past. I therefore hope that Horizon Europe will be used and empowered by the Member States in order to invest in a real curricular transformation and that it will translate into pioneering research and excellence.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the 24th Conference of the OuterMost Regions, known as the RUP, took place in Saint Martin, France, on 6 and 7 February. What are they? Territorially, fragmented territories away from the space of supranational integration. Legally, the only European regions mentioned by name in primary European law — in the Treaty of Lisbon, Article 349. But, politically, they are a platform of awareness identified with the raison d'etion of Europe, which is territorial, social and intergenerational cohesion, which is threatened by a multiannual downside financial framework, which in no case can be at the expense of policies now called traditional ones such as agriculture, cohesion and the Regional Development Fund.  That is why it is imperative that outermost regions maintain 85% co-financing for their strategic projects. And its energy uniqueness, in integrating global trade, protecting its sensitive products, and also in the face of the migration challenge at its vulnerable borders. In order to keep the outermost regions afloat, they are committed to MEPs born and living in those regions.

name: Adrian-Dragoş Benea (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we must realise that in order to achieve the ambitious objectives of the European Green Pact we need not only smart and sustainable transport solutions, but also sustainable transport paths built in respect for the environment.  They come from a country facing the consequences of the lack of a National Management Plan for protected sites and natural areas. Large infrastructure works, such as the Sibiu-Piteşti motorway, or the bypass version of The municipality of Bacău, are affected, among other things. Without these investments we cannot develop Romania and the North-East region, one of the poorest in the European Union. It is the duty of the Bucharest government to speed up the management plans of protected natural sites, so as not to block those infrastructure works. Therefore, Moldova's highway must be environmentally friendly and affect as little as possible the flora and fauna of the protected sites. I am in favour of the Iaşi-Bacău-Braşov motorway variant, the optimal solution for connecting Moldova with Transylvania, only 8% impact on protected areas, compared to 55% impact for the Targu-Mures-Iaşi variant.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: Mr President, several months ago we took the decision — as the European Union — to impose sanctions on Turkey because of its illegal interventions in the Cypriot EEZ. While we are still waiting for the measures, Turkey has agreed with the Tripoli regime to share the sea with each other, which has already been found by the European Union to be completely legally unfounded and invalid. The other day, Turkey announced new illegal actions throughout the Eastern Mediterranean. So I wonder: is this the effectiveness of the European Union in imposing measures and sanctions on such a predatory state as Turkey?  Is this the effectiveness of the European Union in defending its own interests and international law? I therefore believe that, as Mr President-in-May has put it, the Commission has not been in a good way. Borrell, it is simply a matter of applying international law and the European Union must find ways to defend its own interests.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, this decision can save millions of lives. The reopening of the Cantacuzino Institute in Romania must become a priority for the European Union. In the context of the many current concerns about the evolution of influenza, measles, the newer coronavirus and microbial resistance, as well as the need to increase confidence in immunisation solutions, I call on you today, honourable commission, to give priority funding to this strategic objective.  My legislative solution was adopted by the Romanian Parliament \u2012 which is right, after I have tabled it there seven times , but in order to be truly effective, this objective must be part of an integrated plan at European level and can become a strategic objective for the European Union. This will ensure safe, cheap and timely vaccines. 21 strategic vaccines were produced in Romania, and the Institute was one of seven influenza vaccine-producing institutes at European level. We can provide unique products that increase immunity, such as Qantas Timus and Polydin, and, moreover, in crisis situations such as coronavirus now, early and rapid diagnosis can be made and epidemics prevent. I think this European standard of quality in health that I have proposed... (The President interrupted the speaker) ... already in the European Parliament must become a reality.

name: Juozas Olekas (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we are currently actively discussing the European Green Course, the European Union's growth strategy, which must not only counteract our impact on the climate and strengthen the protection of the environment and biodiversity, but also ensure the well-being of the people of Europe.  The common agricultural policy will also have to achieve greater environmental, economic and social sustainability. At the same time, it will have to promote the development of viable rural areas, ensuring a fair income for farmers and rural populations. However, the social and economic sustainability necessary for the success of the green course will not be achieved if farmers in different countries of the European Union continue to receive different rewards for the same work. In Lithuania and other Baltic countries, farmers working according to the same requirements, which guarantee high standards of food safety and quality, environmental and animal welfare, still receive direct payments much lower than the European Union average. The new green course is a historical opportunity. In order to preserve our planet and the future of our children and grandchildren, we must ensure justice, equal and fair opportunities for all Lithuanian farmers, as well as equally fair benefits.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Britain's exit from the European Union is a moment that should not be treated lightly. It is about the loss of an important member of the European Union, but also about how we will continue to cooperate in the future, in the interests of all parties involved, including the 3 million Europeans living there.  Already almost half a million Romanians have registered for the right of residence and we here in the European Parliament are expected to defend their rights, but above all to find new solutions to relaunch the European project. As an MEP, I reiterate the need to create a new status for European citizenship, an explicit legal guarantee of EU citizenship, without differences, without inequalities, a guarantee for equal treatment. EU citizens support this, and in Romania, for example, tens of thousands of people have signed the petition initiated together with PES activists Romania for this. Debates on the future of the EU must focus on the future, citizens and this new status of European citizenship.

name: Klemen Grošelj (Renew).
text: – Dear Mr President! The Western Balkans are also the people who live there, not just geopolitical interests. One such story, important for the region and Bosnia and Herzegovina, is the local elections in Mostar. More than 105,000 residents have been unable to vote for local self-government since 2008 because of political blockades. They're ruled by a technical mayor with no democratic legitimacy.  The unbearability of the situation brought before the European Court of Human Rights by the people themselves has been confirmed by the Court of Justice and ruled that the situation in Mostar constitutes a violation of human rights and imposed a change in electoral law.  But BiH is a special country, and Mostar is also a special place in which the bloody war has left deep and many unheeded wounds. I therefore call on the European Commission to help the people of Mostar and Bosnia complete electoral law within the time limit set by the Court and to allow democratic elections to be held.  While this will not be the realisation of the Commission's 14 points, it will be a concrete step forward in the democratisation of the country, a concrete step in favour of the people of Mostar and a step towards bosnia's values of the European Union and membership.

name: Nicolae Ştefănuță (Renew).
text: – Mr President, the forest is part of Romanian and European DNA. It is no surprise that, in our stakes, NGOs and citizens' associations are actively dealing with the forest.  The exclusion by law of NGOs from the management of protected areas is an incomprehensible limitation, as they should still be able to do projects. These people don't just know the forest well, they love it, they're the guardians of the forest, they've shown this over and over again. Why put the oppositebetween them and their purpose? Let us not forget that by 2019, a third of all Natura 2000 sites were managed by civil society. The state doesn't have the capacity to protect the forest, it doesn't have the money, it doesn't have the people. What logic does it make to stop citizens from offering a helping hand? The European Green Pact is a contract between citizens and institutions, but it will not do itself, it needs to involve people. Romania's forests are the forests of Europe. Our air, the air of the European Union comes from European forests.

name: José Ramón Bauzá Díaz (Renew).
text: – Mr President, the European Parliament is the house of freedom and, for that very reason, last week I invited eight leaders of the Cuban opposition so that they could come to this house to explain what are the stumbles that the dictator Díaz-Canel is exercising and executing, in short, in Cuba. But the problem is, when you deal with dictatorships, dictators show up. And so came the fact that Diaz-Canel and his regime prevented the departure of five Cuban opponents. They could not prevent three of these opponents, because they live outside Cuba, because they live in exile, they could be in this house, in the European Parliament. But, despite this, there was an embarrassing situation and that is that the regime infiltrated in this house a number of people to harass and to verbally assault opponents. And the most shameful of all is that these people were able to enter this house as a result of the GUE/NGL parliamentary group , who are Podemos in Spain – allowed them access precisely to boycott, to break our act. In short, let Mr Díaz-Canel know, let the dictators know, that, as long as there is such action against human and civil rights, this Parliament... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Irena Joveva (Renew).
text: – Mr President, it is no longer about less. You know, I haven't been in politics for long, but I know very well that all politics goes through the means. Through money intended to finance joint projects.  The upcoming budget will not only have an impact over the next seven years, but will form the basis for decades of future development of the European project. Without a sufficiently adequate budget, it will not be possible to finance ambitious and necessary plans for a secure, digital and green Europe. Nor will it be possible to maintain the level of cohesion and agricultural policy, which are key to the development of Europe. It's necessary, both first and second. While cohesion funds are paid to less developed regions, they do have an impact on the development of the union as a whole. But there are two things that need to be taken care of, otherwise there will be no future. This is unity and solidarity.  And that's exactly what cohesion is for. It's time for us all to know these realities. We need more for more.

name: André Rougé (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the French overseas departments, regions and communities of Guadeloupe, Guyana, Martinique, Réunion, Mayotte and Saint-Martin, known here as the RUPs, must not be sacrificed for the future common agricultural policy.  In 2018, the European Commission has proposed a 3.9% reduction in THE CISI budget. It is thanks to these ultramarine regions that consumers can taste many exotic products: bananas, rum or cane sugar. Overseas agricultural and agri-food sectors must be supported. It is about the prosperity of our farmers and their families, the sustainability of local agricultural production and specific supply regimes.  That is why, together with Marine Le Pen and the National Rally, we call on the Commission to maintain a minimum or even increase the current budget of the POSEI regime.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ID).
text: Mr President, by virtue of a strange tradition, countries that take over the presidency of the Council for six months are sponsored by private companies. From my point of view, this is outrageous, because this practice casts doubt on the impartiality of public decision-makers.  Last year, Romania was sponsored by Coca-Cola. This American multinational paid him more than 40,000 euros and, in return, was given the right to offer invitations to public events organized by the Romanian Presidency. The mix of the public and private interests was at its height. This year, Croatia pledged to be exemplary. Alas, it failed, since this country was sponsored by the INA group, an oil company. To say the least, this does not fit very well with the draft green pact which is the priority of the von der Leyen Commission.  We must learn from this and immediately ban the sponsorship of the Council presidencies, without waiting for Germany to be sponsored tomorrow by BMW and for France to do the same the day after tomorrow with the Rothschild Bank.

name: Carlo Fidanza (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the last few days we have promoted a letter to President Sassoli, which I first signed and signed by 35 other Italian MEPs, in which we called for a moment of remembrance to be dedicated today, 10 February, at the opening of the session, to the approximately 30 000 martyrs of the foibe, deep karst cavities, and to 350 000 Italians exiled from Istria. , River and Dalmatia.  We acknowledge that President Sassoli has accepted this request. A minute's silence and a dry message of remembrance. It remains regrettable that, even on this occasion, it has not been found the courage to clearly indicate the historical responsibilities of the Slavic-Communist partisans of Marshal Tito, often aided by Italian ones, in that heinous ethnic cleansing against the Italians. Those Italians died or fled exiles, yes, but they are never said to be killed by whom or to escape from whom. Yesterday's oblivion and today's denialism and justificationism are fought with the courage of historical truth. As long as there are second-class and second-class deaths, there can be no real peace.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: Mr. Trump has the floor. Wallace for a minute.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, what’s the topic?

name: President. –
text: The irregular handling of the Democratic Party’s Iowa caucus by the Iowa Democratic Party and the National Committee in the United States and the concerns it raises for the integrity of the US electoral system.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, my colleague, seemingly, is going to speak on that subject. While I have the opportunity, I might as well use my minute. We had a very interesting election in Ireland at the weekend, where the neoliberal parties of Fianna Fáil and Fine Gael got their comeuppance and we had an absolute upheaval. It was a direct response from the people to incredible unfairness in how the country is governed. So many people have been left behind by the so-called ‘economic recovery’, and sadly, the government have failed to deal with serious problems that were affecting the people. We have a homelessness crisis. We have a housing crisis. They failed to deal with them. We bailed out the banks. We borrowed billions, and we loaded the burden on the ordinary people. We set up a bad bank called NAMA to deal with distressed assets – they cost the state over EUR 20 billion, and nobody blinks an eyelid. We have a lot of problems, but maybe the elections this weekend will go a little bit towards addressing them.

name: Clare Daly (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, (inaudible passage) that this Parliament never misses the opportunity to lecture other countries about their electoral processes or to have a meltdown about electoral interference and yet we’re letting the Iowa caucus go without a mention. Bernie Sanders is on top in the polls, even though we all know the Democrat establishment hates him. Then we find out that the Democrats used an app for the Iowa vote count, built by a company that had taken USD 42 000 from another candidate, Pete Buttigieg. The app broke. The Democrats supressed the result. Mr Buttigieg himself comes out, announces himself the winner and happy days. Now, if this was a reality TV show, we’d be laughing. If it was Iran, Syria or Russia, we’d be suspending the debate here, we’d be apoplectic in our condemnation, but because it’s the United States, that great country that spent so much time bringing democracy to the rest of the world, we say nothing. Well, it’s a bad day and a blight on any semblance of democracy that this type of carry—on would go on, and I didn’t want this to pass without comment.

name: Λευτέρης Νικολάου-Αλαβάνος (NI).
text: Mr President, on 18 February workers in Greece strike against the government's bill, which further dissolves social security, resulting in the majority of today's workers getting less than EUR 450 pension. The reductions of the previous SYRIZA government are guaranteed and the increased retirement limits and the guaranteed national poverty pension of EUR 384 are maintained. It opens the way for reserves to be gambled on high-risk investment products. With privatisation, personalisation and cuts there is a risk that the troubles of a lifetime will be lost. But undermining social security is your strategic choice. Your reports on social rights are a big lie. Similar anti-labour projects are being promoted in France, Belgium and elsewhere and workers are responding to racing. Looking to the new recession that is coming, you are making it easier for employers to reduce insurance contributions, open up a billion-dollar market for the profits of insurance monopolies and distribute them "hot" money. By fighting workers and the self-employed, they will thwart the plans of the European Union and governments, demanding social security under the responsibility of the state and with free health and welfare services.

name: Eugen Tomac (PPE).
text: – Mr President, my intervention today concerns a country in our immediate vicinity of the Eastern Partnership.  In the European Union we have 24 official languages. It seems, however, that, for the Kiev authorities, it is not enough that the language Romanian is the official language of the European Union and, by the education law amended in 2017, by which minorities are denied access to their mother tongue, an extremely serious thing is happening: the minority Romanian is facing a thesis that the Soviet Union has created, namely that the language Romanian is nothing but a foreign language for the Romanians there and that they speak a word called the Moldovan language.  This thesis is today a danger to 500 000 Romanians who speak the Romanian and, because Romanian language teachers in Ukraine are asking to return to the Romanian language, I am also asking for a committee to intervene on this issue. (The President interrupted the speaker)
